name: Ghost Blows Out the Light II
author: Real Overlord
summary: The hit web series "Return to the Ruins of the South Sea" is based on its original novel! The enigma of life and death cycles through the ages, the vanished civilizations of millennia past, the ancient relics buried in dust. A colossal dragon lies coiled upon the vast expanse of land, guarding all that remains. Mighty rivers flow, sands whirl, and seas turn into mulberry fields—what secrets are concealed here? Souls of life entombed wander and struggle, but where is the passage, the gateway to eternal life? A group of explorers stumbles upon these unknown mysteries, gradually unveiling the hidden legends behind them. "Candle in the Tomb II"

chapters.name: Chapter 1: Paper Man
chapters.content:
My grandfather, Hu Guohua, hailed from the Hu family, which was renowned throughout the neighborhood as a lineage of prominent landlords. In their most splendid era, they owned a contiguous stretch of over forty residences along three hutongs in the city. The family’s history boasted officials and merchants alike, and they had even contributed to the imperial grain transportation system during the Qing dynasty.

There's a folk saying that wealth doesn't last beyond three generations, and I've found it to be profoundly true. No matter if one possesses mountains of gold and silver, such wealth cannot withstand the wastefulness of profligate descendants.

By the time of the Republic of China, our family's fortunes began to wane, and it was during my grandfather's generation that the decline became evident. After the family assets were divided, Hu Guohua received a substantial inheritance, sufficient for a lifetime of comfort. Yet, he refused to tread a prudent path, which, admittedly, was partly influenced by the societal milieu of the time. Initially, he succumbed to gambling and later developed an addiction to opium, squandering the great fortune until nothing was left.

In his youth, Hu Guohua indulged in the "five poisons" of drinking, whoring, gambling, opium, and smoking. Eventually, he became so destitute that he didn't have a penny to his name. When a person is afflicted by nicotine addiction, it torments them to the core, making it unbearable to abstain. But without money, how could one indulge? Back when he was wealthy, the proprietors and attendants of the opium dens would lavish him with praise, treating him with the utmost attentiveness. However, once penniless, they would regard him as nothing more than a beggar, eager to hustle him out the door.

Driven to madness by poverty, one's sense of decency and morals may no longer hold significance. Hu Guohua devised a scheme to con some money from his uncle. Knowing his nephew to be a spendthrift and an opium fiend, the uncle had never before been willing to lend him a cent. But this time, Hu Guohua lied, claiming he needed funds to take a wife. The uncle, moved to tears by the prospect of his wayward nephew finally engaging in a respectable endeavor, thought that marrying a virtuous wife might rein him in and perhaps even set him on a path to reform.

So the uncle gave him twenty silver dollars, advising him to marry a good wife and lead a proper life, and above all, to steer clear of opium. He even planned to visit the Hu family in a few days to meet his new niece-in-law.

Ever the schemer, Hu Guohua sought to hoodwink his uncle. Upon returning home, he sought out a craftsman skilled in making paper effigies—those burned as offerings for the deceased. This master of paper art could create anything one could imagine, crafting it with such exquisite detail that it appeared almost lifelike.

 He did as requested and crafted a paper woman out of white paste paper for Hu Guohua, then painted eyebrows, eyes, a nose, clothes, and hair on the paper figure with watercolors. From a distance, it looked just like a living person.

Hu Guohua brought the paper figure home, placed it on the kang in the inner room, and covered it with a quilt. He was quite pleased with himself, thinking that when his uncle visited in a few days, he could simply say his wife was ill, bedridden and unable to receive guests. He imagined his uncle would be content with a brief glimpse from afar. Delighted with his plan, he couldn't help but hum a little tune as he slipped off to the city to smoke opium.

A few days later, his uncle arrived, bringing floral fabrics and pastries to see his nephew's wife. Hu Guohua stuck to his rehearsed script, saying his wife was unwell and couldn't see visitors, allowing his uncle to peek behind the door curtain before quickly dropping it back down.

The uncle was not pleased. "You think you can fob off your own uncle like this? No, I must see the new bride today. If she's sick, I'll pay for a doctor to treat her."

Hu Guohua adamantly refused to let him see her, which only made his behavior seem more suspicious, intensifying his uncle's doubts. As they argued, the curtain to the inner room was suddenly drawn back, and out stepped a woman, fair and clean, with a broad, round face. Hu Guohua's heart skipped a beat. "Good heavens, isn't that the paper figure I had made? How did it come to life?"

The woman greeted the uncle with a bow, apologizing for not having come out to meet him earlier due to her poor health, and asked for forgiveness. She then remarked that she suddenly felt much better and insisted on hosting the uncle for a simple meal. With that, she turned and went to prepare the food.

Hu Guohua's uncle was overjoyed, thinking how virtuous and fortunate-looking his nephew's wife was. "My departed sister, if you knew from the afterlife that your son had married such a fine woman, you'd be thrilled," he thought. In his happiness, he handed Hu Guohua ten silver dollars.

Hu Guohua stood frozen, his mind in turmoil, uncertain whether to feel lucky or frightened. Time flew by, and evening came. The white paper figure had prepared a table full of dishes, delighting the uncle so much that he couldn't stop smiling. Yet Hu Guohua had no appetite; looking at the woman sitting across from him, he felt a revulsion as if he had swallowed a fly. Her face was pale, devoid of any natural color, with rouge applied to give it a semblance of health.

The uncle, with his failing eyesight, noticed nothing amiss about the woman. After several cups of strong liquor, he was thoroughly drunk. Hu Guohua then borrowed a donkey cart and sent him home.

On the way back, Hu Guohua grew increasingly fearful and decided not to return home, instead spending the night in the city's red-light district. There, he squandered the ten silver dollars his uncle had given him on opium and prostitutes.

Eventually, he was thrown out for lack of payment and, with nowhere else to go, he reluctantly headed home. When he arrived, he found the house dark, the white paper figure motionless, lying on his bed under a quilt, as if nothing had ever happened.

 Hu Guohua contemplated keeping her as a living person for the evening, but then thought it better to rid himself of the potential trouble with a swift blaze. He carried the white paper figure out into the courtyard, fetched his flint and fire, and was about to set the paper figure alight when suddenly it began to speak, "You heartless wretch, I've been nothing but kind to you, and now you want to burn me?"

Hu Guohua recoiled in shock, his heart pounding in the dead of night as the paper woman continued, "I took pity on you. Though you indulge in food, drink, and vice, your heart is not entirely corrupt. I wish to marry you. Would you have me?"

Desperately shaking his head, Hu Guohua asked the paper figure if it was a demon or a ghost. The white paper figure replied, "I am indeed a ghost, temporarily residing in this paper figure. But don't you look down on me, you poor wretch. In life, I was wealthy, and the gold and silver ornaments among my burial objects are enough for you to smoke opium for ten lifetimes. Have you not heard? A wealthy ghost is a hundred times better than a destitute soul."

The mention of money stirred something in Hu Guohua, especially since he had recently fallen on such hard times that he had pawned all his clothes. However, he had no desire to gain wealth only to die before enjoying it. He had heard old folks tell of female ghosts who ensnared men, draining them of their yang energy until all that was left was a dry skin-wrapped skeleton. So he said to the paper figure, "Even if your feelings for me are genuine, I cannot marry you. After all, there is a great divide between the living and the dead, the separation of yin and yang. To do otherwise would be against the natural order."

The white paper figure replied, "If that is how hard your heart is, I won't force you. But a day will come when you will regret this decision. Remember, if you ever become so destitute that you can't go on, seek me out at the desolate graves of Thirteen Li Shops. In the midst of that graveyard, there is a solitary grave without a headstone. Inside lies my coffin, and within it, there is plenty of gold. If you dare to come, take the wealth and spend it as you please."

With that, the white paper figure fell silent and motionless. Hu Guohua, mustering all his courage, lit a fire and reduced the white paper figure to ashes.

Later, when he was so impoverished that he had no other choice, he thought of digging up the grave at Thirteen Li Shops, but each time he refrained, scraping by through borrowing and scrounging. Two years later, when he was utterly destitute and at his wits' end, he finally went to that graveyard—but that is a story for another time.

chapters.name: Chapter 2: Rat Friends
chapters.content:
This Spring Festival season was rife with incidents, and the deception of Hu Guohua's uncle through the crafting of a paper figure for money was finally exposed. His uncle, enraged and overwhelmed, fell ill and within three days, departed this world.

Relatives and friends of the Hu family guarded themselves against him as if he were a thief; not only did they refuse to lend him money, but they wouldn't even spare him leftover scraps of food. Driven to desperation, Hu Guohua sold the last pair of sandalwood chests in his home for two silver dollars. These chests, part of his mother's dowry, were treasured memories he had been reluctant to pawn. But his nicotine addiction was relentless, and he could no longer afford sentimentality. With the two dollars, he purchased a small piece of opium and hurried home, where he eagerly lit his pipe and collapsed onto the bed. After a couple of deep inhales, his body felt as light as if he were floating on clouds.

In that moment, he felt as blissful as an immortal, free from the disdain, insults, and bullying that plagued his daily life. After another couple of puffs, he suddenly noticed a dark shape on his tattered bed. Squinting, he saw a large rat, old enough to have white whiskers and nearly the size of a cat, inhaling the smoke drifting from Hu Guohua's opium pipe as if it too understood the allure of opium, greedily savoring the fumes.

Hu Guohua found this amusing and spoke to the rat, "You too have a craving for nicotine, it seems we are kindred spirits." After taking another puff, he blew smoke rings towards the rat which, sensing no harm from him, raised its head to receive the offered haze. After a while, having had its fill, the rat slowly crawled away.

For several days, this rat kept Hu Guohua company in his smoking ritual. Shunned by everyone and friendless, Hu Guohua felt a strange kinship with the creature and would sometimes wait for it, enduring his nicotine cravings.

But the good times were short-lived. The Hu family's possessions dwindled to a mere bed and four walls, and there was no money left for tobacco. Distraught and without a plan, he sighed to the rat, "Oh rat, my pockets are empty, and I can no longer afford opium. I fear we can't continue to indulge in this pleasure." His voice trailed off in lament.

The rat, upon hearing his words, looked thoughtful, its eyes shining with intelligence. It then turned and left. At dusk, it returned, placing a silver dollar beside Hu Guohua's pillow. Overjoyed, Hu Guohua rushed into town that very night and purchased a piece of opium. He returned home, lit the pipe under the lamp, and, along with the rat, indulged in a satisfying session of smoking.

The following day, the rat brought three more silver dollars, leaving Hu Guohua so elated he scarcely knew what to say. Recalling an anecdote from his private school days, he said to the rat, "He who knew Guan Zhong was Bao Shuya. You know of my poverty and have generously bestowed upon me, truly you are my confidant. If you do not disdain it, let us become Sworn Brothers of the Golden Orchid." Henceforth, he called the rat 'Brother Rat,' sharing food and opium with it, even arranging a cotton nest on the bed so that the rat could sleep beside him.

 Living in harmony with a rat was no less remarkable than having a sworn friend. Every day, the rat would bring back silver coins, sometimes one or two, other times three to five. From then on, Hu Guohua's worries about food and clothing were over. Years later, when my grandfather reminisced, he would always say those days were the happiest of his life.

Half a year passed in this way, and Hu Guohua gradually prospered. But as the saying goes, wealth finds friends, and misfortune finds foes. It seemed Hu Guohua was fated to be poor, and soon enough, a villain set his sights on him.

There was a rogue in the village named Wang Ergang, who was unlike Hu Guohua. Hu Guohua had at least known wealth, having been called Young Master Hu for over twenty years.

Wang Ergang, on the other hand, wasn't so fortunate. From his ancestors down to his own generation, none had ever worn trousers that didn't expose their rear. He gloated over the downfall of the Hu family, and whenever he could, he would insult and bully Hu Guohua, tormenting the former Young Master Hu for his own sense of balance.

Lately, he found it strange that Hu Guohua, who had no visible means of income and whose family had pawned everything of value, could still afford to smoke opium daily. His relatives were nearly all gone, so where was the money coming from? Perhaps this lad had turned to thievery. Wang Ergang thought it might be profitable to secretly watch him and catch him in the act, then turn him over to the authorities for a few silver dollars in reward.

But after keeping watch for some time, Wang Ergang saw that Hu Guohua rarely left his home, except to buy food and opium in town. He never socialized with anyone. The less Wang Ergang knew about the source of the money, the more it itched at his curiosity.

One day, while Hu Guohua was out buying groceries, Wang Ergang took the opportunity to climb over the wall into his house. He rummaged through Hu Guohua's belongings, looking for any secret. Suddenly, he spotted a large rat asleep on the bed. Without a second thought, Wang Ergang grabbed the rat and threw it into a pot of boiling water on the stove, then clamped the lid down, thinking to himself that he would enjoy watching Hu Guohua's reaction when he returned home to drink the water.

Wang Ergang hadn't even left the house when Hu Guohua returned, catching him red-handed. Seeing the rat in the pot, boiled alive, Hu Guohua's eyes blazed with fury. He grabbed a kitchen knife and began to hack at Wang Ergang, who was struck multiple times. Fortunately for Wang Ergang, Hu Guohua was weakened by opium, so the blows weren't fatal. Bleeding profusely, Wang Ergang managed to escape to the local Security Team for help. The captain of the Security Team was a relative of a local warlord and was entertaining him at that moment. Outraged that such a brazen attack had happened in broad daylight, the captain quickly ordered his men to seize Hu Guohua, who was bound tightly and brought in.

 Hu Guohua was brought before the court, where the head of the security team demanded loudly why he had attempted to murder Wang Ergang with a knife. 

Tears streaming down his face, Hu Guohua sobbed as he recounted the events that had led up to the incident, concluding with a lament: "Thinking back on how I was once on the brink of death from hardship, had it not been for that old rat, I wouldn't have survived to this day. Yet, due to a moment of negligence, I inadvertently caused the death of Brother Rat. Although I was not the one who killed it, its death was because of me. How can I bear the weight of this loyal friend's demise in the netherworld? I am prepared to face the consequences alone for injuring Wang Ergang. Whatever punishment or execution awaits me, I accept it. All I ask is that you allow me to return home to bury my Brother Rat, so that even in death, I may rest in peace."

Before the head of the security team could respond, a warlord standing nearby, moved by Hu's words, addressed him: "To forget kindness is inhuman, but to remain true to one's heart is righteous. If you can show such loyalty to a rat, how much more to your fellow man? I admire your sense of righteousness and see that you are alone in this world. From now on, follow me and serve as my aide-de-camp."

In times of chaos, the one who commands the troops makes the law, and the barrel of a gun is the source of power. The Warlord Leader ordered his men to whip Wang Ergang as a way to vent Hu Guohua's anger and then released Hu to go home and bury the rat. Hu Guohua placed the rat's body in a wooden box, dug a hole, buried it, and wept for a long time before he went to join the Warlord Leader.

As the saying goes: "When starving, chaff tastes as sweet as honey; when full, even honey loses its sweetness." When someone is in dire straits, they are grateful even for a bowl of porridge or a piece of bread from another, let alone the wealth that the rat brought to Hu Guohua. Of course, the rat's money was stolen. The sage says not to drink water stolen from another, but that is the moral standard of the most virtuous and wise, which even the ancients found difficult to meet, let alone an ordinary man like Hu Guohua. It is said that if one smokes in a room over a long period, even the flies and rats within will become addicted; this is no empty claim.

chapters.name: Chapter 3: The Ominous Corpse of the Desolate Grave
chapters.content:
Since then, Hu Guohua had enlisted as a soldier and was greatly favored for his service. However, in that era of chaos, with warlords clashing and the land in turmoil, a mere hundred men could carve out a territory. Today you vanquish me, tomorrow another conquers you; few forces managed to endure. The warlord influence that Hu Guohua followed was minor to begin with, and within a year, it was shattered in the struggle for territory by another faction. The troops were either killed or scattered, and the warlord leader who had promoted Hu Guohua met his end in the fray, a bullet taking his life.

After the military defeat, Hu Guohua fled back to his hometown, only to find his family's dilapidated house had collapsed. Having left in haste, he carried no money and had not eaten for two days. His nicotine addiction flared up, and with no other options, he sold his pistol to bandits in exchange for some tobacco and food to address his immediate needs.

He pondered his situation, realizing this was no way to live. The meager supply of food and opium would last but three to five days at most. What was he to do once it was all consumed? It was then he recalled the words of the wraith attached to the paper effigy of a woman. She had told him, when he could no longer scrape by, to seek out a solitary grave without a tombstone in the Thirteen Li Shops' desolate cemetery, where her burial objects of gold and silver ornaments lay.

Now, Hu Guohua, having been a soldier and seen battle, had a courage far greater than before. He had heard many tales of tomb raiding from a veteran slicker in the army. Tomb raiding, also known as grave robbing among the common folk, could bring sudden wealth but cost one's head if caught. Thus, he dared not act in broad daylight. Steeling his heart, on a night with a faint moon, he lit a lantern and, carrying an iron shovel, made his way to the Thirteen Li Shop Cemetery.

For those curious, a 'furry moon' refers to a cloudless sky where the moonlight is dim and hazy. Modern folks know this as a 'halo' around the moon, a meteorological phenomenon signaling a change in weather, likely a coming windstorm. But in the rural areas of that time, who could comprehend such scientific explanations? The country folk called it a 'furry moon' and believed that on such nights, lonely spirits and night ghosts were most prone to wander.

Upon arrival, Hu Guohua fortified himself with half a jin of burning liquor to embolden his spirit. The night air was cold as ice, stars twinkling in the frigid sky while a mournful wind whistled through the graves. Phosphorescent fires drifted among the tomb mounds, and the occasional strange bird cried out, its eerie call piercing the silence. The flame in his hand flickered, threatening to extinguish at any moment.

Though he had just drunk, the ghostly atmosphere of the place sent shivers down his spine, and he broke out in a cold sweat, effectively wasting the fiery liquor that now seeped out through his pores.

Fortunately, this was a wild graveyard, ancient and unknown, with no human habitation nearby. He could shout as loud as he wished without fear of being heard. Hu Guohua sang a few mountain songs to bolster his courage, but knowing few lyrics, he quickly ran out of words and resorted to humming the familiar Tune of Longing at the Fifth Watch, a melody he knew by heart.

With trepidation, Hu Guohua made his way to the center of the graveyard, where indeed there stood a solitary grave without a tombstone, its uniqueness setting it apart in the desolate cemetery.

The grave, lacking a tombstone, held another peculiarity: the coffin was not buried beneath a mound of earth but stood upright, half-exposed on the grave mound. The coffin was new, its eighteen layers of vermillion lacquer gleaming. Under the waning moonlight, it cast a sinister glow.

 Hu Guohua harbored some misgivings in his heart, finding the placement of the coffin peculiarly unsettling—as if it harbored some secret significance. Yet, having come all this way, to leave without investigating would render the journey a fruitless endeavor. Starvation from lack of money to buy food was one form of death; dying from nicotine withdrawal due to an opium addiction was another. Either way, it seemed more agreeable to be strangled by a ghost than to endure such agonizing ends. Resigned to his lot in life, which had been nothing but a series of humiliations, he decided to throw caution to the wind and walk this dark path to its end.

With his mind made up, Hu Guohua hefted his iron shovel and began to dig away the earth sealing the lower half of the coffin. His strength, sapped by his opium addiction, faltered after shifting just a bit of soil, leaving him gasping for breath. He did not rush to open the coffin; instead, he sat on the ground and took a pinch of Fu Rong Ointment, snuffing it up his nose.

Stimulated by the opium, his nerves tingled with heightened alertness. Gritting his teeth, he stood up and pried open the coffin lid with his shovel. To his astonishment, the corpse inside was that of a beautiful woman, her features lifelike, though her face was heavily powdered. Her cheeks were daubed with rouge, standing out starkly against the white foundation like two patches of Red Ointment. Adorned with a phoenix crown and a cloud-patterned robe, she was dressed in the auspicious red silk of a bride.

This was certainly not the Woman with a Big Round Face he had seen two years prior. Moreover, the Paper Figure had instructed him to dig up the grave two years ago. Even if the corpse had been freshly buried at that time, it should have decomposed by now. Could she have become a zombie?

By this time, however, Hu Guohua could hardly concern himself with such thoughts. His eyes were fixed on the jewelry adorning the corpse, the gold and silver gems twinkling seductively in the lamplight, and the burial objects wrapped in red paper next to her—cylinders of silver dollars and numerous gold bars, too many to count.

He had stumbled upon a fortune. Eagerly, Hu Guohua reached for the emerald ring on the corpse's hand. But just as he extended his arm, the woman's corpse suddenly flipped her wrist and seized his, her grip unnaturally strong. Her steel-hook-like long fingernails, over an inch long, dug into the flesh of his wrist, rendering him unable to break free. Pain shot through Hu Guohua, a mix of agony and fear, leaving him clueless as to his next move.

The corpse opened her eyes, emitting a chilling, sinister light that struck Hu Guohua, freezing him to the core as if he had fallen into an ice cave, his breath visible in the cold air.

With a cold sneer, the corpse spoke, "You truly are blinded by greed. For money, there's no low you wouldn't stoop to. A heart and liver like yours are useless to you; I might as well take them for myself."

Upon hearing her intent for his heart, Hu Guohua panicked, protesting, "No, no, that cannot be!" But the corpse did not allow him to speak further. She tore open his clothes and with a slash of her long nails, a fresh, beating heart burst forth from Hu Guohua's chest. The corpse snatched it up and swallowed it whole, blood and all, without even a chew.

Hu Guohua was shocked beyond measure. Looking down, he saw a scar on his chest but felt no pain—only a growing haziness in his mind, an emptiness in his heart, unable to recall what had just transpired. He prostrated himself before the corpse, kowtowing repeatedly.

The corpse, perched atop the upright coffin, addressed Hu Guohua coldly, "You are now my puppet. I won't mistreat you. I will grant you wealth and honor. In return, you will lure sixty-four women to this graveyard for me to consume their hearts and livers. Should you make any mistake, your life will be the first I take."

 At that moment, Hu Guohua dared not disobey her command. The book spoke for itself: the female corpse was, in fact, a centuries-old Corpse Demon. To evade her destined calamity, she could not leave the Hiding Cemetery for the time being. She had cunningly lured avaricious grave robbers like Hu Guohua to desecrate the graves, then through threats and temptations, compelled him to capture innocent women to feed her a living heart. Once she consumed the hearts and livers of sixty-four women, she would become invincible, even to the gods descending from the heavens.

Hu Guohua scurried away from the Thirteen Li Shops burial ground, his pants soiled in fright. Upon returning, he first stole a pair of trousers from a neighbor's clothesline to change into. He was in a bind now; without even a wife of his own, where could he find a woman for this demon? He also sensed that something vitally important had been taken from him by the creature, but he couldn't recall what it was—only that it was extremely important. Without a woman to offer, his life was on the line. What was he to do?

His mind raced with frantic thoughts, but then, feeling the two hefty gold bars in the pocket of the foul trousers he had just removed—gifts from the Mistress Female Corpse—he furrowed his brow and hatched a despicable plan to save his own skin. The word 'conscience' felt strange to him, but he couldn't afford to think too much about it. Survival was paramount, even if it meant being unscrupulous.

The next morning, he exchanged the gold bars for Silver Dollars in the county town, indulged himself in an Opium Den, and then, with ten Silver Dollars, he bought a seventeen or eighteen-year-old girl from a poverty-stricken village. In the early years of the Republic of China, despite the official ban on human trafficking, the desperate poverty of the common people made the sale of sons and daughters a common occurrence, and the law was effectively a dead letter.

Having purchased the young girl, Hu Guohua assured her on the way that he had bought her to be his wife, that she need not worry, and that they would live well together. The girl, named Little Cui, was a shy country lass, her cheeks blushing without daring to look up at him, silently letting him lead the way. Hu Guohua led a small donkey, carrying Little Cui on its back, and under the cover of a moonless and windy night, they headed straight for the desolate graves of the Thirteen Li Shops.

The mountain path was rugged and difficult, and Hu Guohua, anxious not to miss the appointed time, hurried along the way. He encountered a Feng Shui Master named Mr. Sun, a renowned exorcist throughout the province with the innate ability to see yin and yang, who was adept at the Escape Technique of Five Elements.

Upon seeing Hu Guohua, Mr. Sun noticed a faint black aura enveloping him. After a quick calculation, he was taken aback and urgently stopped Hu Guohua, asking, "Sir, where are you hastening to in such a rush?"

Impatiently, Hu Guohua retorted, "I have urgent matters to attend to; don't block my path." Mr. Sun, raising his voice, demanded, "I have but one question for you, walking corpse: where is your heart and liver?"

At these words, Hu Guohua felt as if struck by a thunderbolt and immediately knelt, begging Mr. Sun to save his life.

Mr. Sun helped him up, "Though you lack virtue, you haven't committed unforgivable sins. It's not difficult for me to save you, but you must take me as your master and renounce your nicotine addiction."

 Hu Guohua listened as he was told to give up opium, a task he felt might as well claim his life. Yet, upon reflection, he concluded that life was more precious than the narcotic soil. "Where there's life, there's hope," he reasoned. "First, I'll plead with him to save me from the entanglement of that female corpse. Later, when he least expects it, I'll continue to indulge in my Fu Rong Ointment," he plotted with determination. On the mountain path, he kowtowed eight times to Mr. Sun, performing the ritual to acknowledge him as his master.

Mr. Sun then took charge of the arrangements, instructing Hu Guohua to follow the plan while he discreetly followed behind to protect him.

When the moon reached its zenith, Hu Guohua, accompanied by Little Cui, hurried to the desolate gravesite at Thirteen Li Shops. The female corpse had been waiting for some time, and upon their arrival, she scolded Hu Guohua before eagerly seizing Little Cui. She extended her sharp claws to extract the girl's heart and liver and swallowed them whole. Suddenly, the corpse let out a strange cry and tore Little Cui's body to shreds. At that moment, Little Cui revealed her true form; she was actually a paper effigy, a decoy created by Mr. Sun who had already secured the real Little Cui elsewhere.

The heart that the female corpse had consumed belonged to a black donkey's hoof hidden inside the paper effigy—a substance notorious for warding off evil, particularly effective against zombies and other tomb-raiding spirits. Tomb raiders in the Jiangnan region would carry two black donkey hooves on their person, a practice derived from the secret techniques of Maoshan. The reasons behind this would be explained another time; for now, they remain untold. After ingesting the black donkey's hoof, the demon head realized she had been tricked. Enraged, she attempted to tear Hu Guohua to pieces, but he had already kept his distance. She howled to the sky as her clothes disintegrated into ash, her body turning into a pool of blood. Before long, all that remained was a stark white skeleton on the ground.

Mr. Sun, watching from afar, rushed over and extracted a chicken egg-sized Crimson Elixir Pill from the skeleton, instructing Hu Guohua to swallow it. Hu Guohua's heart and liver were thus restored to their rightful place.

Together, they gathered the bones and placed them into the Big Red Coffin. As they were about to seal the coffin, the skull suddenly leapt up, opening its jaws to spew a cloud of black mist at Mr. Sun. Caught off guard, Mr. Sun was enveloped by the chilling corpse qi, feeling a surge of discomfort in his chest. Nevertheless, his extensive experience in perilous situations kept him from panicking. He quickly shut the coffin lid, secured it firmly with long nails, and then drew intersecting ink lines across the coffin with an Ink Compass. The lines formed a grid-like Black Big Net, sealing the coffin tightly and securely.

 Mr. Sun had been severely injured by the malevolent energy of a zombie, and after the flurry of activity, he found himself unable to move, sitting helplessly on the ground. He instructed Hu Guohua to gather some dry wood and set the large vermilion lacquered coffin ablaze. Hu Guohua did as told, lighting a fire that consumed the coffin with voracious flames, sending plumes of black smoke into the air, a stench unbearable. Eventually, all that remained were ashes.

It was only then that Hu Guohua remembered the gold that had been inside the coffin. He stamped his feet in regret, but it was too late. He had no choice but to support his master, Mr. Sun, and with Little Cui in tow, they went to live in Mr. Sun's household.

Mr. Sun later cured Hu Guohua of his nicotine addiction using a secret remedy and taught him some basic skills in Feng Shui and fortune-telling. Hu Guohua set up a small stall in the county town, reading fortunes and faces for passersby to earn a modest income. He married Little Cui, grateful for his master's life-saving grace, and settled into a contented life that gradually improved day by day.

However, Mr. Sun never fully recovered from the chilling corpse poison that had penetrated his bones after being sprayed with corpse qi. A few years later, he passed away.

On his deathbed, Mr. Sun summoned Hu Guohua and said, "We have shared a bond as master and disciple, but I regret not having the chance to teach you my true skills. Here is an ancient text, the 'Sixteen-Character Yin-Yang Feng Shui Secret Technique.' It's an incomplete volume, only half of the original, with minor techniques for Feng Shui and tomb seeking. Keep it as a memento." With those final words, Mr. Sun breathed his last.

Hu Guohua buried his master and, in his spare time, studied the fragmented text left to him. Over time, he gleaned subtle insights and began to gain a reputation in the county for selecting auspicious burial sites for the wealthy, which slowly brought prosperity to his household.

Little Cui bore Hu Guohua a son, whom they named Hu Yunxuan. At seventeen, Hu Yunxuan went to study at the British Church School in the provincial capital. The young man, lively and unrestrained, was also influenced by revolutionary ideas, his blood boiling with fervor. He dreamt nightly of joining revolutionary uprisings and eventually left home to join the revolution in Yan'an, the sacred land of the movement.

Hu Yunxuan joined the military and by the time of the founding of the new nation, during the Huai River Campaign, he had risen to the rank of a certain regiment commander in the Three Wild Six Vertical formation. After the Crossing the River Campaign, he moved south with his unit and settled in the south.

Later on, I was born, coincidentally on August 1st Army Day, and my father named me Hu Jianjun. However, when I started kindergarten, there were seven or eight other children with the same name, so to avoid confusion, my name was changed to Hu Bayi.

 My grandfather, Hu Guohua, once remarked, "This name has been well-chosen, simple and yet encompassing everything."

When I turned eighteen, my family faced turmoil. It began with the downfall of the leaders among the Three Wilderness Officers, and gradually others were implicated. My parents, due to their less favorable backgrounds, were both isolated for investigation. My grandfather was dragged out for a public denouncement parade as an 'Evil Being.' Being advanced in years, his frail limbs couldn't endure the harsh treatment, and he passed away after only a couple of struggles. He spent his life consulting on Feng Shui and selecting burial sites for others, yet in the end, he himself was cremated—a testament to life's unpredictability.

Our home was raided three times, with all valuables confiscated. My grandfather had a penchant for collecting antiques; these were either smashed or seized, not a single one was spared. The sole survivor was a damaged book he left behind, which I managed to preserve by wrapping it in oilcloth and hiding it above the public toilet's ceiling.

Upon graduation during the Cultural Revolution, young people had three choices: enlist in the military, which was the most favorable option as it not only tempered one's character but also promised job placement upon reassignment. The second option was to stay in the city and work as a laborer, which was also decent due to the wages earned. The most unfortunate were those without connections or those whose families had been affected by the political turmoil; these youths had no choice but to 'go up to the mountains and down to the countryside' to join the rural workforce.

You might wonder if I considered a fourth option—to simply stay at home. But that wasn't feasible, as there was no such thing as an 'idle person' back then. Everyone was a 'Socialist Screw,' serving a purpose. If you stayed at home, the Neighborhood Committee and the Educated Youth Office would hound you daily to mobilize. However, some persisted and ultimately avoided the countryside labor, managing to stay in the city and eventually being allocated work. Such is the nature of things in China—ambiguous and perplexing, with rules that are never clear and unwritten norms not everyone comprehends.

I was too young at the time to fully understand what 'going up to the mountains and down to the countryside' entailed. With my family background, joining the military was out of the question, and no one would arrange a city job for me. With nowhere else to go, I figured I might as well embrace the countryside labor. I thought of it as an opportunity to cultivate a 'Red Heart' in the vast world, reasoning that if I was to leave home, I might as well go as far as possible.

Most people from our area chose to go to Yunnan or Xinjiang, but I opted for Inner Mongolia. A buddy of mine, Wang Kaixuan, who was paler and plumper than most, earning him the nickname 'Fatty,' decided to join me. We were assigned to a place called Ganggang Camp, a name I had never even heard before until the moment they told me that was my destination. It was then I realized such a place existed in the world.

Leaving home by train, no one came to see us off. In stark contrast to the warm farewells given to those joining the military, our departure as Educated Youths was a scene of desolation and solemnity. I took with me only the Sixteen-Character Yin-Yang Feng Shui Secret Technique, the book I had hidden in the public toilet's ceiling. I didn't know the content of the book, but it was the only thing left from my family. I wanted to keep it close, so I could look at it whenever homesickness struck.

chapters.name: Chapter 4: The Ancient Tomb in the Mountains
chapters.content:
Though it's called Inner Mongolia, it's actually not far from Heilongjiang, nearly reaching the border of Outer Mongolia. The residents are predominantly Han, with only a minority of Manchu and Mongolian ethnicities. If you've never been to Ganggang Camp, you could never imagine how tough it is out there. Our group of Educated Youth totaled six people, four men and two women. Upon arrival, we were stunned: all around us were rolling mountains and endless primitive forests. Once you left the village, you could walk a hundred miles without seeing a soul.

There were no roads, let alone electricity. Even having an oil lamp was considered a privilege reserved for cadres, and using a flashlight was like staying in a Presidential Suite by today's standards. In the city, one could never fathom this; we had thought the entire nation was filled with buildings, bright lights, and telephones.

Yet, there was a sense of novelty at that time. I had never seen such large mountains, and many of the local mountain delicacies were new to my palate. The nearby mountains were rich in resources, and the rivers were teeming with fish, so we never worried about going hungry. Later, when we returned to the city, we heard from those who had been sent to work in Shaanxi how truly hard their lives were; for years they hadn't seen a single decent grain of food.

The work for Educated Youth wasn't too burdensome since the area relied on the mountains for sustenance, and there wasn't much in the way of crops. On summer evenings, we took turns guarding the crops in the fields for fear of wild animals nibbling them away, which meant spending nights out in the fields.

The crops in the mountains weren't like the vast expanse of green seen on the North China Plain, but rather patchworks here and there—wherever the land was flat, a field was made. So, one had to regularly patrol at night. That night, it was my turn to pair up with Fatty. Fatty slept in the thatched hut while I went out for a round. Seeing nothing amiss, I decided to head back to sleep.

Approaching the hut, I saw a large, round, white shadow not far from it. I rubbed my eyes and looked again. It wasn't a figment of my imagination, but it was too dark to make out exactly what it was. I didn't believe in ghosts and thought it might be an animal, so I picked up a stick, hoping to drive it away.

A white, shimmering object in the pitch dark, swaying slightly—this surely didn't look like any animal, but if it wasn't an animal, why would it move? The darkness was too thick, and without a kerosene lamp, I couldn't discern its nature.

Although I wasn't afraid of ghosts and goblins, the fear of the unknown still lurked within me. I didn't dare to swing the stick wildly. The stick in my hand was just a rough branch I had picked up from the ground. I gently prodded the white mass with the branch; it was soft. Suddenly, out of the darkness, I heard Fatty yelling, "Hu Bayi, why the hell are you poking me with a stick?"

It was a false alarm. It turned out Fatty had eaten some unclean fruit during the day, and his stomach was upset. He squatted there to relieve himself, and in the darkness, his white backside was all too conspicuous.

 The following morning, Fatty was relentless in demanding compensation from me, claiming that the previous night's scare had killed off over a million of his brain cells. I retorted, "With a brain like yours, do you really think you had that many to begin with? We're both destitute bachelors here, having heeded the highest directive to come to the countryside for the much-needed re-education amongst the lower-middle peasants. What exactly do you expect me to compensate you with? Let me make it clear, as your close comrade-in-arms, all I have left to my name is these trousers I'm wearing—and they're my last pair. You surely don't expect me to give you these as compensation?"

Fatty, with a mischievous grin, said that wouldn't be necessary. "Yesterday, at Tuan Mountain, in that old forest, I came across a massive beehive. If you help me poke it, we can get some honey to mix with water for a drink. We could even barter the honey for rabbit meat with Yanzi's father."

Yanzi was a girl's name; her father was a well-known old hunter in the village. Fatty and I were staying at the Educated Youth Point in her home. The father-daughter duo often went hunting in the mountains, occasionally inviting us to savor some game. We always felt a little guilty for partaking in their generosity without being able to reciprocate, but we were too poor to offer anything in return.

Discovering a large beehive, we decided to gather some honey as a gift for Yanzi. Both of us, known for our impulsive nature, were infamous in the city as mischievous troublemakers of the entire Military Region. Poking a beehive was child's play for us; we'd done far more daring deeds.

Wary of losing our way, I borrowed Yanzi's hunting dog, a young pup she had raised herself but never had the heart to take hunting. She had named him Chestnut Yellow. Seeing that we were headed to Tuan Mountain for fun, she lent us the dog.

Tuan Mountain wasn't too far from our village as the crow flies, but with no paths to follow, it took us half a day of trekking over hills and dales to get there. The forest was vast, and villagers had warned us against entering, cautioning that human bears roamed within. We had seen a man in the village with only half a face; as a child, he had encountered a human bear right here. Luckily, Yanzi's father arrived just in time, firing a shot to scare off the creature and saving the boy. However, the bear had already licked his face with its tongue full of backward-facing barbs, tearing away a large patch of flesh. Now in his forties, without an eye, ear, nose, or a straight mouth on the left side of his face, he remained unmarried. The elders would tear up when they spoke of his plight.

Though we were bold, we dared not venture into the primeval forest. The beehive Fatty mentioned was one he'd spotted while gathering pine seeds with the villagers at the forest's edge, hanging on a large tree by a stream.

Unexpectedly, the hive was enormous, larger than any we had ever poked, all combined. From a distance, it resembled a limbless calf hanging from the tree, with a dark swarm of giant bees buzzing in and out, their droning deafening to the ears.

 "Little Fatty, you're setting me up, aren't you? Is this a hornet's nest or a giant Wasp Atomic Bomb? If this thing blows, we're done for," I said. Fatty replied confidently, "If it were just an ordinary nest, would I have bothered you? I'd have taken care of it myself. So, what do you say? Still up for the challenge?"

"What are we even worried about? Our team is invincible; we don't even fear the American Imperialism's Airplane Tanks, let alone a few tiny bees. They're all paper tigers. Damn it, we're going to feast on honey today."

Despite the bravado, we couldn't just rush in recklessly. A single misstep could result in a swarm of wasps stinging us to death. The sheer size of these bees suggested they were venomous. Just one or two stings could be lethal. Fortunately, there was a small river nearby – a stroke of divine luck. I took out a piece of bread, broke it in two, and fed Chestnut Yellow, making sure it stayed well away. Then we donned our Military Greatcoats, pulled on fur hats, wound Scarves around our necks, slipped on gloves, and covered our faces with transparent scarves borrowed from female Educated Youths. After ensuring not a sliver of skin was exposed, Fatty found a couple of hollow reeds for us to breathe through when we would have to take refuge in the river from the swarming hornets.

Once we were ready, we lumbered to the tree like two cumbersome bears, swaying with every step. I held a bundle of Winter Seed Grass and matches at the ready, while Fatty gripped a long pole and counted, "Three." On three, he jabbed the pole at the point where the massive nest was attached to the tree trunk. After four or five stabs, the huge nest fell to the ground with a thud. Countless Giant Hornets immediately buzzed out, forming a dark cloud overhead with a menacing hum.

I was well-prepared. Ignoring the attacking swarm, I struck a match and lit the Winter Seed Grass, placing it downwind of the nest. The smoke disoriented the emerging hornets, causing them to fly about erratically. Fatty and I quickly built a protective Fire Wall with mud around the burning grass to prevent a Mountain Wildfire.

By then, the hornets that had escaped the smoke had identified their targets and were converging on us. It felt like hailstones were pummeling my head as they struck. Without hesitation, Fatty and I dashed for the nearby stream. The water was shallow, less than a meter deep, but it was enough. We plunged in, the current sweeping away the hornets clinging to us. Clutching my fur hat to keep it from being swept away, I used one of the reeds to breathe.

It was a long while before we surfaced. By then, the hornets were either drowned or knocked out by the smoke; the danger had passed. Although it was midsummer, the mountain stream was icy cold. I shivered uncontrollably as I finally crawled onto the bank, lying on a rock and gasping for air. The warmth of the sun on my head was indescribably comforting after the ordeal.

 Before long, Fatty could no longer hold out and staggered onto the bank. Just as he was halfway up, he suddenly yelped, jerking his arm up to reveal a large gash from which blood was streaming.

I hurried back down into the creek to help him. Clutching his wound, Fatty said, “Be careful, there seems to be a broken bowl in the river that got me.”

There were no inhabitants nearby, so the presence of a broken bowl piqued my curiosity. Stripping down to my skin, I dove into the creek bare-chested and felt around the area where Fatty was injured. I found half a broken porcelain bowl, its style and bluish-green patterns reminiscent of the Northern Song dynasty blue-and-white porcelain once collected by my grandfather.

My grandfather's antiques and paintings were all destroyed by the Red Guards during the Cultural Revolution's campaign to obliterate the "Four Olds." To come across such a relic in this deep mountain, old forest stirred a sense of familiarity within me. Yet, such an object held little use for me, and with a flick of my wrist, I tossed the broken half-bowl far into the woods.

Fatty also stripped off his drenched clothes and wrapped up his wound in a makeshift bandage before jumping back into the creek. We bathed ourselves, then laid our clothes and socks out to dry on the creek-side pebbles. I gave a whistle call to summon Chestnut Yellow back.

Chestnut Yellow came running back from a distance, a plump gray hare clenched in its jaws. I couldn't fathom how this unlucky creature had ended up caught by Chestnut Yellow, a hunting dog still in training. Overjoyed at the sight of the hare, I rolled around on the ground with Chestnut Yellow, praising the good dog, and rewarded it with a large chunk of honeycomb dripping with honey.

Fatty suggested, "When we get back, we should get a few puppies to raise. Then we can have rabbit meat every day."

I replied, "You're dreaming too sweetly. The mountains can't sustain your voracious appetite. Enough talk; I'm actually quite hungry. Hurry and clean the rabbit, I'll gather wood for a fire."

Fatty cleaned the rabbit by the creek while I gathered a bundle of dry pine branches and started a campfire. I coated the skinned hare with a thick layer of honey and set it to roast over the flames. Before long, the sweet aroma of honey-roasted rabbit filled the air. I cut off the rabbit head to feed the dog, and Fatty and I heartily devoured the rest, splitting it between us. I had never tasted anything so delicious in my life, almost swallowing my own fingers in the process. Though unseasoned with oil or salt, the wild honey and pine branches lent the rabbit a unique natural flavor, a delicacy unimaginable in city life. The life of an 'Educated Youth' was a mix of hardship and joy; society had pushed us to these remote mountains, and though we had lost some things, we had also gained what could never be found in the city. It seems that in life, some things cannot be measured simply by what is gained or lost.

 After a hearty meal and noticing the day was getting late, we saw that our clothes were almost dry. We threaded a large honeycomb with a thick branch and carried it between us, singing revolutionary songs as we returned to the village: "The sky is vast, the earth is vast, but nothing compares to the resolve in our hearts; father's love, mother's love, none as close as comrade's affection." It was just like the triumphant return from battle, with drums beating and people singing in victory. The only discordant note was the excited barking of Chestnut Yellow, which somehow reminded me of the atmosphere in movies when the Ghosts enter a village.

Back in the village, I noticed that many people were absent, so I asked Swallow, "Where have your father and the others gone?"

As Swallow helped us carry the beehive, she answered, "The Chaganha River has flooded, and the timber at the Forest Farm has been soaked. Most of the villagers went there to help move the wood at noon. The Branch Secretary asked me to tell you to take good care of the crops and not to cause any trouble. They won't be back for about seven or eight days."

I never liked it when people told me not to cause trouble, as if I was born a troublemaker. So I said to Swallow, "The Branch Secretary must have gotten confused by the liquor. What trouble could we possibly cause? We are all good kids here."

Swallow laughed and said, "You don't cause trouble? Ever since you city Educated Youths arrived, the village hens have been so disturbed they've stopped laying eggs."

The other two male Educated Youths had also gone to the Forest Farm, leaving just me, Fatty, and two other female Educated Youths. We felt lucky not to have been assigned to work at the Forest Farm because we had gone out to play. We poured the honey into jars, filling more than ten large earthenware pots. Swallow mentioned that the leftover honeycombs could also be cooked and eaten, promising to make us stir-fried roe deer meat with honeycomb that evening.

As soon as we mentioned eating, Fatty's eyes lit up. He said, "Our life today is almost as good as during New Year's. We had roasted rabbit meat this afternoon, and tonight we'll have stir-fried roe deer meat with honeycomb. I'm already drooling." Swallow asked us where we had roasted the rabbit. After telling her the story, she exclaimed, "Oh no, you shouldn't be reckless! Roasting a wild rabbit near the Old Forest could attract a man-eating bear. What would we do then?"

We hadn't thought about the danger until she mentioned it, feeling lucky that the bear must have been asleep today and hadn't smelled the roasted meat. As I helped Swallow start the fire, I told her about Fatty cutting his hand on a broken bowl in the stream, wondering how a bowl from the Song Dynasty could end up in such a wild place.

Swallow said it wasn't surprising at all. "In our village, when a girl gets married, every family has a few jars and pots as part of the dowry, all fished out from the river."

The more I heard, the more curious I became. "You can fish antiques out of the river?" Swallow pulled out two porcelain vases from under the bed to show me. "They don't grow in the river; they've been washed down from upstream. The sources of several rivers near our village are in the Lama Gully at Ox Heart Mountain. The elders say that the mountain is the site of an empress dowager's tomb from the Liao and Jin Dynasties, filled with buried treasures. Many people have wanted to find that tomb, but those who haven't found it either never return from Lama Gully or get lost in its dense forest. My father once saw wild men lurking in the gully, and some say Ox Heart Mountain is haunted. In any case, no one has dared to go there in recent years."

 As we spoke, night had already fallen. Yanzi had finished preparing the meal, and Fatty went to call the other two female Educated Youths to eat. However, no sooner had he left than he came running back, gasping for breath, with one of them, Wang Juan. I hastily inquired what had happened.

Wang Juan took a moment to catch her breath before explaining. It turned out that the other female Educated Youth, Tian Xiaomeng, had received a letter from home informing her that her mother was hospitalized with a severe case of asthma. Having heard that the Bodhisattva Fruit, which grew in Lama Gully, had miraculous effects on asthma, Tian Xiaomeng set out alone to gather it. She had left in the morning and now, with darkness upon us, she had not returned.

A vein throbbed fiercely on my forehead. Tian Xiaomeng had been too reckless; that place was all virgin forest, where even the most experienced hunters from the village dared not venture lightly. How could she have gone there alone?

Wang Juan cried, "I couldn't stop her. We must hurry to find her. What if something terrible has happened?"

But at the moment, all the village's labor force had gone to the Forest Farm, leaving only the elderly and the young behind. If we were to seek help, only Fatty and I could go. Yanzi also decided to bring along Chestnut Yellow, the dog, and a hunting rifle. We left Wang Juan behind to watch over the crops in the village.

With a dog in the mountains, one need not fear getting lost. Without delay, we lit our torches, took Chestnut Yellow, and ventured into the mountains at night. The Deep Mountain Old Forest had no paths to follow, and I couldn't fathom how Tian Xiaomeng, a girl on her own, had dared to penetrate the deepest parts of the great mountain. Fatty suggested she might have been confused in her panic—who wouldn't be anxious with their own mother ill?

Because it was dark and we needed the dog to track the scent, and since Chestnut Yellow hadn't been professionally trained, we often lost the trail and had to backtrack to find it again. So we moved slowly. A journey that would usually take four or five hours took us the entire night. Dawn broke in the east, and the morning wind in the great forest raised goosebumps on our skin. The crisp air invigorated us. Yanzi pointed to the west: "Look, that big mountain over there is Ox Heart Mountain."

 Fatty and I looked westward, where the vast forest sea cloaked the rolling hills. Amidst them towered an oddly shaped colossal peak, resembling the heart of an ox. Nine white jade-like waterfalls cascaded down the mountain, their rushing torrents reminiscent of dragons. The porcelain pieces picked up by the villagers had been washed out from these waterfalls, suggesting that the tomb of the Empress Dowager of the Liao dynasty, spoken of in legends, might indeed lie within the mountain. Yet, for all these years, no one had managed to find its entrance.

The sight of this magnificent peak suddenly triggered a sense of déjà vu within me. I felt certain I had seen such a mountain before. With a flicker of thought, I recalled a passage from the tattered book left behind by my grandfather that I would peruse in my idle moments. This landscape was a prime example of Fengshui Treasure, with clear prospects in front and reliable support behind. The nine waterfalls divided the hill like a blooming lotus, indeed, it was referred to as Nine Dragons Guarding the Jade Lotus.

The mountain's nine waterfalls, neither more nor less, and the sheer volume of the flowing water, were essential to the pattern of Nine Dragons Guarding the Jade Lotus. Nine, the largest single-digit number, carries connotations of supremacy and eternity, as it sounds like the word for 'long-lasting' in Chinese. It has always been regarded as the most auspicious number. Moreover, if the waterfalls had a lesser flow, they would not represent dragons, but rather snakes.

This kind of Fengshui Treasure also bore another name, Luo Goddess's Chariot. According to the book, it was most fitting to bury females in such a place, for if a male were interred there, his family would befall great misfortune.

At that moment, a vague feeling washed over me. My grandfather's Sixteen-Character Yin-Yang Feng Shui Secret Technique was not mere superstitious nonsense; the contents of the book held genuine substance. I resolved to give it a thorough read upon my return.

However, I didn't believe that this Feng Shui practice had any practical value. Throughout China's ancient history, with its myriad emperors and generals, none were buried just anywhere. The rise and fall of dynasties, the great currents of history, surely could not be swayed by the auspiciousness of an ancestral grave.

Yanzi pointed towards the valley in front of Ox Heart Mountain and said, "This is the renowned Lama Gully. Legend has it that Wild Men dwell within, and at night, it's Haunted."

Fatty glanced at the dense primeval forest that darkened the valley and frowned, "If Tian Xiaomeng entered Lama Gully, she'd definitely get lost. With just the three of us and a dog, finding her is going to be quite the challenge."

Seeing their spirits dampen, I rallied them with encouragement, "Communist materialists should not believe in the existence of Ghosts. Whether it's Ghosts or Wild Men, if I encounter them, they'll be the unlucky ones. I'll catch a few alive and bring them back to Beijing as a gift. I'm sure the sight will astonish everyone."

 Fatty and I, both soldiers by family background, had a natural-born fearlessness coursing through our veins. His spirits lifted upon hearing my words, and he readied himself to enter the gully with zeal.

Only Yanzi was fraught with worry. As a local, she had grown up on countless terrifying tales of Lama Gully, which instilled in her an inherent fear. But with lives at stake, she had no choice but to cast these fears aside.

Before setting out, the three of us sat down for some dry food and checked our equipment. We had two hunting rifles between us, both belonging to Yanzi and her father for hunting. One was a triple-barreled shotgun, the other a lever-action rifle commonly used by the Oroqen people. Both were outdated, muzzle-loading firearms. They packed a punch at close range but beyond thirty-five meters, their power and precision faltered, suitable only for small game like hares and roe deer.

I had been shooting at ranges with my father since I was six, familiar with the standard-issue weapons of the People's Liberation Army, but I had no confidence in handling these antiquated flintlock hunting rifles. Fatty's experience was similar to mine, so after a brief discussion, Yanzi and I each took a rifle, and Fatty armed himself with a wood-chopping machete. Thus prepared, we plunged into the dense woods of Lama Gully.

In Lama Gully, more immediate and real than the legendary Wild Man or mountain ghosts, was the threat of the Human Bear. Though a bear like any other, the Human Bear was so named for its bipedal gait. Massive and tough, hunters dared to confront it only in groups, accompanied by packs of hunting dogs. A lone individual with a decrepit gun facing a Human Bear in the primeval forest was tantamount to a death sentence.

We trekked through the forest for the better part of the day, the thundering sound of the nine great waterfalls of Ox Heart Mountain growing ever louder, signaling the end of Lama Gully and the approach to the base of the mountain.

Without any encounters with Human Bears or Wild Men, nor any sign of Tian Xiaomeng, Fatty collapsed on the ground, exhausted: "I can't go on."

"Let's rest for a bit then," suggested Yanzi. "Lizi Huang seems to have lost Tian Xiaomeng's scent too. What do we do if we can't find her? The Branch Secretary and my father will have my hide when they return."

 Exhausted, I grabbed the water bottle and took several hearty gulps before saying to the two of them, "Tian Xiaomeng might have been eaten by a Human Bear, or perhaps even taken by a Wild Man to become his bandit bride."

As we rested and chatted idly, suddenly we heard Chestnut Yellow barking furiously towards the depths of the dense forest. Hunting dogs of such fine pedigree would never bark so wildly unless they were in extreme danger.

I asked Swallow, "What's gotten into the dogs? Is there some wild animal out there?"

Swallow's face turned ashen. "Climb a tree, quickly—it's a Human Bear."

At the mention of the Human Bear, I scrambled up a large tree in haste. Looking down, I saw Swallow straining to lift Fatty, who was not adept at climbing and was laboriously hugging the trunk, inching upwards. I swiftly slid back down and, together with Swallow, we helped Fatty up to the lowest large branch, where he lay panting heavily, complaining, "The tree is too tall."

Chestnut Yellow's barks grew more frantic, and before Swallow and I could climb back up, a black-furred Human Bear burst through the shrubbery. Spotting a living person, it reared up on its hind legs, roaring thunderously.

Swallow, who had spent years hunting in the mountains with her father and was immensely experienced, didn't have time to think. She raised her hunting rifle and fired at the Human Bear. With a spark and a bang, the bullet struck the bear's belly.

Due to the close range and the softness of the bear's abdomen, the shot tore a large hole, from which blood and entrails poured forth. Wounded and enraged, the Human Bear stuffed its intestines back inside with its massive paws, then charged at Swallow in a fury. Swallow's rifle couldn't fire in rapid succession, and with trees and thorns blocking her retreat, she had no choice but to close her eyes and await death.

Saving her was imperative. Without a second thought, I aimed my gun at the Human Bear's head. If I missed, Swallow would be done for. My hand trembled at the thought, but I gritted my teeth and pulled the trigger. The shotgun's tremendous recoil nearly knocked me to the ground, and whether it was due to the firearm's insufficient lethality or my off-aim, the shot, though hitting the Human Bear's head, only blinded one of its eyes.

While not fatal, the shot saved Swallow. The Human Bear, now blind in one eye and with blood covering its face, half an eyeball still dangling from the socket, became even more frenzied. It abandoned Swallow and lunged straight at me.

At that moment, Chestnut Yellow fiercely bit the Human Bear's hind leg. As the bear turned to grab Chestnut Yellow, the dog, ever so alert, dashed away and provocatively bared its teeth at the Human Bear from a distance.

This brief respite allowed Swallow and me to seize those precious seconds to each climb a large tree, narrowly escaping the clutches of death.

 The Human Bear was grievously wounded, its innards punctured and spilling out, one eye blinded. In the mountains, even tigers gave it a wide berth, but it had never suffered such a loss before. It wanted to snatch up Little Chestnut Yellow, but it couldn't run as fast as the hunting dogs, and when it sought to sink its teeth into the three men, they had all scrambled up into the trees. Circling the base in frustration, it seethed with a bellyful of malevolent fire, yet for the moment, it was at a loss for what to do. Raging like a thunderstorm, it roared up at the sky, its howls reverberating through the valley.

Perched atop a tree, I watched the Human Bear pacing in circles below, its predicament amusing to me as I forgot my own precarious situation. I called out to Fatty, who was on another tree, "Hey, Fatty, why isn't your dear uncle leaving? What's he doing circling around down there? Advise him not to be so rash."

Fatty, more scared of heights than the Human Bear, clung to the fork of the tree, trembling with fear. But upon hearing my taunt, he wouldn't let it slide and retorted, "Hu Bayi, aren't you the heartless one? That's not my uncle down there. Look closely before you speak—that's your wife, isn't it?"

I burst into laughter and pointed at the Human Bear below, teasing Fatty, "My mistake, that's actually your dear aunt. I'm certainly not going to be your uncle-in-law."

Frustrated and furious, Fatty wanted to hurl pine cones at me, but both his hands were tightly gripping the branch, afraid that letting go would send him plummeting down. He dared not make any sudden movements and could only glare at me helplessly.

Seeing Fatty's state only made me laugh harder, but my mirth froze instantly when I saw the Human Bear, heedless of anything else, beginning to climb the very tree I was in.

Clumsy though it was, the bear's strength was tremendous, and its grievous wounds had driven it completely mad. Now, it saw only us three men and one dog. With a bloodshot eye, it dug its massive claws into the tree bark, and its colossal frame ascended over a meter with each lunge. I cursed inwardly, "Who the hell told me bears can't climb trees? This is a deathtrap!"

In the mountains, there's an old hunter's adage for the younger ones: "Rather face a fierce tiger than a mad bear." The completely crazed Human Bear, with its terrifying destructive and explosive power, filled me with dread, leaving no room for jests with Fatty. All I could think of was how to escape this predicament.

That's when Yanzi reminded me, "Load it with iron sand, aim for its other eye."

Only then did I remember the hunting shotgun strapped to my back. Cursing my own uselessness, I climbed higher towards the treetop and untied the Armed Belt that was fastening my trousers. I secured the Armed Belt onto a sturdy branch that could bear my weight, held onto the shotgun with one hand to maintain my balance, and with the other hand, I began loading the gun with gunpowder. I poured nearly half a horn's worth of powder into the muzzle.

The Human Bear was ascending swiftly, drawing ever closer to me. Yanzi and Fatty were both sweating bullets on my behalf. I focused all my attention on the task of loading the shotgun, deliberately ignoring the Human Bear climbing up towards me.

 After packing the gunpowder, I pressed in the iron sand, ramming both tightly with a metal rod. Sweat drenched the hollows of my nose and the temples of my forehead. Such a hunting rifle was truly a nuisance, a damned gun that could claim a life. In the vast forests of the Northeast, how many hunters had lost their precious lives for want of a faster gun? If only I had a Type 56 Semi-automatic Rifle at this moment, even if two or three Human Bears came at me, it would be no matter. Under these circumstances, even a mere pistol would have been better.

Just as I finished loading the iron sand and gunpowder, and had replaced the tinder and flint, the Human Bear's paw reached my foot. I quickly withdrew it, flipping the rifle's muzzle downward in a swift motion to aim right at the Human Bear's head and fired. The shot, overloaded with powder, sent up a cloud of smoke, blackening my face with soot.

The musket worked by propelling the iron sand with the force of the gunpowder, but the low angle had loosened the sand in the barrel, diminishing its intended power. Moreover, shooting one-handed and at close range without any support, the shot went awry, missing its head and merely mangled the Human Bear's shoulder. The beast fell from the tree, a dozen meters up, and crashed heavily to the ground, which was thick with deep layers of dead branches and leaves. Its thick skin and flesh meant the fall from such a height did little harm.

The Human Bear got up. This time, it didn't climb but charged like a heavy tank, bellowing strangely and slamming its hefty body against the trees, causing pine needles and cones to rain down like droplets.

Thankfully, I was secured to the tree with an armed belt, preventing me from being shaken off. I worried that the tree might not be sturdy enough to withstand the Human Bear's onslaught and could snap at the base. It seemed I was destined to die today in the Deep Mountain Old Forest. Facing death, I couldn't lose face. I had to show some revolutionary spirit, let Fatty and Yanzi see that Old Hu was no coward. So I bellowed to my two comrades: "Looks like I'm about to meet Marx. Sorry, comrades, I'm going ahead to save seats for you. Do you have any messages for the revolutionary mentor? I'll be sure to pass them on."

Fatty, perched on another large tree some distance away, yelled back: "Old Hutong Spirit, go in peace. The Revolutionary Cause will not be affected by your absence. When you meet old Marx, study the revolutionary theories well. I hear they always eat potatoes stewed with beef over there; will that suit your palate?"

I replied: "When have we revolutionaries ever been picky eaters, Comrade Fatty? Keep pushing the revolutionary cart forward without faltering. The red flag shall overturn the serf's halberd, the tyrant's whip held high. The remaining two-thirds of the suffering masses in the world rely on you for liberation. As for me, I'm off to eat potatoes and stewed beef every day."

 Swallow, in a fit of panic, burst into tears. "What are we doing wasting time with idle talk? Think of something, quick!"

Just when we were at our wits' end, Human Bear stopped ramming its body into the tree and took a breather, sitting on the ground and panting heavily. It turned out that Human Bear had lost a lot of blood and, after all its thrashing about, even a creature of its brute strength had its limits. Now, it had calmed down from its fury, learned its lesson, and decided to wait us out, resting under the tree as we faced off.

Chestnut Yellow had also witnessed the ferocity of Human Bear and dared not approach it for another bite, squatting at a distance instead. The dog was hungry, but out of loyalty to its master, it refused to scavenge for food. Swallow, feeling sorry for her dog, whistled for Chestnut Yellow to go find something to eat, and only then did it leave.

The three of us lay on the tree, deliberating our next move, but after much thought, we found no viable solution. Descending the tree for a direct confrontation, armed only with our old-fashioned muskets, would be tantamount to seeking our own deaths. With most of the villagers absent, we couldn't hope for rescue. To prevent falling from the tree, we each fastened ourselves firmly to the trunk with our belts, resolved to see who would outlast the other.

This stalemate was most disadvantageous for the three of us perched in the tree. The recent harrowing struggle with Human Bear had drained much of our strength. Evening was fast approaching, and we had been without sleep for two days and a night, having eaten only a few cornmeal pancakes during the day. We were both hungry and sleepy, fearing that by morning we might faint from hunger and fall from the tree.

The situation reminded me of a line from Chairman Mao's poetry: "Surrounded by countless enemy troops, I stand firm and unmoved." But unlike the poem, there were no banners fluttering below, only Human Bear on guard.

Lost in these scattered thoughts, I unknowingly dozed off against the trunk, and after who knows how long, I awoke to an unbearable hunger gnawing at my stomach. I opened my eyes to a sky dense with stars and a crescent moon hanging like a hook, signaling the deep of night. The forest was silent, and by the moonlight, I saw that Human Bear was no longer below. When it had left, I couldn't say. The branches were thick, obscuring my view of whether Swallow and Fatty were still on the tree. I called out loudly, "Swallow, Fatty, are you still up there?"

After several shouts, my voice echoed through the midnight valley, but there was no response from the two. Though I was usually brave, the thought of being alone in the primeval forest sent a chill down my spine. It seemed inconsiderate of them to have left without waking me.

I called out twice more from the tree, but still, there was no reply. Anxiety set in as I scanned the surroundings and noticed a flickering light not far ahead. It was surprising to find signs of habitation in such a place. Perhaps they had seen the light and gone to seek help?

In the darkness, I couldn't discern the cardinal directions, but the sound of flowing water was loud and clear. I looked up to locate the North Star and surmised the light must be coming from the direction of Ox Heart Mountain. I slid down from the tree and made my way toward the light, each step alternating between deep and shallow.

 I began to fantasize that the master of those lights was an old hunter living in the mountains, with a white beard, kind and gentle, warm and hospitable. Surely, seeing an educated youth like me lost in the forest, he would warmly welcome me, first brewing a cup of hot tea before roasting a deer leg for me to eat. The more I thought about it, the hungrier I got, and I wiped the drool from the corner of my mouth with my sleeve.

As I walked, my mind on the food, I quickly arrived at the entrance of a huge cave, where lights shone brilliantly from deep within. It was odd; the lights had seemed close just moments before, but now they appeared deep inside the cave. Perhaps my hunger was making my eyes play tricks on me.

Driven by the immense temptation of the roasted venison in my imagination, I entered the cave, taking three steps at a time as if they were two, until I reached the dark, gloomy, and lengthy end of the cave. There, the space inside the mountain opened up before me, and my eyes were suddenly met with clarity. I caught sight of five or six young girls walking side by side, chatting and laughing. Despite it being the height of summer, they were dressed in luxurious fur coats of a classical style, seemingly not of modern fashion—except for one girl in season-appropriate blue khaki clothing. With two braided pigtails on her head and an army green canvas bag slung over her shoulder, emblazoned with the slogan "Serve the People," wasn't that Tian Xiaomeng?

Indeed, it was unmistakably Tian Xiaomeng. She was an Educated Youth from Suzhou, while Fatty and I hailed from Fujian. Although all of us were from the south, we weren't particularly close. Mainly because Fatty and I were too mischievous, always causing trouble, and the generally quiet and gentle girls didn't dare get too close to us.

However, seeing a familiar face in this strange cave gave me some comfort. I quickened my pace and called out to Tian Xiaomeng, "Xiao Tian, what are you doing here? Do you have anything to eat?"

Tian Xiaomeng turned her head, saw me, and waved, beckoning me to come closer. I approached and said, "You seem to be enjoying yourself here, while we nearly got eaten by a Human Bear looking for you. What is this place? Do you have anything to eat? I'm so hungry I could eat a horse."

Tian Xiaomeng replied, "I'm so sorry, it's all my fault. I got lost while picking herbs in Lama Gully and was rescued by these kind sisters. They're about to perform a Shadow Puppet Play; you've come at the perfect time. We can watch it together before heading back." She then introduced me to the young women beside her, who all spoke with a local accent and were very polite. They offered me some dried deer meat and invited me to join them for the play.

Following them further into the cave, I saw a fortress at the heart of the vast space, its towers magnificent and brightly lit, surrounded by mountains of antiques and jade artifacts.

In front of the city gates, a stage had been set up with paper lanterns and white cloths, behind which sat a dozen masters of the gong, ready to play their music. There was an ancient-looking long table set up in front, adorned with exquisite tea sets and teacups, and a large red agate tray piled high with fruits and pastries.

 Three chairs were set before the table, and the fur-clad ladies who had arrived earlier invited Tian Xiaomeng and me to take our seats to the left and right, respectively. The chair in the center remained conspicuously unoccupied, as if awaiting the arrival of someone of importance.

Tian Xiaomeng, noticing that there were only three seats while the rest stood behind, felt rather uncomfortable and was inclined to decline the offer. But I, weary and famished, had no patience for such formalities. After all, the people's land is for the people to sit upon. If there's a seat to be had, it matters not who takes it.
