So, with a nonchalant air, I sat down and began to eat from the spread before me.

Perhaps my hunger was too great, for although the food was exquisite, it lacked any flavor, tasting as if I were chewing wax. After a few bites, the more I thought about it, the stranger it seemed.

At that moment, two young girls helped an elderly lady, dressed in a luxurious white gown, to walk out from the main entrance and take her place in the central chair.

Tian Xiaomeng and I stood up to greet our hostess, and upon seeing the old lady, a sense of oddity grew within me. What era was it now that we still encountered a figure akin to a landlord's wife?

The old lady nodded at us both and settled into her seat, silent and seemingly waiting for a show to begin.

With a clap from a young woman standing behind, the musicians and puppeteers of the troupe, upon hearing the signal, began to perform with vigor. The Shadow Puppet Play, originating from the Han and Tang dynasties and also known as 'lamp shadow play,' was a popular folk art. It involved carving figures of characters and animals from donkey hide and manipulating them behind a white screen, accompanied by the rhythms of drums and musical instruments, narrating stories through song. This art form, with its hundreds of plays, had been widely celebrated.

However, this art form was inevitably affected during the Cultural Revolution, criticized as a 'poisonous weed' that promoted tales of scholars, beauties, emperors, and generals, and few dared to perform it anymore. I could never have imagined that I would have the opportunity to witness such a performance today. In an era where cultural life was virtually non-existent, this was incredibly captivating. I was so engrossed in the play that I forgot everything else.

The Shadow Puppet Play featured a series of splendid dramas, first depicting Taizong's dream visit to the lunar palace, followed by Di Qing's nocturnal conquest of Kunlun Pass.

On the stage, the clash of swords and the movement of soldiers were depicted in thrilling detail, and the drumming music stirred the audience into bursts of applause. I was so entranced that my throat became parched, and I reached for the teacup on the table to quench my thirst. As I did so, I inadvertently glanced at the elderly lady beside me. She was watching the play with a beaming smile, occasionally reaching for the candied fruits and pastries on the table, her cheeks puffing in a peculiar fashion as she chewed, reminiscent of an old monkey sucking on its food.

My own grandmother, in her old age and without teeth, never ate like that. Confusion took hold of me—was this old lady human or simian? In my disarray, the teacup slipped from my grasp and shattered on the floor. The breaking of the cup was of little consequence, but with it, the old lady's head tumbled to the ground as well. Her severed head continued to gaze at the Shadow Puppet Play, her mouth still chewing incessantly.

 The old lady's maidservants hurriedly approached, reverently lifting her severed head and carefully placing it back upon her body.

I knew in my heart that we had encountered a ghost. Seizing Tian Xiaomeng's hand, I dashed towards the cave's exit. Stumbling through the pitch darkness, we tumbled out of the cave. Thunderous roars filled our ears, the ground shook incessantly, and the cave entrance sealed shut behind us, transforming into a massive stone wall. Had we delayed even half a minute longer, we would have been crushed alive between the closing walls.

Outside, dawn had broken. Clutching Tian Xiaomeng's hand, I ran down to the creek at the foot of the mountain. Suddenly, an excruciating pain seized my belly, cold sweat beading on my forehead as I doubled over. It seemed that something was amiss with the food they had given me. I recalled the tales my grandfather told of ghosts offering food—how ghosts and goblins would turn stones, frogs, and maggots into delectable dishes to deceive humans. I shuddered at the thought of what kind of "ghost bird" I might have ingested, and the revulsion overwhelmed me, causing me to vomit profusely.

In my agony, I vaguely noticed two figures approaching. The girl in the lead looked familiar—it was Yanzi. Seeing her brought a sense of relief, and then darkness clouded my vision as I fainted.

When I awoke, three days had passed. Yanzi and Fatty had stayed in the tree till dawn, while the Human Bear below had bled to death. They couldn't find me anywhere until they discovered Tian Xiaomeng and me, unconscious by the riverbank.

Throughout those three days, I lay in a coma, feverish with temperatures soaring above forty degrees. Fatty had traversed over a hundred li of mountain paths to fetch a doctor from the county for me. Thanks to my robust constitution, I eventually regained consciousness. As for Tian Xiaomeng, she never came to and was taken home by her relatives for further treatment. Her subsequent fate remained unclear to us.

I shared my ordeal with Yanzi's father, who suggested that I might have stumbled upon a "Ghost Market," also known as "Ghost Play." There was a local legend about the Empress Dowager who, upon her death, had many folk performers buried alive with her as burial objects. In the past, others had witnessed similar phenomena on Ox Heart Mountain.

Yet these memories are hazy in my mind, and sometimes I even doubt whether they truly occurred.

My time as an Educated Youth lasted only half a year—not particularly long, but the memories will never fade. When it was my turn to return home for the Spring Festival, my fate took another significant turn.

chapters.name: Chapter 5 Kangba Kunlun Non-freezing Spring
chapters.content:
In that year's spring, the shadow of war loomed over all of China. The Soviet Union had deployed over a million troops across three army groups along China's northern border. India, a neighbor, was in constant friction with China's border forces, and the island nation, seeing an opportunity amidst the tension, readied themselves for a counteroffensive. Meanwhile, the United States' Seventh Fleet had also entered a state of combat readiness.

The upper echelons of the Chinese government felt the threat from international hostile forces and continually readjusted their strategic deployment. The military expanded, preparing for both war and famine, digging deep bunkers and stockpiling grain. The masses actively engaged in the Three Defense Drills against nuclear, chemical, and air attacks.

During my return to the city to visit my family, someone shared insider information with me. My parents' case would soon be clarified by the organization, proving that my grandfather was not considered a landlord but a middle peasant. Therefore, their release was only a matter of time. Due to the People's Liberation Army's large-scale conscription, an old comrade-in-arms of my father's helped me to enlist as a backdoor soldier.

Uncle Chen, my father's comrade-in-arms, was the chief of general staff at the military district. Back when the Ninth Army Corps went to aid Korea, on the icy Gema Plateau, hundreds of thousands of the Volunteer Army encircled the U.S. Army's elite First Division of the Navy's 6th Marine Corps. The U.S. Army's aerial bombs and napalm lit up the night sky like daylight. Braving the steel barrage that formed the U.S. Army's firepower barrier, the Volunteer Army surged like the tide, wave after wave of assaults.

In that brutal campaign, my father, enduring temperatures below minus forty degrees, carried the severely wounded Uncle Chen from a pile of dead bodies. By the time they reached the aid station, their bodies were frozen together by the blood that coated them, and nurses had to cut through their flesh to separate them. Their friendship transcended the phrase "friends through life and death." Moreover, my parents' historical issue was about to be resolved. For a division staff chief, arranging for the son of an old comrade-in-arms to join the military was no difficult task. In a sense, the Chinese habit of using backdoor connections began in the military.

 Uncle Chen asked me what branch of the military I wanted to join, and I told him I wished to be in the Air Force—I heard the pilots get good meals. Uncle Chen chuckled and gave me a playful knock on the head: "You think flying a fighter jet is that easy? You, my boy, should join the Field Army first, tough it out for a few years, get a promotion, and then I'll transfer you to work at the Military District Office." I replied that I'd rather not return to work at a Government Agency; I preferred to stay with the troops on the ground, as office life wasn't for me.

I wanted to go back to Ganggang Camp and say goodbye to Little Fat Swallow and the rest, but time didn't allow it, so I wrote them a letter instead. I felt rather guilty in my heart—joining the army and leaving my good friends behind to toil in the mountains felt like abandoning them in hardship. However, that feeling dissipated after three months; that's when I truly understood how comfortable life as an Educated Youth in the mountains could be.

I was conscripted into a unit that was about to be re-equipped as an armored division. As fate would have it, just after enduring three grueling months at the New Recruit Training Camp, an order from the Central Military Commission came through, and our unit was reassigned to the Sixty-Two Class Soldier Station at the Kunlun Mountain Pass on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. Our entire division was reformed into Engineering Troops.

In fact, this turn of events wasn't all that surprising. At that time, military units across the country were engaged in digging bunkers for civil defense construction—various types of bunkers for air defense, ammunition storage, strategic concealment, and so on. Virtually no military unit was exempt from digging. What set my unit apart was the shift from amateur to professional digging. Our task was top secret: to construct a massive Underground Battle Readiness Facility deep within the Kunlun Mountains. Although the soldiers were not explicitly informed of the facility's purpose, anyone with a bit of sense could probably guess. There were strict confidentiality rules within the troops, so we never discussed this matter. Rumors circulated that upon completion of this engineering mission, we might be reassigned back into the Field Army.

The Kunlun Mountain Pass, also known as the Kunlun Pass, is situated at an altitude that geologically qualifies as Perennially Frozen Desert Terrain, composed of ancient, heavily eroded Complex Metamorphic Rock. From top to bottom, our division, other than being adept at trench digging, knew nothing about civil engineering or construction. Therefore, many engineers and technicians were sent to guide the work and conduct an intensive five-month training for the Combatants. My squad was chosen as the Advance Small Squad to first head south, passing through the Non-freezing Spring, and enter the vast depths of the Kunlun Mountains. Our mission was to scout for concealed locations suitable for construction.

 The Non-freezing Spring is located on the northern bank of the Kunlun River, also known as Kunlun Spring. A circle of granite slabs forms the pool's edge, within which the clear spring water has gushed forth ceaselessly for thousands of years, never freezing, even in the harshest of winters. No one knows where the spring's source lies beneath. Orders from above have been relayed, instructing soldiers not to bathe there, as the local Tibetan people regard the Non-freezing Spring as a divine source and often worship its waters. When Tibet was first liberated, the advancing army passed by this place; at that time, these rules had not yet been established. Three soldiers who bathed in the spring drowned in its depths, allegedly due to the high concentration of nitrate sulfur in the water. Their graves are situated not far from here, at a military post, where our small squad's final supply station is also located.

Finally, we entered the Kunlun Mountains, where nearly everyone suffered severe altitude sickness. Everyone's face turned a shade of purple, their gazes blurry, as if illusions had taken hold in our eyes. The majestic Kunlun, with its thousands of hills and ravines, seemed like an endless procession of silver-gray giant dragons. And our small squad, comprising just over a dozen people, appeared even less significant than a tiny ant in these vast and powerful ranges.

While marching, I remembered the book passed down from my grandfather. It said that the Kunlun peaks, rising five thousand meters, are the ancestors of all dragon veins in the world. These mountain ranges have buried countless secrets since ancient times, and it is said that the mausoleum of the hero king of Tibetan mythology, King Gesar, and the gateway to the Demon Nation are both hidden within these undulating peaks.

In ancient Tibetan customs, sky burial is not the highest honor. The highest form of burial is a tower burial, according to the Book Alliance.

chapters.name: Chapter 6: 100 Skins of Beautiful Women
chapters.content:
The Vanguard Team's mission was to find a suitable construction site, accompanied by two engineers, a surveyor, and a geological prospector. After abandoning their vehicle, they trekked through the mountains for two full days. As dusk approached on the second day, they pitched their tents for rest under a sky heavy with leaden clouds, from which sparse snowflakes began to drift down, hinting at a heavy snowfall come nightfall.

The four engineering technicians, all bespectacled intellectuals, included one woman among them. They were far from acclimated to the harsh highland environment, gasping for breath inside the tent, their labored breathing causing concern for their frail physiques.

The Company Instructor, the Squad Leader, and the medic, three in leadership, were busy tending to them—pouring water, offering medicine, and urging them to eat, for the less they ate, the more acute the oxygen deprivation felt.

The soldiers, robust from the rigors of military training—which included daily five-kilometer cross-country exercises with full gear—had a strong capacity to adapt to the environment. By now, they had mostly adjusted to the thin air. Using specially made white coal briquettes, they lit a fire for warmth. The soldiers huddled together, eating their half-cooked noodles and compressed biscuits, as the high altitude prevented water from boiling properly, leaving the noodles only partly done.

A few comrades-in-arms, who I was quite familiar with, included the tall lads from Heilongjiang in the northeast, a Tibetan soldier named Gawa from the Tibetan Region, and Xiao Lin, a sixteen-year-old signalman from Jilin. After hastily consuming our noodles and catching our breath, we felt that just having a meal on the plateau required more effort than a cross-country march on the plains.

After resting a bit, Xiao Lin said to me, "Brother Hu, you're a city soldier, knowledgeable about many things. Tell us some stories, will you?"

The tall fellow chimed in, "Yeah, Old Hu, I just love listening to you talk. It's so engaging. Anyway, we've got to hold a platoon meeting later and can't rest just yet. So go on, tell the comrades a story."

Gawa, whose Mandarin was broken but understandable, also seemed eager to say something. After opening his mouth several times without finding the words, he simply waved at me, which I took to mean, "Go ahead, I'd like to listen too."

With a tongue-in-cheek air, I replied, "With such thin air up here, how come you guys are still so spirited? Since the comrades want to listen, I'll keep it casual for now. But if the Squad Leader gives me a hard time during the platoon meeting later, you all have to back me up."

I said this because our Squad Leader wasn't too fond of me. He had enlisted from the countryside and, like a young bride, had toiled in the army for five years before becoming a Squad Leader. He particularly disliked me, a soldier from the city. Every time there was a meeting, he'd make me speak, then criticize me at length for any slip of the tongue I made—it had almost become a ritual, and it infuriated me beyond words.

But what should I talk about? I had read fewer than ten books in total, which included four volumes of Mao Zedong's Selected Works, a book of quotations, a dictionary, the novel "Red Sun," and "Youth Guards" could count as another. However, I had already told them all about these. There was also a book on "Feng Shui Secret Technique," but I figured they wouldn't understand that.

 After racking my brains, I finally remembered a book I had borrowed from Tian Xiaomeng during the time I went to the countryside; it was a popular folk legend manuscript of that era. The content of this handwritten volume primarily revolved around the exploits of the Plum Blossom Party and was interspersed with a variety of strange and wondrous tales circulating in society at the time. Among these, the story of the "Hundred Skins of Beautiful Women" left an especially deep impression on me.

The narrative began on a train journey from Beijing to Nanjing. Zhao Pingping, a female university student, was traveling back to Nanjing to visit her family. Across from her sat a young and handsome officer from the People's Liberation Army. The two struck up a conversation, rather intentionally or by chance, and Zhao Pingping found herself captivated by the young officer's demeanor and eloquence. As they talked, she learned that he came from a well-to-do family and was highly educated, prompting her to daydream about marrying him. Before they knew it, the train had arrived at Nanjing Station. The officer invited Zhao Pingping to a nearby restaurant to sit down for a meal. During the meal, he stepped out to make a phone call and returned with a letter, entrusting her to deliver it to his family in Nanjing. He explained that he had to return to his unit immediately due to an urgent mission and could not visit his home. Zhao Pingping agreed without hesitation, and after a reluctant farewell, they parted ways.

The next day, Zhao Pingping went to deliver the letter to the officer's home, where she was greeted by an elderly woman. The woman read the letter and then cordially invited Zhao Pingping inside for a cup of tea. After a few sips and some idle chatter with the old woman, Zhao Pingping suddenly felt the world spinning around her, and she collapsed to the floor. She was jolted awake by a bucket of ice-cold water and found herself stripped and bound to a human-peeling stand, surrounded by walls adorned with human skins. Several people stood around her, including the old woman and her burly henchmen. The old woman held the letter in front of Zhao Pingping's eyes for her to read; it contained only one sentence: "Delivering the hundredth skin of a beautiful woman, please accept with thanks." The old woman sneered, "You're at death's door, so I'll let you die knowing the truth. We are all undercover agents, and we peel the skins of women to pack them with explosives. We needed to prepare a hundred human skins, and today we finally have enough." She handed a sharp skinning knife to one of her subordinates, instructing him to begin the gruesome task. The knife, specially designed for skinning, was placed at the top of Zhao Pingping's head, and amidst her screams...

I was just getting to the exciting part when the Second Squad Leader interrupted me, "Enough, enough. Hu Bayi, you're at it again with your wild stories. Right now, our squad is in the middle of conducting a squad affairs discussion meeting. You love to talk, don't you? Well, this time we'll let you have your say—is it relevant or not to the Book Alliance?"

chapters.name: Chapter 7: The Great Glacier
chapters.content:
I rose to my feet, snapped to attention, and mimicked the Squad Leader's accent as I responded: "No, no, why should it always fall to me? It's Lamu Tso's turn, that little Ga Wa should have a say for once. Equality for all is the principle of socialism, after all."

The Second Squad Leader said, "Little Hutong Zhi, why do you always have such odd things to say? I told you not to mimic me. I am the Squad Leader. When I say speak, you speak. Don't bring up Absolute Egalitarianism—do you understand?"

I glanced around at the several comrades-in-arms. Each one of them sat in earnest anticipation of my words. Taking advantage of the Squad Leader's inattention, Ga Wa even stuck out his tongue at me. This bunch, they're really too much. Now I had to find a way to gracefully extricate myself: "Report to the Squad Leader, you haven't yet told us what today's discussion topic is. Without you telling us, how can we speak?"

At that moment, Instructor Li Jian walked over. In his thirties, of medium build, he was a refined man and a veteran soldier of over a decade. He treated officers and soldiers well, without putting on airs. Approaching, he said to everyone, "Comrades, I see you're having a meeting. I'll listen in too."

The Second Squad Leader promptly saluted the instructor, who waved his hand and said, "Carry on, don't let me interrupt your discussion."

With the instructor standing by, the Second Squad Leader, who was of limited capability, became especially nervous, unsure of what to say. Perhaps thinking singing would be simpler, he said to the soldiers, "Comrades, let's sing a Revolutionary Song together to boost our morale. Shall we?"

The soldiers answered in unison, their response nearly causing the instructor to laugh out loud. He quickly pretended to cough twice to cover it up.

The Second Squad Leader, oblivious to the humor, maintained a stern face and raised his hands in the manner of a music conductor: "Comrades, I'll start us off. 'Erlang Mountain,' prepare, sing!"

"Erlang Mountain, no matter how high you tower, the People's Liberation Army's ironclad men, resolved to forge ahead, unafraid of the wind's howl, unafraid of the snow's flutter, determined to build that highway, all the way to Tibet." As the snow in the sky fell thicker and thicker, the chorus of a dozen soldiers resonated amidst the swirling white of the Kunlun Mountains. It was unclear whether the vast, flying snow accentuated the grandeur of the Military Song, or if the soldiers' singing adorned the desolate loneliness of the Kunlun Mountains. For a moment, even the engineers in another tent were drawn by the song, forgetting their altitude sickness as they gazed at the endless peaks, their minds ebbing and flowing with the music.

Finally, the instructor addressed everyone: "Like all of you, this is my first time at the Kunlun Mountains. The conditions here are indeed very harsh, the environment extremely severe. We are facing the sternest of tests. But my comrade brothers, we are no ordinary troops. Our unit is known as the Heroic Bayonet Brigade. This honor was earned by our predecessors with their lives and blood. We cannot under any circumstances tarnish this banner. The Central Party Committee has entrusted us with this Glorious Task, showing immense trust in our sixth company. We must display our Revolutionary Military Style that fears neither hardship nor death to complete this mission successfully. Comrades, do we have the resolve?"

 Together, we answered affirmatively.

The instructor nodded with satisfaction and continued, "Get some rest early today. Our Small Squad will be crossing the Great Glacier tomorrow. Everyone needs to be well-prepared in advance. Dismissed."

On the third morning of our venture into the mountains, Small Squad arrived at the Great Glacier. Legend had it that nearby lay a very low-lying basin, which was the destination of our journey. As this was a secret mission, we could not enlist local guides for direction—indeed, there was no one who knew the way. We had to rely on a roughly made military map, searching for our destination amidst the chaotic contour lines.

The Great Glacier consisted of three parts, with a dramatic height difference and steep slopes. Its highest point soared over six thousand meters, where the snow never melted. In the middle, a long stretch resembled a slick, mirror-like surface of cold ice, with layers reaching hundreds of meters in thickness. At the bottom, it dipped below the average elevation of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, carving deeply into the earth like a fissure, creating a rare belt of green vegetation. Here, the warmth of the earth fostered life, and the plateau reaction lessened. To continue deeper into the Kunlun Mountains, one had to traverse the valleys beneath the Great Glacier.

Before departure, an engineer had warned us that while marching beneath the glacier, any loud noise could trigger an avalanche, burying us alive.

Everyone dared not even breathe too heavily, yet an accident still befell us midway. While descending from the glacier into the valley, an engineer from Beijing lost his footing and plummeted. We found his mangled body in the oasis beneath the glacier. Geological prospector Luo Ning, his colleague from the same unit, upon witnessing this tragic scene, could hardly restrain herself from bursting into loud sobs.

A geologist surnamed Wang quickly covered her mouth with his hand, whispering, "Don't cry out loud."

Luo Ning buried her head deep into Engineer Wang's chest, sobbing in agony. The instructor took the lead in removing his hat, paying silent tribute to the fallen comrade, and then Ga Wa and I gathered the engineer's remains into a bag to bury him. This engineer had been with us for less than three days; I only knew he was from Beijing, and before I even had the chance to learn his name, he was gone without a trace.

A tall man started to gently dig into the earth with an engineer's shovel. After a few scoops, a blue fireball, the size of a basketball, suddenly shot out from the pit he had dug. It circled in the air twice before plunging into the crowd, causing members of the Small Squad to hastily dodge in all directions.

As the fireball hit the ground, the blue flames gradually extinguished, revealing a bizarrely shaped little ladybug. Its entire body resembled red transparent crystal, and its wings were even more translucent and lustrous. Through its clear carapace, one could faintly see the semi-transparent innards, within which seemed to flow a faint flame, giving it an indescribably mysterious and eerie appearance.

 The group exchanged glances, each wanting to ask what kind of insect this was, yet no one could possibly provide an answer. It was likely an undiscovered species. Engineer Wang, driven by curiosity, leaned in closer, pushing up his thick, nearsighted glasses, and excitedly pinched the beetle, which resembled a red flame, between his fingers. He examined it meticulously with great care. However, at that very moment, the spot where his fingers touched the beetle ignited with a blue flame. In an instant, the fierce fire engulfed his entire body.

Engineer Wang was consumed by the blue flames, and large blisters quickly formed on his skin before bursting open. The glasses on his nose melted out of shape and fell to the ground as he twisted and writhed in agony on the floor.

It was too late to save him. His screams, as he was burned by the fire demon, echoed through the valley, sending chills down everyone's spine. It appeared he wouldn't succumb to death for quite some time.

Someone thought to shovel dirt over him to extinguish the flames, but the burns covered one hundred percent of his body, a deep burn injury. Even if the fire on him could be temporarily put out, in the remote depths of Kunlun Mountain, devoid of medical supplies, he wouldn't last more than an hour or two. It would only prolong his suffering.

The sight of a living person being burned alive was too cruel to bear. Luo Ning turned her head away, unable to watch any longer. Her expression froze as she covered her ears, her mouth agape, unsure if she wanted to cry out or scream. Xiao Lin, the youngest among them, was terrified and hid behind the taller figures, his whole body quivering.

The Second Squad Leader drew his pistol, intending to end Engineer Wang's suffering, as he couldn't bear to watch him in such torment. Moreover, if his screaming continued, it could very well trigger an avalanche.

The instructor restrained the Second Squad Leader's hand as he was about to pull the gun bolt and whispered, "Don't shoot. Use the bayonet. Let me do it."

Thousands of tons of snow hung precariously atop the Great Glacier, where any slight noise could lead to catastrophic consequences. The only mercy they could offer Engineer Wang now was to plunge a bayonet into his heart, granting him a swift death.

Without hesitation, the instructor took a Type 56 semi-automatic rifle, now fitted with a bayonet, from one of the soldiers, murmured an apology to his comrade brother, closed his eyes, and drove the military dagger into Engineer Wang's heart. Engineer Wang's heart-wrenching cries ceased, and he lay motionless on the ground, the flames still consuming him.

As the instructor was about to withdraw the bayonet from his chest, the enchanting blue flames flared violently, traveling up the bayonet and along the rifle's barrel.

The fire spread with alarming speed, not even allowing time for a blink. Before anyone could comprehend what had happened, the instructor was already enveloped in the blue inferno.

The instructor, much like Engineer Wang, struggled and screamed in agony. Everyone knew him well enough; he was a tough man, seemingly gentle but with the endurance and resilience of the finest professional soldier. It was unimaginable, the excruciating pain of being burned by that strange fire, to elicit such a piteous wail from him.

 With tears streaming down his face, the Second Squad Leader raised his pistol. He could no longer concern himself with the possibility of triggering an avalanche; he simply couldn't bear to witness the instructor's suffering any longer. Just as he was about to pull the trigger, the instructor, engulfed in flames, suddenly spoke: "I order none of you to shoot. Take the comrades and leave this place immediately."

Despite excruciating pain, the instructor's mind remained lucid. Realizing his screams could set off an avalanche, he silenced himself by turning the glowing-hot bayonet and plunging it into his own heart. After what felt like an eternity, his body was reduced to a pile of fine ash.

The remaining members of the small squad watched this heroic and tragic scene, their fists clenched, teeth gritted, struggling to hold back the tears welling up in their eyes. Some had bitten their lips so hard they bled.

The valley lay silent, the deep blue sky reflected on the surface of the Great Glacier, creating an illusion as if there were two identical heavens – one could not tell which was above and which below. The enchanting beauty of this otherworldly scene was filled with an eerie and terrifying atmosphere.

There were two piles of ashes on the ground. Just minutes ago, they had been alive, and now they were reduced to tiny mounds, burned to the point where not even bone fragments remained. If no one had witnessed what had transpired, who could believe that such events could occur in this world?

Suddenly, from the ashes where Engineer Wang had been incinerated, a blue fireball shot out. It hovered in mid-air, facing the crowd as if choosing its next target. With incredible speed within its range, it seemed no one could escape its attack. A faint vibration filled the air, likely the sound of the strange beetle's wings fluttering in flight.

Now, the small squad had lost three of its key members, including the leading instructor and two engineers. The two remaining engineers were Surveyor Luo Ning and Worker Liu from the Shanghai Geological Survey Institute. It seemed the mission was doomed to fail.

Without the instructor, the soldiers felt as though they had lost their main source of courage. Yet facing the sinister blue fireball, nearly everyone shared the same thought: they would rather be buried alive by an avalanche than be burned to ashes by this ghostly thing.

A few impatient soldiers had already raised their guns, aiming at the beetle in the sky, when the Second Squad Leader suddenly stepped forward and said, "Comrades, the instructor has sacrificed himself, and now I am your captain. I order you all to make it back alive, do you understand?"

I understood what the Second Squad Leader intended to do; he was planning to sacrifice himself to buy time for the others to retreat. I grabbed his arm, choking back tears: "No, you're not even a Party member, why should you go? If anyone should, it should be me."

The Second Squad Leader pushed my hand away, "You little Hu, you're not even a league member. I told you not to mimic me, why won't you listen?" Before his words were fully spoken, he had already charged towards the hovering fireball without looking back.

chapters.name: Chapter 8 Avalanche
chapters.content:
The Second Squad Leader had barely taken two steps forward when he abruptly stopped. Before us unfolded an inconceivable scene: a single Bizarre Ladybug Emitting a Flame Aura had split into three identical copies.

One of the three Blue Fireballs lunged directly at the Second Squad Leader, while the other two darted into the crowd like lightning. Including the Second Squad Leader, Chef Old Zhao, and Communications Officer Xiao Lin, three were struck by the fireballs. Their bodies erupted into flames, and they let out harrowing screams as they writhed and struggled on the ground, desperately trying to smother the engulfing blaze.

A horrifying turn of events ensued. In the face of the fireballs, the soldiers had become so tense that they had all disengaged their weapons' safety catches, and the bullet magazines were fully chambered.

Communications Officer Xiao Lin, a mere sixteen years of age, lacked the courage and mental fortitude of the instructor and the Second Squad Leader in facing death. The devilish flames stripped away his sanity. In the agony of being bitten by the searing flames, his semi-automatic rifle discharged unintentionally with a series of heavy reports—tat-dang, tat-dang, tat-dang, tat-dang. Amidst the heavy gunfire, three comrades were struck by stray bullets and fell into pools of their own blood.

The situation deteriorated rapidly. The instructor would rather take his own life than allow us to open fire, but in the end, someone did shoot. The attack by the strange firebug was terrifying, but it paled in comparison to the horror of an avalanche triggered by gunfire. An avalanche inherently meant a Catastrophe of Annihilation; not a single member of the Small Squad would survive. In the valley beneath the Great Glacier, shouting might only have a thirty percent chance of causing an avalanche, but gunfire was two hundred percent likely to bring about the most dreadful outcome.

Upon witnessing the delirious Xiao Lin's rifle misfire, which accidentally killed three comrades, I didn't have time to think. Gritting my teeth, I raised my rifle and with three bursts, I brought down Xiao Lin, the Second Squad Leader, and Old Zhao, all of whom were still struggling painfully in the fire.

The gunshot sounds of the rifle bullets echoed through the valley. The narrowness of the valley, coupled with the mirror-like ice walls of the Great Glacier, turned it into a natural large speaker. Gunfire, screams, and cries reverberated in waves through the valley, unceasingly.

I had not yet freed myself from the torment of having shot my own comrades; their voices and smiles before death haunted my mind, blurring my consciousness. Suddenly, I felt a chill on my head and, coming back to my senses, touched it to find a snowflake had landed on my forehead.

The weather was clear, and the sun hung in the sky, shimmering with dazzling light—snowfall was impossible at that moment. The instant I touched the snowflake, a dreadful realization sank in my heart: the avalanche had finally begun.

At that moment, from the still-burning bodies of the three fallen comrades, a Blue Fireball rose from each. Now, there was no longer any need to hold back from shooting. Gawa, whose marksmanship was the most accurate among the small squad members, raised his rifle without aiming and fired three shots. Each bullet struck the center of a fireball. The insects inside were not as large as the caliber of the bullets; the bodies of the insects were completely obliterated by the bullets, and the flames disappeared with them.

 After a brief and brutal skirmish, of the ten of us from our squad—eight soldiers plus the Second Squad Leader and one instructor—only Big Guy, Little Wa, and I remained, along with two intellectuals, Worker Liu and Luo Ning.

The snowflakes falling from above grew denser, and a thunderous rumble filled the sky. The entire valley quaked. I looked up to see a storm of snow swirling above, like a white tsunami engulfing the sky, rolling towards our valley with overwhelming force.

Big Guy yanked me and shouted, "Old Hu's Mother, stop gawping and leg it!" (slang for "What are you looking at? Hurry up and move!")

Our position was in the middle of the valley, which was certain to be leveled by the avalanche. There was nowhere to run, but at this life-or-death moment, it's human instinct to make one last desperate struggle.

Luo Ning had already fainted from fear. Big Guy hoisted her onto his shoulder, while Little Wa and I dragged Worker Liu as we ran towards the opposite side of the Great Glacier, hoping to climb the slightly higher slopes before the avalanche hit, vying for that last sliver of a chance at life.

In our most desperate moment, we did not abandon our guns. A gun is a part of a soldier's life; to discard it is to discard one's honor. But everything else was left behind, all equipment forsaken. We wanted to shed our backpacks too, but in our haste, we couldn't manage it. The five survivors clung to each other and ran wildly.

The avalanche was upon us too quickly, a sweeping force that shook the valley with the energy of collapsing snow. The ground shook and the mountains trembled.

I had heard about avalanches, but never could I have imagined a force of nature as powerful as this Silver Giant Wave. Everyone felt a sense of finality, knowing that no amount of speed could outrun it.

Yet, fortune favors the brave, and the violent tremors from the avalanche cracked open a steep, downward-sloping fissure in the mountain slope before us.

With the snowstorm almost upon us, we had no time to think. We charged into the crevice. The slope was steeper than expected, and we fell, tumbling down and crashing at the bottom of a large hole.

Then, a massive slab of snow rolled down from above, sealing the crevice perfectly and kicking up a cloud of snowflakes that made us cough violently. The thunderous noise above lasted a long while before it quieted down. Judging by the sounds, the snow above must have buried us under countless tons.

In the darkness, we could not see anything. After a long time, someone finally spoke up with a thick Northeastern Accent—it was Big Guy. He asked, "Anyone who can still breathe, make a sound. Old Hu, Little Ga Wa, Worker Liu, Luo the Worker, are you all there?"

I felt like my body had almost fallen apart from the fall and was in too much pain to speak. I just grunted twice to show I was still alive.

Little Wa responded and took out a flashlight, illuminating our surroundings. Luo Ning sat on the ground with a vacant stare, seemingly unhurt. Worker Liu lay beside him, unconscious, his eyes tightly shut. His left shinbone was broken, the white of the bone protruding out.

chapters.name: Chapter 9: Nine-layered Demon Tower
chapters.content:
We had tumbled into a narrow and deep crevice in the mountain, the beam of our flashlights unable to penetrate the encompassing darkness. Limited visibility cloaked the distant terrain in mystery.

The tall man felt for Worker Liu's breath and, with a shake of his hand, despairingly uttered, "It's over, he's not breathing."

Crawling over, I touched Worker Liu's carotid artery. He was indeed gone—no heartbeat. I sighed and said to the tall man, "Let's bury Worker Liu."

I took out an Engineer Soldier spade to dig a hole, but Ga Wa stopped me, pointing to the ground: "Bugs, fire."

Ga Wa's reminder brought back the memory of when we tried to bury a fallen engineer in the valley and unearthed a devilish ladybug. Out of the Small Squad's fourteen, ten perished in those harrowing minutes. It seemed the earth here was not to be disturbed lightly, who knew what ghostly things lurked beneath.

I had an intuition that the bizarre insect was no simple mysterious creature. After it set two people ablaze, it split from one into three. Was it merely a coincidence? I couldn't make sense of it.

However, we couldn't just leave our comrade's body exposed. We had to find a compromise. Illuminated by my flashlight, Ga Wa and the tall man gathered stones to cover Worker Liu's body, constructing a rudimentary stone tomb.

Throughout this process, Luo Ning sat motionless on the ground, silently watching over Worker Liu's stone grave. Eventually, unable to contain her grief any longer, she burst into tears, releasing the sorrow that had been dammed in her heart.

I wanted to comfort her but found myself at a loss for words. Her crying touched a nerve, and my heart ached as if being cut with a knife. I thought of the previous night when the Small Squad had gathered around the campfire, belting out military songs. The echoes of those resonant voices seemed to linger in my ears, yet today, most of our comrades lay forever beneath the great glaciers of the Kunlun Mountains.

I helped Luo Ning to her feet, and together we observed a moment of silence for Worker Liu and the other comrades. In those times, any occasion warranted quoting the Selected Works of Mao Zedong. I led with, "The sky is blanketed with white; the urgency of marching through the snow is palpable."

The other three joined in chorus, "Over hills and under mountains, the wind unfurls the red flag across the pass. Only the many ambitions sacrificed dare to command the sun and moon to usher in a new sky."

We then raised our right fists in oath, "We wish our great leader longevity without boundaries, longevity without boundaries. May our intimate comrades-in-arms enjoy robust health, everlasting health. Comrades-in-arms, comrades, please rest assured in your departure. Some deaths are as light as feathers, while others as heavy as Mount Tai. To die for the people's interests is to weigh more than Mount Tai, and you have sacrificed for the people's interests. We must inherit the legacy of the revolutionary martyrs, follow in the footsteps stained red with their blood, and carry the proletarian cultural revolution through to the end. The final victory will always belong to us, the workers."

At that time, I was still a new recruit, never having attended a comrade-in-arms' memorial service. I didn't know what to say, only that this was how others spoke at meetings. In such circumstances, there was no question of appropriateness.

 After a long while, everyone calmed down from the pain and tended to their wounds, which were fortunately minor and did not impede movement. They ate a few compressed biscuits and gathered to discuss the next steps. It was impossible to exit through the valley crushed by the snowboards—I estimated that the entire valley might have been filled by the avalanche. Our only option was to find another way out.

Gawa patted his empty bullet pouch, indicating that our ammunition was running low. When we set out on the mountain, we had to carry a lot of equipment, so we brought only the bare minimum of ammunition: three rifle bullet magazines per person. After all, this wasn't a combat mission, and there weren't any bandits in the area, so we had been somewhat negligent in our planning. During the avalanche, we had lost some of our ammunition, and now each of us had only about twenty bullets left on average, and we had a total of two hand grenades. Underground, there wouldn't be many wild beasts, so having a surplus of bullets was unnecessary—as long as we had enough for self-defense.

We had no more provisions; we had consumed everything edible. We had to find an exit within two days, or else we would starve to death underground. Fortunately, Luo Ning still had a compass on him.

The depth of the mountain crevice was beyond imagination. After heading south for a while, we reached a dead end. The crack in the earth turned north, and it felt as if we were walking beneath the Great Glacier.

We walked in the darkness for over ten hours, and as we proceeded, the terrain descended, and the underground space expanded. Luo Ning checked the barometer, and according to the air pressure, which translated to an altitude of just over four hundred meters, we were at a level comparable to Sichuan, far below the average altitude of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. If we kept descending at this rate, we might as well reach the center of the earth.

Finally, the terrain leveled out, and the sound of a rushing underground river reached our ears, suggesting that one wasn't far away. Seeing no further descent, I shone my flashlight around, looking for an upward path, when suddenly, the beam reflected off the rock wall, creating countless faint glimmers, like light on shattered mirrors.

Luo Ning exclaimed, "Mica!"

The rest of us, not knowing what mica was, mistook her alarm for a sign of emergency and quickly shielded Luo Ning behind us. We swiftly unslung our Type 56 semi-automatic rifles and racked the gun bolts, ready to shoot.

"What are you doing?" Luo Ning asked, puzzled.

While maintaining a defensive stance with my rifle, I asked Luo Ning, "What 'mother' or 'father' are you talking about?"

"It's not an animal," Luo Ning clarified. "I mean, the surroundings are full of crystal bodies. Mica and quartz often grow in the same stratum, so there might also be quartz here."

Although Luo Ning mainly handled cartographic duties, she often worked with geological exploration teams and knew quite a bit about geology. The crystal bodies around us, resembling thin glass shards, were monoclinic crystals that only appeared in ancient dual-quality rock layers. The underground reserves in Hebei were substantial, but the color of the mica here was exceptionally deep, forming large hexagonal columns, far surpassing the quality of what was found in Lingshou County in inland Hebei. The depth of the mica's color indicated that our current location was unimaginably deep.

Attracted by the rare large mica surrounding us, Luo Ning examined one piece after another. I picked up a small piece and looked at it but couldn't see anything particularly remarkable.

Suddenly, I heard the big guy shouting at Gawa, "Lamu Tso, what are you doing? Get up quickly."

Shining my flashlight, I saw Gawa prostrating on the ground, performing full body prostrations in the Tibetan manner. I wondered who he was bowing to. Then, shining the light ahead of him, I couldn't help but draw a sharp breath.

 Beneath the earth stood a colossal Wooden Tower, constructed from thousands of massive timbers. Its surface was speckled with countless red glimmers, which, upon closer inspection in the dim light, revealed the tower's base to be nearly two hundred meters wide, built from packed earth and stone. The body of the tower was made of thousand-year-old cypress wood, rising up into nine distinct layers. Each level was filled with the desiccated skeletons of people in ancient garb, men and women, young and old. Every timber was etched with the secret scripts of the Tibetan people. Could this be a tomb? Its scale was immense; who could have built such a structure underground?

I went over to the little Ga Wa, who was prostrating on the ground, and pulled him up. "Although our Party and Army respect ethnic policies, you, as a Little Ga Wa and a Tibetan, are also a member of the Chinese People's Liberation Army when you don the uniform. As such, you should not indulge in such idealistic nonsense of idealism. We do not permit any engagement in superstitious religious activities."

The tall man chuckled beside us, "Well done, Old Hu. The kid's got quite the knack for words, could make a good political instructor."

Luo Ning had been examining mica but came over when she heard our argument. 

I waved at the tall man to stop interrupting and continued questioning Ga Wa, "Do you recognize the script on this tower?"

Ga Wa shook his head persistently.

I said, "Kid, if you don't understand it, why prostrate yourself? Did the sight of these bones scare you witless?"

Ga Wa's face was filled with panic as he replied in halting Chinese, "Hu, this little bear... oh, let me explain, you pulled me over... the Larados Nine-layered Demon Tower."

I didn't quite catch the first part of his sentence, but the last four words were clear enough. What was this Nine-layered Demon Tower for, if not to bury the dead?

Before Ga Wa could respond, Luo Ning ran back from the side of the tower, gesturing for us to be silent. She whispered urgently, "Don't make a sound, or you'll wake them."

Seeing her serious expression, I sensed trouble but didn't know what she was referring to, so I asked in a low voice, "Wake what, the dead in the tower?"

Luo Ning replied with intense anxiety, "No, it's those firefly beetles; they're all sleeping on the corpses, countless in number."

Only then did I realize that the dense red glimmers on the Wooden Tower were the luminescent bodies of those transparent beetles.

Although I possessed some of the fearless spirit of a revolutionary soldier, the thought of those peculiar beetles filled me with dread. Such creatures beyond common understanding were too difficult to deal with, and the horrific scene in the valley had left a strong sense of fear in me.

I signaled, and the four of us quietly retreated the way we had come. But before we had gone far, Ga Wa's foot slipped, and he fell into a hidden trench that ran parallel to our path and had gone unnoticed on our way in. The trench was only a little over a meter deep, but Ga Wa still grunted from the fall. I quickly jumped down to help him and saw him clutching his foot in pain.

Luo Ning and the tall man also climbed down into the trench. Shining their flashlights, we saw that Ga Wa's foot had been impaled by a sharp white bone, which had pierced right through his shoe and foot, causing blood to gush out. The trench was filled with layers upon layers of animal bones, too numerous to count. It seemed to be a sacrificial burial pit for animals like oxen and dogs.

To avoid disturbing the beetles in the nearby Wooden Tower, the tall man covered Ga Wa's mouth to silence his cries. I swiftly pulled the bone from his foot, and Luo Ning sprinkled Yunnan Baiyao from her first aid kit onto his wound, then wrapped it with a white bandage to stop the bleeding.

 My hands were stained with the blood from the child's leg, and I wiped them carelessly on my military uniform. A thought suddenly flashed through my mind: the sacrificial burial pit for cattle and horses was oddly shaped—not square or round, but dug into a long trench, leading straight to the wooden tower where the bodies were placed. This form closely resembled a layout mentioned in the Feng Shui secret techniques. If it were exactly the same, then there should be another sacrificial trench of the same scale at a parallel position.

The two parallel sacrificial trenches flanked the wooden tower structure of the tomb, forming a 'twin dragons playing with a pearl' configuration. Based on this, the trench beside us should contain various artifacts used by the tomb's owner in life. It was unclear whether these trenches were man-made or natural, though the latter seemed more likely.

The sound of the river's flow nearby was loud, and judging from the roar of the rapids, there was an underground river to the northwest, behind the Nine-layered Demon Tower. Dragons, after all, cannot be separated from water.

If my conjecture was correct, then the map of this underground world was already in my mind. I just needed to find the other sacrificial trench to confirm my deduction.

The big guy pushed my shoulder: "Old Hu, what are you pondering over?"

I had been lost in thought and only came back to my senses with his push. I asked Luo Ning: "Luo the Worker, can you estimate our current position on the map?"

Luo Ning used a compass to reference the map and after a moment's thought, he said: "We've been continuously heading north underground for over ten hours. According to our pace, we should have passed the Great Glacier overhead and be nearing the exit of the Kunlun Mountains."

I shared my thoughts with them. Going back was not an option as it would only lead to the crevices covered by the avalanche. If my estimation was correct, following the underground river should provide us a way out. However, this would mean taking a risk by passing beneath the Nine-layered Demon Tower—a gamble for survival amidst certain death.

After discussing it among the four of us, we decided that despite the dangers, it was worth the risk to try. However, I resolved to first confirm my hypothesis by finding the other sacrificial trench.

Before we set out, I asked the child what exactly the Nine-layered Demon Tower was.

The child struggled with his Mandarin, but after a while, I managed to understand a part of it. In his hometown of Xuewei, there was a relic identical to this Nine-layered Demon Tower. It was said that such towers were the burial form for the mausoleums of the Demon Nation's royal lineage throughout the ages. When the Demon Nation perished, the tomb had been destroyed by the Hero King, King Gesar. On the Tibetan plateau, only a pile of rotten timber frameworks remained, along with narrative poems passed down by word of mouth among the herdsmen, glorifying King Gesar's unparalleled martial exploits like the sun.

When the Tibetan herdsmen passed by these relics, they would bow in worship and chant the epic. This was not out of fear of the Demon Nation king's mausoleum but to express reverence for King Gesar. The child also mentioned some religious matters, which I couldn't understand. Whether those ghostly fire-like insects were the resting spirits from the tomb was also unknown.

Leaving Luo Ning and the other two behind, I crept forward and found another sacrificial trench about a hundred meters away from the Cattle and Horse Sacrificial Burial Trench. Indeed, it contained ancient leather boots, ancient Tibetan wooden scripts, ancient Mongolian wooden scripts, painted wooden pieces, gold-decorated wooden discs, wooden bird and beast figurines, bronze ware, grains, and a large amount of silk and other burial objects.

 It seems my conjecture was not amiss; the Underground River beyond the Nine-layered Demon Tower must surely connect to the outside world. Thus, I slipped back to the Animal Burial Trench to summon the other three to action.

I led the way, with the tall man holding his gun behind me, followed by the lad, whose thorn-wounded foot was not light, and Luo Ning bringing up the rear, supporting him as he walked.

The Nine-layered Demon Tower was vast in scale. The Underground Cavern was originally extremely spacious, but the tower and the large expanses of Mica Handle nearly choked off the northern path, leaving only narrow spaces on either side barely passable.

We passed under the Wooden Tower with bated breath, and upon seeing those beetles flickering with a fiery aura inside the tower, it felt as though our hearts were about to leap from our throats. Throughout the two-hundred-meter journey beneath the tower, each step felt impossibly distant.

Having painstakingly edged past the Nine-layered Demon Tower and walked less than two hundred paces forward, the ground beneath my feet suddenly gave way, as if I had stepped on some enormous creature. Shining my flashlight, I discovered beneath my feet a colossal reptilian animal I had never seen before. It flicked its long tongue, its skin color closely resembling that of the ground, somewhat like a Giant Lizard in appearance, yet akin to a crocodile in shape, but without the rough hide. Its snout was not as pointed as a lizard's, rather more rounded, and its tongue, red and long like a snake's, forked at the end. Its pitch-black skin was covered in large white spots, and from its appearance alone, it could be described as a large frog with a long tail.

In my life, I fear neither heaven nor earth, but I have a particular aversion to such repulsive creatures. Startled, I instinctively shrank behind the tall man, who also caught sight of the peculiar animal and was equally taken aback. Perhaps a soldier's only true companion is his rifle, and acting on instinct, he raised his gun and fired a burst. The reptile writhed a few times and then lay dead.

At this moment, Luo Ning, who had been walking at the back, came over and looked at the animal's carcass on the ground. He exhaled and said to us, "This is a Salamander that dwells underground, feeding on insects and mayflies, harmless to humans."

I was not particularly saddened by the death of an animal; my concern was the tall man's reckless gunfire, which might awaken the insects in the tower. When misfortune strikes, it seems even a sip of cool water can choke you. The beetles in the Nine-layered Demon Tower were evidently stirred by the gunshots, as countless lantern-like Blue Fireballs lit up.

The entire underground space was bathed in blue firelight, and the Wooden Tower too was ignited. The flames grew larger and larger, with hundreds of fireballs hurling towards us. Amid such a great blaze, we felt not a hint of warmth but were instead besieged by a bone-chilling cold that made our teeth chatter.

Seeing the dire situation, the tall man reached for the two Hand Grenades attached to his Armed Belt, ready to pull the pins and hurl them at the fireballs. I quickly pressed down on his hand, "Throw one, and save the last as an Honor Bullet for us. I have no desire to die by that Ghost Fire." Book Alliance

chapters.name: Chapter 10: Underground Lake
chapters.content:
Our standard-issue infantry weapon, the Wooden Handle Grenade, consists of three parts: a cylindrical top wrapped in sheet metal and a wooden handle below. Once the pin is pulled, the explosive charge within propels shrapnel from the metal casing to harm the enemy, though its power is not particularly formidable.

The big fellow left behind one Hand Grenade while I took another, noticing numerous fireballs surging forward. I pulled the fuse, and with white smoke hissing from the Wooden Handle Grenade, I hurled it into the fray.

The Hand Grenade exploded into a cloud of white smoke. The shrapnel struck the dozen or so Blue Fireballs ahead, causing them to fall and extinguish upon the ground. Yet more fireballs continued to swarm in from behind.

Luo Ning led the way, while the remaining three covered the rear, retreating and firing with their Semi-automatic Rifles. With only about twenty Bullets each, they were spent in under two minutes.

To contend with those Mysterious Ladybugs forming Blue Fireballs, gunfire was the only option. Any slight contact would set oneself ablaze. A rifle without Bullets was no better than a fire poker.

The big man discarded his rifle and drew his last Hand Grenade, shouting to me, "Old Hu, it's time. Are we doing this?"

Luo Ning and I supported the little one, forming a circle with the big man's Hand Grenade at the center. I watched the Hand Grenade before me, knowing that once he pulled the pin, we would all go down together in mere seconds. The final moment had arrived.

In such times, I refused to dwell on other matters. Not only were the fireballs drawing nearer, leaving no time for distraction, but I also feared that pondering farewells might weaken my resolve. I had always aspired to be a Top-class Combat Hero like Yang Gensi. Yet here I was, not perishing on a battlefield but at the end of my life under Kunlun Mountain, an end I could hardly accept. Steeling my heart, I was ready to signal the big man to detonate the Hand Grenade.

Luo Ning, who had already braced herself for death with eyes tightly shut, suddenly had a realization. She stood up abruptly, pulling us back, "Listen to the roar of the water! We must be near an Underground River. Let's jump in!"

Caught up in shooting and the impending suicide by Hand Grenade, we had forgotten about the Underground River. Amidst the chaos, we hadn't noticed the thunderous sound of the water. Luo Ning's words sparked hope of a way out. If we could leap into the river in time, the formidable fireballs might be unable to harm us.

Time was of the essence, and with thousands of Blue Fireballs closing in, the four desperate survivors sprinted towards the sound of the roaring water.

The water was only about ten meters away. We hadn't run far when, at the end of the Underground Cavern and around a bend, a large waterfall appeared, cascading into a sizable natural Underground Lake.

Before I could take a closer look, a burning sensation struck my back, a pain as if my heart and liver were being clawed at. Presumably, a fireball had hit me. With mere sparks enough to engulf my body in flames, there was no time for second thoughts. I leaped into the lake.

In the ensuing chaos, I saw the big man and the others, also aflame, screaming as they jumped into the lake one after another. I dove into the water, and the Blue Flame that had caught on me was immediately Extinguished by the Lake Water.

 Water and fire are incompatible, and it seemed as though the other insects knew the ferocity of the lake; they hovered a couple of meters above the surface, not daring to plunge down to attack.

I emerged from the water to catch my breath and saw that the big fellow had also surfaced, but Luo Ning and Ga Wa were nowhere to be seen. Concerned they might have drowned, not knowing how to swim, I took a deep breath and prepared to dive back in to rescue them when Luo Ning, supporting Ga Wa, surfaced from the lake.

It turned out that Ga Wa had never swum in his life. Upon jumping into the lake, he had been overwhelmed by the water and fainted. Luo Ning, who had seen what happened, dove in and brought him to the surface. Fortunately, Ga Wa had not been underwater for long; after coughing up a bit of water, he regained consciousness.

Tibetan customs forbid swimming or bathing in lakes, so Ga Wa chanted prayers incessantly, seeking Buddha's forgiveness.

The lake's surface was brightly illuminated by countless fireballs, as bright as day. The four of us huddled together, and despite it being early spring, we found the underground water not cold but rather warm to the touch, a geothermal effect creating a warm lake.

The big fellow cursed, "Damn it, my gun's gone, sunk to the bottom of the lake."

I reminded him, "We're out of bullets anyway. A gun's no use to us now. Let's focus on finding a way out. Keep your head low and watch out for those insects diving down."

The big man scoffed at the idea that the fire-bodied insects could dive into the lake, grinning foolishly. But his smile soon froze as thousands of blue-glowing fireballs gathered into a massive flame and swooshed down toward us. He quickly ducked back under the water.

I took a breath, ready to follow, when I saw Ga Wa paralyzed by shock. He had an innate fear of the water and dared not dive to escape. I had no choice but to forcibly push his head under and drag him by the arm toward deeper waters.

The fireball, several meters in diameter, touched the lake surface, causing steam to rise. Despite its size, the lake was vast, and the suicidal attack method of the ladybug suicide squad was ineffective; they drowned one by one.

The lakebed was naturally dim, but the firelight from above allowed us to make out the surroundings within a dozen meters. In the depths, numerous large fish swam slowly. These fish, with their extremely long barbels, resembled mahi-mahi. Adapted to the dark environment, their eyes had degenerated into mere white spots.

Startled by the peculiar appearance of these large fish, I swallowed some water. Glancing at Ga Wa, who was flailing and unable to hold his breath any longer, I guessed the insects had mostly perished and pulled him back to the surface.

The lake's surface was littered with the dead bodies of the ladybugs, and without the firelight, everything was shrouded in darkness. I called out to the big man, "Do you still have a flashlight?"

He replied, "Lost everything, nothing left. Guess we're moving in the dark now."

Suddenly, there was light. Luo Ning emerged from the water, wiping her face. In her other hand, she held a military L-shaped flashlight. "It's the last two I have. Luckily, they were in my pocket and didn't fall into the lake."

We helped each other onto the shore, feeling both exhausted and hungry, with no energy left to move. After going without food for over ten hours, even bodies of iron would falter under such strain.

The big man dove back into the lake and returned with a fish skewered on his bayonet. He scraped off the scales haphazardly and sliced it into pieces. I tried a piece first; the raw fish tasted fine, not too fishy, just slightly bitter, which became savory after chewing more.

Only Ga Wa, citing religious reasons, refused to eat, adhering to the ethnic discipline of the troops that prohibited consuming fish in Tibet. But considering that the Kunlun Mountains lie on the border between Qinghai and Tibet, and we were technically still on the Qinghai side, where the Hui population outnumbers the Tibetans, eating fish here did not break any rules. In truth, even if it did, we were too famished to care. Special circumstances called for special measures.

 Three of us wolfed down a large fish with ravenous hunger and felt a lingering craving for more, so the big guy dived back into the lake to fish. Luo Ning checked the wounds on the child's feet, while I walked around the lake to see if there was any way out. Given the waterfall's powerful flow, there had to be an outlet somewhere.

The waterfall had a drop of several dozen meters, and Luo Ning surmised that the water system before us was likely an underground tributary of the Yarlung Tsangpo River. Moreover, the possibility of a volcano deep underground could explain the warm temperature of the lake water.

Armed with Luo Ning's L-shaped flashlight, I discovered an opening in the underground lake through which water flowed out. The waterway was a cave about seven or eight meters high, completely submerged, with no path to walk on. If we wanted to move forward, we would have to swim out through the water.

I returned to Luo Ning and reported what I had seen. Having lost her map and compass, she could only guess our location based on intuition. With years of experience in surveying, she estimated we were not far from the Non-freezing Spring, which, even in the depths of winter, did not freeze, suggesting the presence of underground magma. The problem was finding a way back to the surface; constantly wandering underground was not a solution. The only viable plan was to follow the river, as only where there was a river would there not be a dead end.

The big guy came back disheartened, having caught no fish this time. Unwilling to linger, the three of us, all strong swimmers, supported the child between us and swam downstream toward the far end of the cave.

Although not wide, the underground river had a strong undercurrent. With the help of the rushing water, we floated and swam with little effort. However, the tunnel was exceedingly long, and the water temperature had risen considerably. The smell of sulfur filled our nostrils, and despite being in the water, we all felt parched.

The big guy grew restless and complained as we swam, "We might have made a mistake of left-leaning impulsiveness this time. How come we've swum so long without reaching the end? With such a rapid current, there's not even a place to stand and catch our breath. Maybe we should just turn back."

I rebuked him, "What were you doing earlier? Now that we've come this far, you're asking how much longer the red flag can be waved? Are you doubting whether our revolution can achieve final victory? You're already faltering at the first step of the Long March of Ten Thousand Miles. Bite the bullet and hold on."

The big guy retorted, "How can you say that? I just want to conserve some strength for the revolution. If you keep going blindly like this and cause a loss to the revolution, who's to blame?"

We had only gotten halfway through our conversation when Luo Ning cried out in alarm, "Look behind us! Is there some animal? It seems like a water monster."

I also heard an unusual disturbance in the water behind us, and turning around, I shone the flashlight. The water churned, and a massive shadow approached rapidly from beneath the surface. The flashlight's beam was insufficient to see clearly, but it was clear that the comer meant no good. We each drew our military daggers, bracing for battle.

chapters.name: Chapter 11: Tyrant Salamander
chapters.content:
The undercurrents beneath the river's surface and the force of the Dark Surge grew ever stronger, beyond our control. We were swept helplessly forward by the torrent, while the enormous creature behind us followed as if it were our shadow.

Most of its body submerged, it churned the water into wave after wave of spray. The cavernous river passage was too dark to see; we could only hear the creature, and by the sound of it, it must have been at least seven or eight meters long.

In the final stretch of the subterranean river, the current intensified. Fearing we would be separated, the four of us clung tightly together, tumbling and spinning into a hole in the riverbed.

Below lay a vast underground river, its waters scaldingly hot. Countless tributaries, just like the ones we had passed, burst forth from the mountain walls like enormous water cage heads, converging into the main channel below. On both sides, protruding stone orifices emitted jets of white, high-temperature gas. Some crevices even glowed with the dark red of lava. It seemed we had reached the subterranean volcanic zone Luo Ning had mentioned.

The river's temperature was extreme, and we struggled desperately to climb atop a massive rock on the riverbank, which felt warm to the touch. The nearby glow of molten lava provided enough light, so I turned off my flashlight to conserve the precious battery life. I asked my companions, "Did any of you get a clear look at that thing behind us? It was enormous."

The tall man and Luo Ning both shook their heads, having seen nothing clearly. Gawa fared the worst, having swallowed a bellyful of river water, his stomach distended and round. He tried to speak but vomited several mouthfuls of water first. Rubbing his belly, he said, "Oh, I saw that little bear. It fell into the middle of the river behind us."

To be on the safe side, the tall man stood up with a military dagger in hand to survey the nearby river. "There's no sign of any water monster," he said. But as he turned to come back, a blood-red tongue, over two meters long, shot out from the river, coiling around his legs and knocking him to the ground, dragging him towards the water.

Thanks to Gawa's quick reflexes, he stabbed the monstrous tongue with his bayonet. The creature, pained by the attack, released the tall man. It emerged from the water, glaring with eyes that glowed red like lanterns.

It looked exactly like the salamander that the tall man had previously shot dead—its head like a frog's, its body like a skinless crocodile's. But this salamander was colossal, measuring over ten meters in length. Its skin shimmered with iridescent scales, and with a vicious flick of its tail, it watched us menacingly.

I hurriedly asked Luo Ning, "Luo the Worker, are you sure it doesn't harm humans? Why is this one so huge?"

Luo Ning was pale, trembling as he replied, "I said the last one was just a Tyrant Salamander, very aggressive and extinct since the Ice Age. I never imagined they'd still be here."

None of us had anticipated that in this isolated environment, creatures from ancient times, long thought extinct, would still exist.

Salamanders, such creatures of the underground, are cold-blooded. The excessive geothermal heat had rendered this Tyrant Salamander before us incredibly ferocious. Moreover, Gawa had wounded its tongue, and the taste of blood in its mouth had triggered its aggressive instincts. Furthermore, we had no idea if the salamander we had shot was a relative or offspring of this one. In any case, a feud had been established, and it seemed we were now bound to fight to the bitter end.

 I signaled with my eyes, and the tall fellow and the little guy understood immediately, flanking the Tyrant Salamander from both sides. Our trio formed a pincer attack, ready for combat.

The Tyrant Salamander bellowed and hissed, confronting us with bared teeth and brandished claws. Before we could even make a move, it swept its massive tail, knocking the little guy to the ground and coiling around him. With its gaping maw wide open, it lunged to bite. Normally, salamanders don't have teeth, but this Tyrant Salamander's jaws were lined with three rows of sharp fangs, top and bottom. A single bite would be fatal.

In the face of imminent danger, the tall fellow and I lunged forward. Together, we grappled with the Salamander's gaping jaws from above and below, determined to prevent that lethal bite, or the little guy would lose his head.

Whenever religion was not involved, the little guy would become incredibly brave. Even though his lower body was trapped by the Salamander's tail, his hands never stopped moving. Seeing that the creature was tough-skinned and impervious to both water and fire, he resorted to stabbing fiercely with his bayonet into its mouth.

Wounded and enraged, the Tyrant Salamander thrashed about with such strength that it flung all three of us to the ground. The force of its throw was immense; I was hurled against a rock, which left me reeling with a surge of blood and stars dancing before my eyes. The tall fellow fell into the river but quickly scrambled back to shore, his body steaming white and howling in pain from the scalding water.

To think that we could fight this colossal Tyrant Salamander with just three bayonets was like trying to shatter a rock with an egg. With a collective shout, we turned tail and fled, with the Salamander in hot pursuit.

The ground was littered with volcanic rocks and ash, soft and slippery, making our escape all the more arduous. To shake off the pursuing behemoth, we climbed the steep volcanic rock at the edge of the river valley, scrambling higher and higher. Halfway up, I heard the tall fellow shouting a warning to me. Glancing down, I saw the Tyrant Salamander scaling the cliff like a giant lizard, mere meters away from me. Its long tongue almost licked my boots. I contemplated jumping down to escape, but the height was too great, and I couldn't be sure of landing in the river. A misstep could mean a fatal crash onto the rocks. Cursing, I freed one hand to draw my bayonet, ready for a cornered beast's last stand—if I was to die, I would take the monster down with me.

The other three, seeing the Salamander closing in on me, were helpless with frustration. The slope was too steep for them to come to my aid in time. They watched, teeth clenched and eyes fierce, but could do nothing.

The Book Alliance

chapters.name: Chapter 12 Earthquake
chapters.content:
Suddenly, Luo Ning thought of something and, leaning against the rock wall, shouted at me, "Comrade Little Hu, honor bullet!"

The others had the realization at the same time. Yes, we still had one hand grenade left, unused, tucked in the big guy's armed belt all this time. The standard-issue Chinese wooden handle grenades were waterproof. Some soldiers stationed by Qinghai Lake would often use hand grenades to fish in the lake. Despite everyone having fallen into the water earlier, the hand grenade should not have been affected by the moisture. We owed a debt of gratitude to Luo Ning for the reminder.

The big guy pulled out the hand grenade: "Old Hu, catch!" He lobbed it towards me from above.

I quickly clamped the bayonet between my teeth and reached out with my right hand to catch the hand grenade. I used my big thumb to push off the safety cap, spat out the bayonet, and bit down on the pull ring. The fuse of the hand grenade was ignited, hissing as it emitted white smoke.

I looked down and aimed for the tyrant salamander's gaping mouth, throwing the hand grenade into it. The creature, unaware of what a hand grenade was, saw the dark object flying towards it and, following its hunting instincts, snatched it with its long tongue and swallowed it. There was a muffled boom—the grenade exploded inside its mouth. Although the tyrant salamander's outer skin was tough, the flesh inside its mouth was soft. The explosion blew its head inside out, the remains falling beneath the rock wall. Its massive body twitched a few times before it lay dead by the riverside rocks, belly-up.

I exhaled deeply, my entire body soaked in cold sweat. I hadn't felt fear during the moment, but now my limbs were weak, and looking down made my head spin.

Suddenly, the mountain wall shook violently. The water in the underground river surged, filling the air with the scent of sulfur, and waves of heat rushed up from below.

The volcano beneath the riverbed had become active. This unexpected event caught us all by surprise, nearly causing us to fall. We scrambled up a relatively gentle slope and sat down to catch our breath, still shaken. But the underground tremors grew more intense, and the volcanic rock that formed the mountain wall threatened to collapse at any moment.

Luo Ning said that a volcanic eruption wasn't necessarily imminent; it seemed more like a periodic volcanic activity. The duration of these cycles was unpredictable—it could be days or even centuries apart. There are many types of volcanoes. The common ones with inverted trumpet-shaped chimneys are formed after large-scale eruptions. Others, though not extinct, may not have erupted for tens of thousands of years, lying deeply buried underground, occasionally causing tremors.

Regardless of its activity cycle, we were out of luck to have encountered it now. We had intended to follow the underground river to find an exit, but with the water now boiling, descending further would have meant being cooked like dumplings in a pot. It seemed impossible to go down. At a loss for what to do next, Gawa tugged at my clothes and pointed upwards for us to look.

Hundreds of meters above our heads, a slender ray of white light appeared. My eyes dazzled, and I felt a sharp pain in them. What could it be? Perhaps it was some long-extinct creature?

Luo Ning was ecstatic: "It's the sky! It's the sky!"

The seismic activity from the underground volcano had caused an earthquake, splitting open a large fissure above us. Having not seen the outside sky for so long, I had almost forgotten what it looked like—whether it was blue or white.

 I said to the others, "Comrades, indeed there is no predicament without an outlet. Perseverance leads to victory. For the sake of New China, let us advance."
