The four of us, already exhausted, suddenly saw a glimmer of hope for escape from Birth Sky, and as if out of nowhere, boundless strength surged within us. We stretched our legs and swung our arms, scrambling up the slope with all our might.

The rumbling below grew more intense, the heatwave oppressive, and the pungent sulfur fumes caused throbbing pain in our foreheads. Fearing that the crack might close again due to the earthquake, everyone wanted to get out as quickly as possible. On the steep 45-degree slope, we exerted ourselves as if sprinting a hundred meters.

The higher we climbed, the more fragmented the volcanic rock became. Some were as fine as sand, making it hard to find footing. For every three feet we ascended, we slid back two, our hands raw from the friction, but we ignored the pain, gritted our teeth, and clawed our way up. The 500-600 meter ascent was as arduous as the Long March of Ten Thousand Miles across snowy mountains. After expending all our strength, we finally returned to the surface, greeted by the blue sky and white clouds, with mountains stretching on both sides. The spot we had climbed to was a section of the Kunlun River Valley, one of the lowest areas on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, just a few kilometers from the Non-freezing Spring Military Station at the head of the pass.

Luo Ning was weak, and Gawa had an injured foot; they lagged behind at the critical moment. Without time to rest, the tall man and I linked our Armed Belts into a lifeline and lowered it for Luo Ning and the others to grasp.

The earthquake grew fiercer, and the crack, more than a meter wide, could collapse at any moment. Luo Ning and Gawa could only cling to the belt, each step sliding back due to the tremors below, unable to advance even half an inch.

The tall man and I pulled with all our might, but no matter how strong we were, it was impossible to haul them up together. Just then, Gawa released the belt and pushed Luo Ning up from below while we pulled from above, and in one go, we yanked her out of the fissure.

When I thought to throw the belt down again to save Gawa, a violent tremor hit, and the earth closed in again, trapping Gawa alive in its midst.

In the sub-zero temperatures, our coats and hats long gone, the three of us, forgetting the cold and clad only in thin clothes, wept and futilely dug at the earth and stones with our hands and bayonets.

Three days later, I lay in a bed at the Military District Hospital. The Chief of Staff of the Military Region, holding my hand, offered his warm consolation, "Comrade Little Hu, you have shown great bravery this time. On behalf of the Military Commission, I extend my regards and hope for your swift recovery, that you may achieve new merits on the revolutionary path. How are you feeling now?"

I replied, "Thank you for your concern, sir. I am holding up alright. But whenever I think of those comrades-in-arms who have left me forever—Xiao Lin, Gawa, the instructor, the Second Squad Leader—this weight in my chest, it's just indescribable." Book Alliance

chapters.name: Chapter 13: Leaving the Troops
chapters.content:
Just as Churchill once remarked, there are no permanent friends or enemies in the world, only perpetual interests.

Due to the exigencies of the international situation, my unit was dispatched deep into the Kunlun Mountains for construction work. The harsh environment caused the project progress to lag unexpectedly. Over the course of three years, dozens of combatants sacrificed their lives on the worksite, and yet the military facility we were building had only reached two-thirds completion.

At this juncture, the global political landscape was reshuffled. Nixon's visit to China in '72 thawed Sino-American relations. China's strategic deployment underwent a massive overhaul, and the construction project within the Kunlun Mountains was halted. We, the combat engineers who had been drafted midway into our careers, were reassigned back to the field army's combat sequence, under the jurisdiction of the Lanzhou Military Region.

Day after day, year after year, the routine of training, drills, exercises, study, and critiques continued. Life in the barracks was not only monotonous but also arduous. A few more years passed, and the Cultural Revolution came to an end. The Central Party Committee timely rectified the chaos, the Gang of Four was smashed, and after a decade of turmoil, social order was finally restored.

However, the army was an environment isolated from society, and I hardly felt any significant change within the barracks. The only difference was that we no longer had to recite quotations upon meeting each other, but whenever new recruits arrived, we still had to provide them with revolutionary education.

One morning, just as I returned from a meeting at the headquarters, the communications officer Little Liu came running up to me, panting: "Report to the Company Commander, a platoon of new recruits has arrived today. However, the political instructor has gone to the Military Region for training, so please, you must give them a talk on the revolution and our traditions."

Speaking about the revolution and our traditions essentially meant sharing the history of our unit with the new recruits. Admittedly, I was no expert on the subject, but as the company commander and with the political instructor away, I had no choice but to step up to the task.

I led the thirty-odd new recruits into the unit's Honor Display Room and pointed to an embroidered banner that read "Heroic Bayonet Brigade," telling them that this was an honor earned by the predecessors of our Sixth Company during the Huaihai Campaign. This title had been retained to this day. I recounted the fierce battle, embellishing the details of how our Sixth Company had seen red with their bayonets and, despite being out of ammunition and provisions, had used their bayonets to repel a frenzied attack by an entire regiment of Kuomintang reactionaries, gloriously completing the blocking task assigned by our superiors.

Then, pointing to a blackened, broken iron pot in a glass case, I narrated to the new recruits: "Comrades, don't underestimate this old pot. During the Huaihai Campaign, it was after eating pork and vermicelli stew cooked in this very pot that the revolutionary forebears of our Sixth Company went on to kill enemies and earn merits on the battlefield. Look at the cracks on this pot; they were caused by the reactionary artillery fire of the Kuomintang, and to this day, it silently bears witness to the heroic deeds of the past and the beastly behavior of the reactionaries."

That was about all I could share, as I wasn't professionally responsible for ideological work. Still, I believed I did quite well, enough to hoodwink these new recruits.

After dismissing the new recruits to the canteen for their meal, I walked behind them with Little Liu and asked him, "How was the level of the 'revolution and tradition' talk given by our Company Commander just now?"

 Little Liu exclaimed, "Wow, Company Commander, you speak so wonderfully that I'm drooling over here. When will our unit study the Revolutionary Martyrs and improve our meals a bit? I'm craving some pork stewed with glass noodles."

Swallowing hard, I flicked Little Liu's forehead and scolded him, "You didn't catch a word about the revolutionary traditions, just fixated on pork and noodles, eh? Hurry up and get to the canteen for food. I heard they're serving buns today, and if you're late, the new recruits will have snatched them all up. I order you, run!"

With an affirmative shout, Little Liu strode briskly, charging towards the canteen. Suddenly remembering something crucial I had neglected to tell him, I called out, "Pick a few with generous fillings for me!"

Lying on my bed, I devoured the buns while perusing the letter that had just arrived from home. Everything was fine, with no mention of anything significant. After reading it twice, I set the letter aside and picked up the worn book passed down through my family. The experiences of the past few years had sparked a profound interest in Feng Shui, and I would study it whenever I had the chance.

The book was filled with terms like the Five Elements, Eight Trigrams, and Yi Numbers, mentioning things like Eastern Jia Yi Wood, Southern Bing Ding Fire, Central Wu Ji Earth, Western Geng Xin Metal, Northern Ren Gui Water, and trigrams such as Qian, Zhen, Li, Wei, among others. Many parts were puzzling. Over the years, I had gathered various books on the subject and, despite my limited education, managed to grasp about thirty to forty percent of the content.

The Sixteen-Character Yin-Yang Feng Shui Secret Technique is comprised of the words Man, Buddha, Intimidate, Object, Yang, and Empty.

The origins of the book, as well as its author, were unknown, but its contents were profound. It spoke of the Sixty-four Changes of Fuxi's Bagua, which should actually be the Sixteen Hexagrams. During the Yin Shang Dynasty, these Sixteen Hexagrams, which were said to reveal the secrets of heaven, were halved by the deities, and even the number of the remaining Eight Trigrams was incomplete. Yet, those who understood even a fraction were considered formidable. Take Zhuge Kongming, who, with some knowledge, was able to protect Liu Bei and strategize for a world in balance. Liu Bowen, who could decipher but a third, helped Zhu Yuanzhang establish the Ming Dynasty's foundation for four hundred years. But such tales of mystic power, I found hard to believe.

My only regret was that this book contained only the half that discussed the Fengshui Five Elements Tomb Layout Structure. The other half, concerning the Yin Yang Bagua Taiji numbers, had been missing since my grandfather's time. The fragmented text was disjointed and obscure, making it difficult to fathom its deeper meanings. I imagined that a complete version would be much easier to understand.

Suddenly, the air of the military camp was pierced by a series of long and short bugle calls—an emergency assembly. My immediate thought was that something had happened; such a call would not be made without good reason during the daytime. I stuffed the remaining two buns into my mouth, sprang from the bed, and dashed out the door.

 Rows upon rows of troops aligned in orderly columns, and I saw that it wasn't just our battalion assembling—our entire regiment was mustering. As a junior officer like myself, I wasn't privy to the details of the operations at hand, my role was simply to obey orders and follow commands. We were instructed to stand by at the train station, ready to deploy alongside the Brother Troops.

Over ten thousand men, a force as imposing as mountains and seas, crowded the Military Train Station. From a distance, the mass of soldiers resembled a tide of green. It seemed the whole division was mobilized—an extraordinary event, as calling an entire division to action was no small feat. Our Main Force Division was a large establishment, comprising three Infantry Regiments, an Artillery Corps, a Tank Regiment, and the Administrative and Logistics Department of the Headquarters, totaling more than twenty thousand personnel. Such a large-scale operation surely wasn't for disaster relief, as I hadn't heard of any disasters in the vicinity recently.

We were bewilderedly transported in Iron Can Vehicles all the way to the Yunnan Border, where it finally dawned on us that we were heading into battle. At that moment, many broke down in tears.

Meanwhile, Deng Xiaoping, on a visit to the United States, made a startling statement at the White House: "When children don't listen, they need to be disciplined." He openly acknowledged the large-scale troop buildup along the Sino-Vietnamese Border.

The Dawn Division's two hundred and twenty thousand People's Liberation Army soldiers launched a full-scale offensive, pushing forward to Liang Mountain, after which China announced its withdrawal.

My unit was the Dagger Company of the Main Force Division, on the Frontline. After ten days of fierce combat, we suffered over fifty percent casualties. During a subsequent march, we fell into an ambush by Vietnamese Special Agents. They used women carrying children as Cover, throwing Dynamite Bags into our Armored Personnel Carriers. Eight of my soldiers were killed inside the armored vehicle. In that moment, my eyes saw red—I killed three and captured two remaining Vietnamese Militia, an old man and a child.

They were a Vietnamese Old Man in his fifties and a Vietnamese Woman in her twenties, apparently father and daughter. One of my men told me that the woman had disguised the Dynamite Bag as a baby in her arms and threw it into the armored vehicle as she passed by. There was no mistaking it—it was her doing.

What I feared most was witnessing my Comrades-in-arms dying before my eyes. In a fit of rage, I completely forgot the Three Main Rules of Discipline and the Eight Points for Attention, as well as our military's policy on the treatment of prisoners. I had a Dynamite Bag tied underneath the Vietnamese Woman and made her sit on an Earth Plane. I then bound the old man tightly and threw him from the cliff into a minefield.

This act was a serious violation of military discipline and even alarmed General Xu at Command Headquarters. Had it not been for my family's deep connections within the Military Region, I would have been court-martialed, and my military career would have been over. With a demobilization order in hand, I returned to my hometown. Book Alliance

chapters.name: Chapter 14: Business
chapters.content:
The battle was nearing its end, sporadic gunfire still erupted intermittently, and the battlefield was shrouded in gun smoke. Trenches were chaotically filled with bodies, strewn in every imaginable position.

In the tunnel, about six or seven remaining Vietnamese soldiers were trapped. I had my men seal off all the exits. Standing at the tunnel's entrance, I shouted into the depths: "Yě bù sōng gōng yè, sōng kuān hóng dú bīng nèi."

The rest of the soldiers joined in: "Yě bù sōng gōng yè, sōng kuān hóng dú bīng nèi." In Vietnamese, this meant, "Lay down your arms, and you will not be harmed; prisoners will be treated well." Each frontline combat unit was equipped with a Battlefield Manual, which included phonetic transcriptions in Chinese characters for common Vietnamese phrases such as "Raise Your Hands" or "Don't Move, Hands Up." These phrases were used for capturing or persuading the enemy to surrender. Additionally, there were messages intended to propagate our military policies to the Vietnamese civilians. In fact, in the northern regions of Vietnam, where numerous ethnic groups resided, the official Vietnamese language was not as widely spoken as Chinese, and most Vietnamese soldiers were conversant in Mandarin.

The encircled Vietnamese, from deep within the tunnel, responded with a volley of bullets.

I threw my steel helmet to the ground, cursing: "Damn their ancestors, they refuse to be captured alive." I then turned to the soldiers behind me and commanded: "Cluster hand grenades, flamethrowers, hit them hard." Cluster grenades and flamethrowers were the most effective means against enemies stubbornly resisting inside tunnels and bunkers. We would first suppress them with a barrage of grenades, then proceed to exterminate them with flamethrowers.

Bundle after bundle of grenades were hurled into the tunnel, followed by a series of violent explosions. The Chinese soldiers then pressed the flamethrowers against the entrance and unleashed a fierce blaze.

The air was thick with smoke and the smell of burnt human flesh, making it impossible to keep one's eyes open. I led the way into the tunnel with a submachine gun in hand, eager to see what those little, skinny chicken-like Vietnamese brats had been reduced to.

Inside the tunnel, more than a dozen charred Vietnamese bodies lay scattered, indistinguishable whether they had perished from the blasts or the flames.

At the far end, I found a large bundle of unexploded cluster grenades. I hurriedly led my men to run out, but it was too late. A muffled explosion shook me, and a wave of force knocked me down, plunging my vision into darkness, as if a layer of mud had been smeared over my eyes.

Desperately clawing with my hands, unspeakable panic filled my heart. Then someone grabbed my wrist and said, "Comrade, wake up. Are you having a nightmare?"

I opened my eyes to find two train attendants and a carriage full of passengers staring at me, smiles on their faces. Only then did I realize it had all been a dream. I took a deep breath, still shaken by the nightmare.

To think that I could dream while on a train ride home; I had lost all face. I managed an awkward smile to everyone, probably the ugliest smile of my life. Thankfully, there were no mirrors for me to see my own face.

Seeing that I was awake, a train attendant informed me that we were approaching the final station and that I should prepare to disembark. I nodded, squeezed through to the connection between two carriages, and sat on my luggage. Lighting a cigarette, I took several deep drags, my mind still lingering on my comrades-in-arms at the front.

Wearing a uniform without badges or cap emblems felt awkward, and even walking seemed a challenge. How was I to explain this to my father? If the old man found out that I had been sent back by the military, he'd likely take a belt to me.

 After about fifteen minutes, I arrived at my stop. I circled around my front door, not daring to enter, and wandered aimlessly through the streets, trying to concoct some far-fetched story to pull the wool over my old man's eyes.

As dusk fell and twilight embraced the town, I entered a restaurant to grab a bite. The menu prices gave me a start; I hadn't dined out in years, and couldn't believe the cost of food these days—a plate of Yu Xiang Shredded Pork was six yuan! By that reckoning, my demobilization pay of just over three thousand yuan would barely cover five hundred servings of Yu Xiang Shredded Pork.

I ordered two bowls of rice and a plate of Kung Pao Chicken, along with a bottle of beer. The young waitress tried to push some Braised Prawns in Oil on me, but I adamantly refused. Muttering under her breath, she rolled her eyes and huffed away to fetch my order.

I didn't want to stoop to her level. After ten years of military service, sweating blood, facing life and death, my efforts were apparently worth no more than five hundred plates of Yu Xiang Shredded Pork—a thought that was both laughable and somewhat disheartening. Yet, when I considered my comrades who'd sacrificed their lives in the snowy mountains and on the battlefield, what right did I have to feel dissatisfied?

Just then, another customer entered, sporting what appeared to be an imported American-style Large Toad Mirror sunglasses. His trendy attire caught my eye, and I took a longer look.

He noticed me too, and after sizing me up for a while, he came over and sat opposite me at my table.

I wondered what his deal was, with so many other tables free, why squeeze in with me? Could he be some thug looking to start trouble? It was almost as if he read my mind—I was actually in the mood for a fight. But then, something about him seemed familiar. His face was mostly hidden behind the Large Toad Mirror, and I couldn't quite place him.

Pushing his sunglasses down his nose, he spoke, "Heaven's King Covers the Earth Tiger."

The phrase rang a bell, and I automatically responded, "Pagoda Suppresses River Monster."

He asked, "Why's your face red?"

I shot back, giving a Big Thumb up, "Anxious from not finding a wife."

"And why's it turned white now?"

"Scared pale by a shrewish wife."

We embraced each other, laughing. "Little Fatty, bet you didn't expect the Central Red Army to return, huh?"

Fatty, nearly in tears with emotion, exclaimed, "Old Hu, our various Red Army factions have finally rendezvoused in Shaanbei once again."

We'd exchanged letters over the years, but the vast distance had kept us from meeting face to face. It was an incredible coincidence to run into each other in a restaurant upon my return to the city.

Fatty's father had held a higher rank than my own dad, but unfortunately, he didn't survive the Cultural Revolution, meeting his end in a Cowshed. A few years after Fatty's Return to City, he landed a job but got into a fight with his boss. Not long after, he started his own gig as a Self-employed Household, trafficking popular Cassette Tapes of songs to the north from our area.

We hadn't seen each other in years, and as we drank, our faces flushed and voices grew loud, I completely forgot about the lies I had intended to fabricate. When I got home, truth spilled out in my drunken state, and I told my father everything. To my surprise, he wasn't angry but rather pleased. I thought to myself, the older this old man gets, the lower his consciousness seems to fall, happy that his son no longer had to go to the front lines.

 The job that the Reconversion Office had arranged for me was a position at a Food Factory as the Deputy Chief of Security Department. Having spent too much time in the military, I had no desire to return to the routine life of clocking in and out, so I didn't take it. Instead, I teamed up with Fatty to venture into business in the north.

Time flew swiftly, and before we knew it, the Eighties had arrived. We were both well into our thirties, yet our business was growing increasingly bleak. Far from saving up for marriage, we were struggling just to feed ourselves, often having to ask our families for money to deal with urgent needs. According to the Third Plenary Session, the whole country had basically solved the problem of food and clothing, but it seemed to me that we were still living in times predating liberation—oppressed, exploited, and unable to satisfy our basic needs.

On this particular day, the weather was splendid, the sky clear for miles. Each of us sporting a pair of sunglasses and dressed in bell-bottoms, we pushed a tricycle down the streets of Beijing. On it, we mounted a board laden with cassette tapes, and with a battered tape recorder connected to two worn-out speakers, we blared Taiwanese pop songs of the time.

A bespectacled female student approached us, browsed for a while, and asked, "Do you have any tapes by Wang Jieshi and Xie Lisi?"

We used to stock those, but they had sold out two days earlier. Fatty, with a grin, responded to her, "Oh, my dear sister, what era are you living in that you're still listening to their songs? Have you heard of Teresa Teng, Qian Baihui, or Zhang Aijia? Take a few tapes to listen to at home, they're as delightful as can be."

The female student, sensing that Fatty was not the most reputable of fellows, turned and walked away.

Fatty couldn't help but mutter a string of curses in frustration: "What a fool, putting on airs like that. She still wants to listen to Golden Shuttle and Silver Shuttle, yet she looks as plain as a shuttle herself."

I chided him, "Why have you started speaking with a Beijing Accent now? Isn't speaking Mandarin well enough? Pretending to be someone you're not. Doing business in Beijing has become too difficult; let's head to Xi'an in a few days."

Fatty was about to defend his lineage, claiming his ancestors hailed from Beijing, but before he could finish, he suddenly pointed towards one end of the street and shouted, "Industry and Commerce are raiding, run!"

We pushed our tricycle and bolted, zigzagging through the streets until we unwittingly found ourselves in Panjiayuan Antique Market.

The street was lined with vendors dealing in all things vintage, from Old Emblems and Red Treasure Books that collectors sought, to an assortment of bottles, old clocks, Old Pocket Watches, and Embroidered Shoes once worn by women with Three-inch Golden Lotuses. Piles of old coins, Snuff Bottles, various Antique Furniture, Pipes, calligraphy and paintings, Carved Research Desks, Inks, Brushes, and Yellow Papers, old Pipes, cricket jars, porcelain, Lacquerware, and an array of gold and jade ornaments—if it was old, it was likely to be found here.

chapters.name: Chapter 15 Antique Market
chapters.content:
Fatty possessed a family heirloom, a jade pendant that he always carried with him. This piece of jade was a gift from a commander of the Northwestern Field Army to his father. Back in the day, the commander led his troops into Xinjiang and eradicated a gang of bandits in the Niya Oasis. The jade had been on the person of one of the bandits. Though it was referred to as a jade pendant, its shape was hardly typical—its design was ancient and peculiar, engraved with a mishmash of patterns that resembled both a map and inscriptions, its true purpose unknown.

I had seen this jade numerous times, as my family had a collection of antiques, and I grew up listening to my grandfather share his extensive knowledge of gold. However, the age and value of this particular piece of jade eluded me.

Fatty had thought to sell the jade to raise some capital for business, but I stopped him. "This is a legacy from your father; don't sell it unless you absolutely must. We're not yet at our wit's end. If it really comes down to it, I can ask my family for money. After all, my grandparents have had their pensions nicely topped up."

We spotted an empty space by the roadside and parked our tricycle there, then bought two bowls of braised stuffed buns for lunch.

Braised stuffed buns consisted of a broth made from pig offal, filled with things like intestines and soaked with chopped-up baked wheaten cake. At a little over one yuan per bowl, it was both economical and filling.

I had added too much chili to my bowl, and it was so spicy that I was in tears, panting and sticking out my tongue.

After taking a couple of bites, Fatty said to me, "Old Hu, I had hoped to lead you to fortune these past few years, but now the national economy is thriving. The situation isn't just a little good—it's excellent. It's nothing like when I first started peddling, when there were only three places in all of Beijing selling pop music cassette tapes. I feel like I've dragged you down. Your father was a division commander before he retired and enjoys the benefits of a deputy municipal-level official. You might as well go back and have your old man pull some strings to get you a job in a government agency. There's no need for you to suffer with me."

I patted Fatty's belly and replied, "Brother, let me tell you something from the heart. If I really wanted a government agency job, I could get one at any time. But I'm afraid to. Do you know why? If I sit still in one place, I can't think of anything else—all I see are my deceased comrades-in-arms, haunting me. The sight of them nearly tears my guts apart. At least when we're running around busily with our small business, I can distract myself with other thoughts. Otherwise, I'd go mad."

Having spent so many years in the military, if I hadn't learned anything else, I had learned how to boost morale. I comforted Fatty, "We're not doing too badly now. Aren't we still able to enjoy braised buns? Just think back to the days in the Kunlun Mountains—that was real hardship. One Spring Festival, everyone was homesick, and many of the new recruits were crying in secret. The division commander couldn't stand for that and quickly arranged for everyone to make dumplings to improve the meal. You wouldn't believe what those dumplings were like. There were no vegetables in the Kunlun Mountains; they were more expensive than gold. We had plenty of meat, though, so the dumplings were all meat-filled. The altitude was so high that water wouldn't boil, and the dumplings came out half-cooked, with the meat inside still red. Can you imagine the taste? Despite that, I gobbled down seventy or eighty of them—I was so starved for cooked food, I almost burst. The next day, I had to be taken to the hospital; my stomach felt like it was lined with sheet metal. Do you remember what they said in 'Red Cliff'? 'The night before the revolution triumphs is the coldest.' Our business won't always be like this. If cassette tapes don't sell, we can sell something else. Just as the old man said, 'If Mount Lu is closed to us, then we'll climb the Jinggang Mountains. If the People's Liberation Army won't join me, I'll find the Red Army.'"

 I turned on the tape recorder, and instantly, the two loudspeakers began to emit music.

Due to the shabby condition of the recorder, the sound quality was terrible. Even the most beautiful songs played through it sounded like a broken gong.

But Fatty and I didn't find it unpleasant; it was, after all, better than either of us could sing. After my thorough and simple ideological education, Fatty's spirits had lifted, and he began to sway his legs to the rhythm of the music, belting out his sales pitch: "Come take a look, see for yourself, Hong Kong and Taiwan original versions, slashing arms and legs in a clearance sale, selling at a loss to earn a 'Yo He'!"

Passersby and the neighboring vendors cast curious glances our way. There was a man selling antiques on a street stall nearby. He came over to greet us with a smile, revealing a big gold tooth. The man with the Big Gold Tooth pulled out a pack of cigarettes and offered us a round.

Taking a cigarette, I noted: "Not bad at all, American cigarettes, Marlboro."

As Big Gold Tooth lit my cigarette, he said, "Gentlemen, selling pop songs at the Panjiayuan Flea Market, I bet no third person in this Four Nine City (Beijing) could've thought of that. You two are really something else."

I took a deep drag of the cigarette and exhaled two streams of white smoke through my nose. These American cigarettes really packed a punch. I looked up at Big Gold Tooth and said, "Don't tease us with that. We're just here to avoid the Bureau of Industry and Commerce. We'll leave after a short rest."

As it turned out, we weren't strangers after all. Big Gold Tooth was from Hainan Island, had been sent down to Yunnan in the past, and his father's generation had settled there during the People's Liberation Army's southern campaign. His family roots were all in the 'Three Wildernesses', and once you start talking about where your hometown is, which column and which unit of the army your elders belonged to, you find the connections aren't so distant.

 Big Gold Tooth's father wasn't any sort of official; he was a folk craftsman of grave robbing who was later conscripted during the Xuzhou-Bengbu Campaign, which is also known as the Huaihai Campaign. His unit defected and joined the People's Liberation Army, where he served as a cook. On the Korean battlefield, he suffered frostbite that left him permanently paralyzed. After the Reform and Opening-up, he moved from Hainan to Beijing and started a small business dealing in antique collectibles.

Talking is not as good as listening. He might dress it up with fancy terms like "craftsman of grave robbing," but isn't that just a euphemism for a grave-digging thief? Others might not catch on, but I was raised by my grandfather who often spoke of such matters.

An expert needs only to extend a hand to know what's there. Digging deeper, I asked Big Gold Tooth, "Did your old man ever unearth any significant 'zongzi' during his tomb raiding days?" The term 'zongzi' is a bit of covert lingo among tomb raiders, similar to how mountain bandits wouldn't outright admit to murder and arson but have their own slang or jargon. Here, a 'zongzi' refers to a corpse that is well-preserved and not decayed. Encountering a 'big zongzi' suggests running into trouble, like zombies or malevolent spirits. A 'dry zongzi' means the corpse has decayed to nothing but bones, while a 'meaty zongzi' indicates a body that still has valuable items on it.

At the mention of this, Big Gold Tooth immediately treated me with newfound respect and insisted on inviting Fatty and me to Dongsi for a mutton hot pot, with the intention of discussing further. So, the three of us gathered our things and set off for Dongsi together.

chapters.name: Chapter 16: Big Gold Tooth
chapters.content:
In a hotpot restaurant in Dongsi, Beijing, every table was occupied by diners, with steam from the bubbling pots filling the air. The sounds of the drinking game "Push Cup and Change Goblet," along with the merry cries of "One Five Drink Six," were ceaseless.

We found an empty table in a corner and sat down. Big Gold Tooth kept pouring me drinks, and I thought to myself that this fellow was probably trying to get me drunk to pry some secrets from me. So, I quickly stopped him, "Lord Jin, this Erguotou packs quite a punch. I'm a lightweight; I think I'll stick to beer."

As we ate and chatted, the conversation turned to the topic of grave robbing. Big Gold Tooth, flashing a grin that showcased his namesake, tapped his gold tooth and said to us, "Gentlemen, feast your eyes on this. I acquired this gold tooth at Panjiayuan. It was dug up from a grave, a Pre-Ming Buddha Lang Gold, plucked right out of the mouth of a rice dumpling. I couldn't bear to sell it, so I had my own tooth pulled and replaced it with this one."

It was quite something, discussing such matters over dinner, almost enough to put one off their food. If he was too stingy to spend money, why not just say so? The more I thought about what he said, the more disgusted I felt, so I quickly steered the conversation to other topics.

We chatted about various things, from the tricks of the trade in feng shui tomb assessments to the days spent as an engineer soldier on the Kunlun Mountains. Big Gold Tooth listened with such amazement that he couldn't help but express his utmost admiration for me.

Big Gold Tooth's father, before being conscripted by the Kuomintang, had apprenticed with a master grave robber from Hunan, surnamed Cai, and knew a great deal about the craft. However, he never learned the skills of locating graves, as his master, Mr. Cai, was not versed in the art of feng shui. It wasn't until after the twelfth year of the Republic of China that Farmer Li from Luoyang devised the Luoyang Shovel. Before its popularity, their faction relied mainly on their sense of smell, and to maintain the sensitivity of their noses, they abstained from tobacco, alcohol, and spicy foods.

They would drive an iron drill into the ground and then smell it upon extraction. The various scents that the iron drill brought up from the earth, along with the tactile feedback when drilling—whether the ground was hollow, or if there was wood, brick, or stone—these sensations were unmistakably different.

In essence, this method was not too dissimilar from using a Luoyang Shovel; the difference lay in using the nose instead of the eyes. The soil brought up by the Luoyang Shovel could be examined to determine the composition of the soil beneath. The presence of porcelain shards, wood fragments, cloth, mercury, lead, as well as rammed earth and bricks, were all indicators of a grave below. These clues could be used to deduce the era and structure of an underground ancient tomb.

 However, the craft of Wen Tu was lost when it reached Big Gold Tooth. His father was disabled in both legs, and he himself suffered from congenital asthma since childhood, so he gave up the tomb raiding business. Those who are in this line of work usually have seen their fair share of genuine artifacts and, with that bit of discernment, they start dealing in antiques.

I joked that his ancestral skills were rather trendy. I mentioned that I had heard from my elders about grave robbing. The real masters never used iron drills or Luoyang shovels; those were considered crude methods. A skilled individual could arrive at a site, take one look, and know whether there was an ancient tomb underground, its exact location, and its structure—all at a glance. Wherever the feng shui was exceptional, there was bound to be a large tomb. Those interred within were no ordinary people during their lifetimes, and such tombs were filled with treasures. A true expert would disdain the use of a Luoyang shovel, for if the soil wasn't dry enough, its effectiveness would be greatly reduced. Especially in the wealthy regions of the south, where rainfall is abundant and many ancient tombs are submerged by groundwater, the soil layers are thoroughly disrupted.

Big Gold Tooth was dazzled by my elaborate talk and held me in even higher esteem. "Master Hu, I am truly convinced. How does the saying go? 'Hearing the Way in the morning, one can die content in the evening.' After listening to your profound insights, I feel my life has not been lived in vain. To encounter someone like you, who understands both feng shui and has been an engineer soldier, with knowledge of civil engineering operations, is truly rare. It would be a pity for someone with your talents not to be a tomb raider."

I shook my head and said, "I have no intention of engaging in such immoral activities. What I've just told you are stories I heard from my grandfather, who was a tomb raider in his day. He once encountered a huge 'zongzi' (a euphemism for a dangerous encounter in a tomb) and nearly lost his life."

Big Gold Tooth acknowledged that the risks were indeed real, but with a few black donkey hooves, one need not fear. Moreover, as the saying goes, "Even thieves have principles." The reputation of grave robbing is tarnished, but that's due to some despicable petty thieves who aren't really from the trade. They have no understanding of the rules and wreak havoc wherever they go, which naturally incites hatred. If we were to trace the history of grave robbing, it would span over three thousand years. During the era of the Three Kingdoms, Cao Cao had a special unit under his command tasked with excavating ancient tombs for military provisions, which is how we came to have the term "tomb raider."

 Before liberation, the trade was divided into four schools of thought: east, south, west, and north. By the eighties, the talent had withered away, leaving only a few remaining practitioners, and even they had washed their hands in a golden basin, retiring from the trade. The younger generation now consists of idle country folk who band together to dig up graves and plunder tombs, completely ignorant of the professional ethics, the two taboos, and the ritual of three incenses and three bows. Much of the good stuff has been destroyed by their hands.

Big Gold Tooth sighed for a while, then turned to us and said, "I've been dealing in Panjiayuan for many years. If you two ever come across any treasures, I can help you find buyers. You handle the negotiations, and if a deal is struck, just give me a small commission."

Fatty, who had been preoccupied with eating and drinking, was nearly full when he suddenly remembered something. He took out a piece of jade he had on him and asked Big Gold Tooth to appraise it, to see how much it might be worth.

Big Gold Tooth examined it, sniffed it a few times, and said, "Fat Master, this is a fine piece of jade, at least a thousand years old, perhaps even dating back to before the Tang Dynasty. The script on it isn't Chinese—I can't make out what it is—but it's definitely valuable. However, I'd advise you not to sell it until its true value is ascertained; otherwise, you might suffer a great loss. Where did you come by this jade?"

Fatty, invigorated by the topic of his family history, began, "The origin is a long tale, akin to a child without a mother. To put it simply, this jade was given to my father by an old comrade-in-arms who participated in the Huangma Uprising. My father's comrade was the foremost senior officer in the field. When his troops entered Xinjiang, they encountered a gang of bandits. Those bandits were courting death; the guard corps from the People's Liberation Army's top leader is not to be trifled with. In less than five or six minutes, they had wiped out over a hundred bandits. When they were cleaning up the battlefield, they found this jade on the leader of the bandits. The top leader gifted it to my father as a memento. As for the history of the jade before that, I have no idea."

We continued drinking until past midnight before parting ways. As we said our farewells, Big Gold Tooth gave each of us a hook-shaped object. It was over an inch long, jet black and shiny, exceedingly hard, and bore two characters in seal script that looked like 'touch gold.' It appeared to be an ancient artifact, with one end drilled and strung with a red silk thread, suitable to be worn as a pendant. Big Gold Tooth said, "It's like we've been brothers from the first meeting. These amulets are made from pangolin claws. They're for you to keep as a memento. Come find me in Panjiayuan whenever you're free. As the green hills remain and the clear waters flow, we shall meet again."

chapters.name: Chapter 17: The Plan
chapters.content:
Fatty and I returned to the small flat we rented near Chongwenmen, drunk to the point of stupor, and slept straight through to the next afternoon.

Upon waking, as I lay in bed gazing at the low, squat ceiling, my thoughts were many. The trade of tomb raiding wasn't unfamiliar to me—I was confident in my ability to locate some grand mausoleums. Money wasn't of utmost importance to me; one could even say I couldn't care less about it. Yet life is full of contradictions, and now, I found myself in dire need of it.

My parents were state-supported; I had no familial burdens to shoulder. If I was fed, the whole family was content. But what of my brothers who had fallen on the battlefield? Who would care for their parents, cover the costs of their medical care and medications, or pay for their younger siblings' education? The meager consolation money they received was hardly enough to fend off the biting northwest winds.

On the battlefield, it seemed everyone had a reason they absolutely couldn't die—everyone except me. Yet, I was the survivor. My life was bought at the price of many comrades-in-arms. It was time I did something for them.

Fatty woke up too, rubbing his eyes. Seeing me staring blankly at the ceiling, he said, "Old Hu, I know what you're thinking without you saying it. The words of Big Gold Tooth yesterday stirred your heart, didn't they? I'm itching to act too. Just waiting on your word, brother."

I took out the amulet Big Gold Tooth had given us. "Don't regard that grandson as any sort of saint," I told Fatty. "He's in business for profit, up with the sun for a reason. This digging claw dates back to the time of Cao Cao, a warlord of the Three Kingdoms, worn by his tomb raiders. He wouldn't just gift us something so valuable without motive—he's seen our potential and wants a slice of the pie."

Fatty became agitated. "I knew he wasn't a good egg. I'll go to Panjiayuan later, rip out his big gold tooth and toss it into the outhouse."

Despite saying this, we both agreed that it might be wise to use each other to our mutual advantage, at least for the time being. A flaw in my character was impulsiveness, not thoroughly considering consequences. I felt the path of tomb raiding was viable, believing that everything in the world has two sides—a good deed could turn bad, and a bad deed could turn good. This was the dialectical method.

The tombs of emperors and generals were filled with countless treasures, but could one truly say these fine things belonged to the tomb masters? Weren't they all plundered from the common people? Appropriated from the populace, they should rightfully be used for the people's benefit. How could we let them eternally accompany dry bones sleeping underground? If one were to act, act grandly. The commoners' graves held little interest, mostly devoid of valuables, and taking from the people would damage one's yin virtue.

I remember my grandfather speaking of the rules of tomb raiders, quite distinct from those of common grave thieves. Grave thieves dug and grabbed without rhyme or reason, their deeds absolute, indifferent to whether the tombs belonged to loyal ministers, valiant generals, officials, or commoners. They had no rules to speak of, and what little they had were cobbled together by the peasants themselves, not amounting to much at all.

 Tomb raiders at work would always light a candle and place it in the southeast corner whenever they opened a large tomb and entered its underground chamber. Then, they would begin their task, prying open the coffin to seek treasure. The most valuable possessions of the deceased were often found on their person. Notably, those of princes and nobles, the masters of these tombs, were adorned with pearls in their mouths, bodies draped in gold and jade, with heart-protecting jade on their chests, and even their hands clutching jade Ruyi scepters. Some were so extravagant that even their anal cavities were stuffed with precious stones. At such a time, one must proceed without damaging the remains, gently feeling from the crown of the head to the soles of the feet, leaving behind one or two treasures for the deceased. During this process, if the candle in the southeast corner were to extinguish, one must return the acquired wealth to its original place, bow respectfully three times, and retreat along the same path they came.

The reason some ghosts are said to linger in these tombs, not entering into reincarnation for hundreds of years, remains a mystery. It is likely that they cannot part with the glory and riches of their former lives, watching over their treasures day after day. When one encounters such spirits, more attached to their wealth than to life itself, it is better not to forcefully rob them of their possessions.

Ultimately, Fatty and I decided, to hell with it, we would become full-fledged tomb raiders. As for any pangs of conscience, let's say our conscience was half-eaten by a dog. Or rather, let's view it from another perspective. It's the eighties now, isn't it? Isn't devotion being advocated? It's about time those princes and nobles who exploited the working people made their contribution. But these dead souls are not so enlightened; don't expect them to come forth and offer their treasures willingly. That's where we come in, to shake down these feudal overlords, to sweep up their golden pots and divide their fields and lands. We're truly busy with this task.

Having set our strategic direction, we still needed to carefully plan the specific tactical objectives and their implementation.

In the provinces of Henan, Hunan, and Shaanxi, where tomb raiding was most rampant, large tombs had become hard to find. Moreover, it was inconvenient to operate in crowded places, and one had to cover their activities with farming or building houses. The best option would be to head for the deep mountains and old forests, where few people ventured.

Speaking of large tombs I've encountered in deep mountains and old forests, the one on Ox Heart Mountain undoubtedly tops the list. I was too young and ignorant when I was sent "Up to the Mountains and Down to the Countryside," but judging with my current experience, that tomb must date from before the Northern Song Dynasty, likely from the flourishing Tang Dynasty period. It was fashionable then to use mountains as mausoleums, a trend that continued into the early Song Dynasty. After the Southern Song Dynasty, as the nation's power waned, no royal mausoleum dared to undertake such grand construction projects again.

 Fatty asked me, "Didn't you say that Ox Heart Mountain was haunted? Can't we find a place that isn't haunted to do our thing? We can handle the Bear Wild Man just fine, but if we come across ghosts, I wouldn't know how to deal with them."

I told him, firstly, there are no such things as ghosts in this world. What I told you last time might have been a hallucination of mine. Secondly, this is our first operation, and it's not absolutely necessary to start excavating mountains. Do you remember how many families in the village have antiques? Let's go collect a few and sell them. That would save us the trouble and effort.

That very day, we each prepared separately. Fatty went to dispose of the remaining cassette tapes, while I headed to the second-hand market to buy some essential tools: a flashlight, gloves, a face mask, candles, rope, a water bottle. What thrilled me the most was finding two German-made sapper's shovels. Holding the engineer soldier's shovel in my hand felt like meeting an old friend.

This type of engineer soldier's shovel was equipped by the German Mountain Assault Division during World War II. Many were seized by the Soviets, and during the period of Sino-Soviet Friendship, some made their way into Chinese territory. The German-made sapper's shovel is very portable, foldable to be hung at the waist, and the steel edge is superb. Not to mention digging through soil and rock, in times of danger, it can also be wielded as a weapon, capable of chopping off half an enemy's head with a single swing.

The only regret was not being able to buy a gas mask. During the nationwide civil defense efforts, many Model 60 gas masks were distributed among the populace, and they occasionally appear in the antique market. Unfortunately, I had no luck finding one today and had to leave it for another time. There were also a few other items missing, but those could wait until we reached Ganggang Camp.

In total, I spent over fifteen hundred, mainly because those two shovels were expensive—at six hundred apiece, the price was firm and wouldn't budge. In the end, I was left with only six yuan in my pocket, which was problematic—I didn't have enough money to buy a train ticket.

Thankfully, Fatty had managed to sell off the cassette tapes and had also terminated the lease on our rented room and sold the tricycle, which just about covered our round-trip expenses. We bought train tickets overnight. I was not yet eighteen when I left that place, and it had been over a decade since I'd been back. The thought of seeing the villagers I hadn't seen in so many years excited both of us.

chapters.name: Chapter 18: Black Wind Pass Wildman Gully
chapters.content:
Our train was scheduled for the next afternoon at two o'clock, and in our excitement, we spent a sleepless night. I asked Fatty how much money we had left. After counting, Fatty said there was only one hundred and fifty left—barely enough to cover our travel expenses and meals.

I thought to myself, that won't do. We haven't been home in over a decade. It would be highly inappropriate to show up empty-handed to see our folks. We needed to find a way to scrounge up some money to buy gifts for them.

Fatty suggested, "Why not sell this jade piece of mine for a good eight or nine hundred?"

I told him, "Better keep it. Don't always think about pawning off the few things your dad left you. Once sold, you can't get them back, and you might end up regretting it bitterly."

In the end, I dug out something of value. We had an Eagle Song brand mechanical watch, a limited edition piece given to me by my dad when I became a company commander. It was so rare that even money might not buy it, and it could fetch over two hundred on the market. I went to Panjiayuan and sold the watch to Big Gold Tooth, a guy who'd buy anything. When he heard we were heading to Inner Mongolia to try our luck, he even sponsored us with an extra hundred, agreeing to help us find buyers for whatever we might find.

Back in the eighties, three hundred yuan was enough for an ordinary family to live luxuriously for two or three months—it was a considerable sum. With this money, I bought plenty of food items—preserved fruits, milk candies, canned goods, chocolates, tea leaves—delicacies you couldn't find in the mountains. The remaining cash I exchanged entirely for national Food Ration Tickets on the black market.

The two-day-and-night journey felt long, filled with anticipation. After arriving at the station, there was still a day's tractor ride, followed by another day and night of trekking into the mountains.

Barely a day into the mountains, Fatty and I could go no further. The burden was too heavy; each of us was carrying over a hundred pounds. I gritted my teeth and pressed on, but Fatty was truly spent. He sat under a big tree, gasping for air, unable to utter a word.

Thankfully, we ran into an accountant coming out of the village for business. Back when we joined the commune, he was just a kid, always trailing behind us and calling us 'brother.' Seeing our heavy luggage, he hurried back to the village and brought back a few folks with donkeys to help us. Among them were some elders we recognized, and two girls around twelve or thirteen, born after I had left. They awkwardly called me 'uncle.'

I asked the accountant, "Why aren't there any young men in the village?"

He explained, "All the able-bodied men from the village have gone to work with the Archaeological Team. Remember the Tangshan earthquake in '76? Though it happened far from here, we're on the same earthquake belt. That quake cracked open Ox Heart Mountain in Lama Gully, revealing a palace-like large tomb inside. Many of the braver souls from our village went in to grab what they could. There were treasures aplenty. Somehow, the county government got wind of it, and the Archaeological Team arrived soon after. They claimed it was the mausoleum of Empress Dowager Xiao of the Liao dynasty, and they confiscated all the valuable items from our homes, not leaving a single piece behind. Since then, the Archaeological Team hasn't done much with Ox Heart Mountain, saying there's still much more to unearth beneath it. They've hired all our village laborers, providing food and lodging, plus three yuan a day. It's been several years and the work still isn't finished. Many are still employed there."

 Fatty and I nearly choked on our own blood when we heard these words. The audacity to think they could outmaneuver us at our own game, as if even the Buddha himself would fall from grace.

But there was little we could do. It wasn't as if we could just go and wrestle with the Archaeological Team or the Cultural Relics Bureau for their turf. Since we were here, we might as well enjoy ourselves for a few days before finding another spot. After all, it's not like Ox Heart Mountain was the only ancient tomb around.

As we approached the village, the news of our arrival had already reached the villagers who were waiting at their doorsteps. They crowded around us, firing questions, as Yanzi, leading her daughter by the hand, cried and said to us, "Oh, Old Hu and Fatty, we've missed you so much. Why haven't we heard from you in all these years?" Yanzi's father hugged us both tightly, "You two rascals, vanishing without a trace. This time, you're not leaving unless you stay for at least two or three years. No one's allowed to leave."

Fatty and I were both moved to tears. Fatty had lived here for six or seven years, and I for one, but the mountain folk were sincere. Once you've lived among them, they treat you as one of their own forever. Everything was just as it had been before, unchanged. There was no electricity, no roads. Many here had never seen an electric light in their lives. The more I thought about it, the sadder I felt. I resolved that once I had the money, I would definitely build a road for the villagers. But when would we ever have that kind of money?

At that moment, the village's old Branch Secretary, supported by others, made his way toward us. Before he even reached us, he called out loudly, "The Chairman's children have returned! How is the Chairman doing now? How did he fare during the Cultural Revolution?"

I was puzzled by his words. How would I know how the Chairman was doing? I hurried forward to support the old Branch Secretary's arm and said, "He's resting well, lying in the mausoleum every day. Anyone who misses him can buy a ticket to go see him. The Cultural Revolution has long ended. Now, Comrade Xiaoping is leading us all in the Reform and Opening-up."

It seemed as though the old Branch Secretary hadn't heard a word I said. He craned his neck and shouted, "Comrade Ming, what is he up to?"

Yanzi whispered to me, "Don't mind what he says. Who knows what he's getting at. He's been deaf since '73 and can't hear much. Plus, he's always a bit confused."

Then it dawned on me, and I leaned in close to the Branch Secretary's ear and said loudly, "Branch Secretary, I've brought you lots of tasty treats. I'll bring them over to you in a bit. Take your time and enjoy them."

 As they talked, the group entered the village. The old Branch Secretary was still shouting from behind: "Children, when you return, report to the elder that we resolutely support the Proletarian Cultural Revolution and will follow through with whatever is required."

That evening, the table on Yanzi's kang, a traditional Chinese bed-stove, was laden with stir-fried pheasant slices and smoked deer leg, with a large clay pot in the center simmering sour cabbage and white meat. Yanzi's husband, who was well acquainted with us, hadn't returned from working in Ox Heart Mountain, so we couldn't meet him for the time being.

While drinking with us, Yanzi's father joined in the conversation. I brought up the matter of the ancient tomb at Ox Heart Mountain and casually inquired if there were any more tombs of ancient nobility hidden within these great mountains.

For ages, the mountain folk had seen tomb raiding as a way to supplement their income, with no moral qualms. It was the same in the north; in the southern regions of Xiangxi, robbery and murder were treated as a side business. The mountain people would farm by day and turn bandit by night, hiding in the woods and exclusively targeting foreign merchants passing through, leaving no survivors. This was a survival tactic honed over thousands of years, living off the land and water. In areas of poverty and harsh terrain, ancient tombs and passing travelers became their sustenance. If there was a tomb nearby, there would surely be someone to unearth it. In these remote areas, where the emperor's reach was weak and the law held little sway, such practices were commonplace, even if they couldn't be justified legally. Most of the ancient tombs nearby were too old, their markers lost to the changing landscape; otherwise, the locals would have plundered them long ago.

Yanzi's father recounted that before liberation, there were a few young amateur tomb raiders in the village. At that time, they were unaware of the tomb at Ox Heart Mountain and set out for a fabled place rumored to have gold-filled graves. Whatever they encountered remains unknown, as none returned, including Yanzi's second uncle. Yanzi's father knew the approximate location of this legendary site but had never dared to venture there himself.

As the old man delved into the past, he lit his Yabuli pipe and took a few pensive puffs. After a long silence, he spoke: "If you're seeking ancient tombs, there are none nearby other than at Ox Heart Mountain. According to old tales, if you head north from here through Tuanshanzi and into the mountains for a five-day journey, you'll reach Black Wind Pass at the Sino-Mongolian Border. There lies Wildman Gully, which is said to be filled with the graves of princes and nobles, rich with gold. However, that place is seldom visited by humans and is rumored to be haunted by wild men. Do you have the courage to go?"

I had heard of Wildman Gully before, but not of any tombs there. What exactly had befallen the last group of tomb raiders, no one knew—not me, not Yanzi's father, and not anyone else in the village.

 Deep in the mountain forest, dangers abound—feral beasts of all kinds, and even the capricious weather and natural environment can claim a person's life. Should one encounter an opium den and be engulfed within, even the most divine immortals could not escape.

Our resolve to go was firm, and not even Swallow's father could dissuade us. No one in the village had truly ventured to Black Wind Pass or Wildman Gully; we only knew their approximate locations. Since these places were near the border and devoid of human habitation, the villagers, even those who went hunting or foraging in the mountains, never ventured so far. Moreover, Swallow's father was advanced in years and suffered from chronic leg pain, which prevented him from entering the mountains. Swallow herself was pregnant with her second child and couldn't travel far. The young and able-bodied men of the village were all working in Lama Gully and wouldn't return for some time.

Swallow's father said, "I'll always be worried if I don't lead you there myself. The danger in Wildman Gully doesn't come from any wild man; it's the complex terrain that's the real threat. Come winter, the fierce blizzards make it easy to lose one's way. But now, in early autumn, that's not a concern. If you must go, be sure to take plenty of dogs and find a reliable guide. Our village has raised several Tibetan Mastiffs in recent years, and you should take them with you."

The term 'mastiff' does not refer solely to the Tibetan Mastiff; in the northeast, any large and ferocious dog is called a Tibetan Mastiff, which is not exactly the same as the ones from Tibet.

Hunters and herders living in the northern grasslands and forests, threatened by wolves and black bears, find ordinary hunting dogs insufficient. They have adopted the Tibetan method of raising mastiffs to breed Tibetan Mastiffs. There's a saying: "nine dogs, one mastiff," which doesn't mean that out of nine dogs, one will be a mastiff. It requires a female of excellent lineage to give birth to a litter of nine puppies, which are then confined to a pit from birth, without food or drink, left to fight each other. The sole survivor, tempered by this brutal selection, is deemed a mastiff. With a nature fiercely aggressive, three Tibetan Mastiffs are capable of tearing a strong human bear to shreds.

Our village had a total of three mastiffs, and along with five of the finest hunting dogs, they were all entrusted to us. Swallow's father also recommended a guide to us, Yingzi.

At just nineteen, Yingzi, a rare member of the Oroqen ethnicity within the village, was an exceptional hunter among the younger generation. Known throughout the great mountains as a sharpshooter, her youth belied her experience; she had hunted in the forest with her father since she was a child. There was nothing about the Old Forest she didn't know, and of the village's three Tibetan Mastiffs, two were raised by her own hand.

 Before setting out, I had Yanzi help me prepare a few things: a birdcage, glutinous rice, black donkey hoof, a crowbar, a large barrel of vinegar, and some strong liquor.

Once everything was packed and ready, Yanzi’s father, laden with endless reminders and cautions, insisted that if the search proved fruitless, I shouldn't force it. He urged me to return swiftly and only stopped escorting us when we reached the entrance of Tuanshanzi.

I was fairly confident in my ability to locate ancient tombs, especially if I managed to reach Wildman Gully. Whether or not there were any tombs to be found, if they existed, I was certain I could uncover them. My knowledge of tomb raiding was partly gleaned from books and largely from stories told by my grandfather, Hu Guohua, who had served as an officer in the old warlord's army. Some of his soldiers had once been under the command of Sun Dianying, a notorious tomb raider of the Eastern Tombs, and had participated in several large-scale tomb raiding operations. Their experiences were vast, and it was from their accounts that my grandfather had learned much.

Historically, tomb raiding fell into two categories: official and civilian. Official raiders operated openly, targeting imperial mausoleums. Xiang Yu, the Hegemon-King of Western Chu at the end of the Qin Dynasty, could be considered the forefather of official raiding. During the Three Kingdoms period, the so-called Tomb Raider armies merely systematized this official plundering into an assembly line operation. Among civilians, there were amateurs and professionals—the former would dig up anything they came across, while the latter specifically sought the graves of nobles and princes, disdaining smaller finds.

The key to tomb raiding lay in the ability to locate ancient tombs, a profound discipline in its own right. With thousands of years of dynastic changes in China, the construction and site selection of imperial mausoleums varied greatly. During the Qin and Han dynasties, the trend was to build inverted-cone-shaped burials, with the mound shaped like an inverted measuring cup, its edges clearly defined, and a small square platform at the peak. Some resembled the pyramids of Egypt, albeit with an additional side, and were astonishingly similar to the pyramids of the lost Maya civilization in South America. The connection between these, however, remained a mystery.

In the Tang Dynasty, mausoleums were carved out of mountains, reflecting the monumental scale and majestic spirit of the era, which corresponded with the great national strength of the prosperous Tang Empire. The royal tombs of the Tang Dynasty exuded an air of imperial supremacy, as if declaring, "Who else but I should be considered the foremost under heaven?"

From the Southern Song Dynasty until the early Qing, China faced incessant warfare and some of the greatest natural disasters in its ancient history. With the nation's power weakened, the scale of the mausoleums for princes and nobles was no longer as extravagant as before.

Later, during the Kangxi and Qianlong periods of the Qing Dynasty, the nation's economy and productivity greatly recovered. The architectural style of the mausoleums underwent a change, emphasizing above-ground structures and integrating them with ancestral temples and garden landscapes. Drawing on the anti-theft experiences of previous dynasties, the construction of underground palace tomb chambers in the Qing Dynasty was exceptionally sturdy, making them exceedingly difficult to breach.

 Ultimately, regardless of the era, the burial customs that have persisted throughout China's millennia-spanning history all stem from the intricate layouts derived from the sixty-four hexagrams of Fuxi, intertwined with the Five Elements and Feng Shui. Despite endless variations, they never stray from their essence, all aiming to capture the world's geomantic advantage. At their core, they pursue an eight-character maxim: within the workings of nature, humanity and the cosmos are one.

This mortuary culture encapsulates the quintessence of Chinese civilization. Various ethnic groups such as the Mongols, Huihu, Tubo, Jurchen, Xianbei, She people, Dangxiang, and others have been greatly influenced by it. The layouts of their mausoleums often imitate those of the Central Plains, yet most only manage to grasp the superficial aspects. It can be said that anyone who understands how to read the veins of the world's mountains and rivers can effortlessly locate even the most hidden ancient tombs.

Moving forward, an endless expanse of primeval forest unfolds. Yingzi, leading with eight large dogs, clears the path ahead, while Fatty, leading a stout horse laden with tents and various supplies, follows. I bring up the rear, carrying a hunting rifle as we all enter the towering mountains of the Sino-Mongolian Border.

As we trek, Fatty inquires of Yingzi ahead: "Big sister, what's the deal with the Wild Man of Wildman Gully? What exactly is a Wild Man? Have you ever seen one?"

Yingzi glances back and replies, "I don't really know what a Wild Man is. I've heard from my father that many have seen one over the years, but no one has ever caught one alive, nor have they found a body. Those who have seen it can't clearly describe what it looked like."

From behind, I laugh and say, "Fatty, you're truly uncultured. As the name implies, a Wild Man is a person who's wild by nature. You should study more. Do you know what a wild person is? It's someone born in the wild, perhaps from a tree or grown from the ground, but definitely not man-made."

The Wild Man is shrouded in mystery. The legend of the Wild Man of Shennongjia has been around for a long time. I heard about it while in the army; it's said that a People's Liberation Army soldier once shot and killed a Wild Man there. The body of the Wild Man fell off a cliff, and in the end, it remained unclear whether the Wild Man was human or just a large, hairy monkey. Nearly all eyewitnesses who have seen a Wild Man insist that it is tall and strong, covered in fine, black hair.

Listening to Yingzi's story, we learn that the Wildman Gully at Black Wind Pass wasn't always called that. It used to be known as Dead Man's Gully, and even earlier, it was called Moon Cradling Gully. It has long been a burial ground for the nobility of the Great Jin dynasty. Later, when the Mongol forces decisively defeated the main army of the Jin at Black Wind Pass, the bodies piled up like mountains. The Mongols threw the dead into the gully, nearly filling the entire valley, which led the locals to call it Dead Man's Gully. Over time, sightings of the Wild Man near this valley led to the name being replaced by Wildman Gully.

 There's nothing to fear from the Wild Man; how could it possibly be more formidable than a Tibetan Mastiff? Suddenly, a thought crossed my mind: I wonder how much a Wild Man would fetch on the market. But then I reconsidered, realizing that such an idea was inhumane. It would be better to focus on tomb raiding—that was a more legitimate pursuit.

Traveling with horses meant we couldn't navigate steep slopes, so we often had to take detours around large mountains. Our journey was slow, but the autumnal primeval forest was a feast for the eyes, with its resplendent scenery of red and yellow leaves blanketing the hillsides in a rich tapestry of color that never failed to captivate. Occasionally, we would spot pheasants, hares, roe deer, and wild boars darting out from the depths of the woods. Yingzi would then release the dogs to give chase. By nightfall, we would set up camp, gather wild herbs and spices from the mountains, and light a campfire to grill our catch. Both Fatty and I relished these meals, never once repeating the same wild game dish.

Navigating through these mountains without hunting dogs meant resigning oneself to sleeping in the trees. But with three Giant Mastiffs and five Large Hunting Dogs, our pack was a formidable force in the forest, unmatched unless we encountered more than three Human Bears. Yingzi said that the mastiffs were the bane of Human Bears, which would immediately keep their distance upon hearing the dogs' barks. So, we slept in tents at night, with our loyal hunting dogs standing guard around us. There was nothing to worry about; these dogs were far more reliable than people.

Yingzi's temperament was far fiercer than that of a young swallow, as fiery as a hot pepper. Whether it was choosing our path or deciding what to eat, we had to follow her lead—after all, she was our guide. Even the dogs heeded her commands. Although I was accustomed to being a Company Commander, in her presence, I had to swallow my pride and become just another soldier.

But Yingzi truly had skills. Whether it was hunting, finding paths, locating springs, or distinguishing poisonous mushrooms in the deep mountains, she knew it all. She could find wood ear mushrooms, hazelnuts, persimmons, codonopsis, schisandra berries, and more with ease. There was nothing she didn't know. She could even identify animals I had never seen or heard of in my life, explaining their habitats, diets, and how to capture them with specific traps. Fatty and I could only look at each other in amazement and concede with two words: Impressive.

The Oroqen people, to which she belonged, were born hunters. "Oroqen" is the official name given to this ethnic group, though it's not entirely accurate. Sometimes they refer to themselves as "Elunchun" or "Olu'enchun," which means "deer-hunting people wandering through forests and mountains." They have roamed the forests of the Lesser Khingan Range for years, living a nomadic life of fishing and hunting. When China was first liberated, there were less than a thousand Oroqen people left. The government resettled them from the harsh living conditions of the Deep Mountain Old Forest to a more sedentary lifestyle. However, the people held a near-deification reverence and longing for the nomadic hunting life of their ancestors. They worshipped Shamanism and venerated nature. Even though they had settled down, they would still frequently venture into the mountains to hunt.

 Throughout the journey, we exchanged few words, keeping our conversations brief. For six or seven days, we trekked through the primordial forest, finally reaching the Black Wind Pass at the Sino-Mongolian Border. The density of the forest at Black Wind Pass is indescribable; in its depths, there is scarcely a place to stand firm. The forest is dominated by cold-resistant species such as red pine, larch, birch, and poplar. The ground is layered with fallen branches and leaves, each step sinking into the detritus. For humans, it's manageable, but the horses, with their significant weight, frequently get stuck, unable to move. We had no choice but to exert all our strength, pulling and dragging them along, inching our way forward.

Who knows how many years it's been for the layers beneath us, with rotting foliage and carcasses of wild animals emitting waves of putrid odor. This foul stench, mingling with the scent of red pine and wildflowers, creates a peculiar aroma—unpleasant at first, yet strangely addictive over time.

Upon arrival at Black Wind Pass, the rest was up to me. We found a valley that must have been the legendary Wildman Gully. At first glance, it lacked the fierce appearance of Lama Gully, but this was merely a superficial impression. Yingzi cautioned that the valley might contain opium dens, insisting we must be absolutely certain before descending. Falling into an opium den would mean no escape. To venture into Wildman Gully, each of us needed to prepare a large wooden stick to probe the path ahead; the layer of fallen leaves was deeper than any marshland. Fortunately, it wasn't the rainy season, or the descent would have been impossible.

Wildman Gully is an offshoot of the Greater Khingan Range, flanked by gently sloping mountains. The valley runs north to south, with hills on both the east and west. The central area receives very little sunlight throughout the year, casting a gloomy pall over the space. The valley floor is filled with decaying leaves and wild grass, and apart from some sparse, low shrubs, no trees grow here. Beyond the valley, the trees grow even sparser, marking the end of the primeval forest. Two hundred li further lies the vast Mongolian grasslands.

As dusk approached, the blood-red sun hung on the horizon. We climbed a hillside and looked out to see the setting sun about to sink, the sky streaked with swathes of crimson clouds, as if painted with thick oils. The forest-covered mountains and the endless grasslands in the distance all blurred into a hazy vista. It was a scene of mountains vast as seas, with the dying sun like spilt blood.

Fatty, beholding this magnificent view, felt an immense joy: "Old Hu, this scenery is too beautiful. Our journey has not been in vain."

My mind, however, was preoccupied with the ancient tomb in Wildman Gully. I carefully examined the valley's topography, comparing it with the Sixteen-Character Yin-Yang Feng Shui Secret Technique, and took out my compass to discern the Eight Trigrams. In my heart, I whispered a secret passage: "At last, we've found the right place. There must be a noble's ancient tomb hidden in this valley."

 Wildman Gully, formerly known as Moon Cradling Ravine, is a place where the terrain exudes a stately and majestic presence, as if it could swallow the universe whole. One end borders the grasslands, while the other connects to the Greater Khingan Range. The vast Mongolian grasslands stretch out like an endless ocean, and Moon Cradling Ravine is like a mighty river flowing into this sea.

Though the geomantic elegance of this place might not befit the burial of emperors, it's more than sufficient for princes and high-ranking generals. When the moon reaches its zenith, its light will reveal the location of ancient tombs.

As evening approaches, the sun gradually sinks below the western horizon, and the great forest is on the brink of being devoured by shadows. This place was once called Moon Cradling Ravine because when the moon rises directly above the valley, if you lie on your back at the deepest point and look up at the sky, the peripheral vision creates an illusion. The highest hills on either side appear as two enormous arms, reaching up towards the bright moon. The deceased here are believed to be embraced by the essence and auspicious energy of the sun and moon, as detailed in a chapter of my ancestral book on geomancy. Although some of the text is obscure, it's not difficult to infer the general idea with on-site observation.

If Wildman Gully were not covered with a thick layer of dead leaves and rotting grass, we could easily find the central point. But now, we must wait for the moon to rise at night, using its position in the sky as a reference to find the ancient tomb at the valley's deepest point. Our manpower is limited, and we cannot afford any deviation during our work, or the scale of the project would be overwhelming.

With midnight still some time away, we pitch our tent under a large tree on the hillside, tether our pony to the tree, feed it fodder, light a bonfire to boil water for dinner. Tonight's game is a young deer caught by the hunting dogs, an odd-looking creature with piebald spots, uneven in size, with unusually thick hind legs, large ears, and no antlers, likely a doe.

Yingzi rushes over when she sees the dogs dragging this strange deer, quickly flipping the deer over to inspect its belly, which is smeared with fresh blood. She pries open the deer's mouth as if searching for something, but ultimately finds nothing. Frustrated, she kicks the deer's body hard twice and scolds the large hunting dogs: "You useless creatures, all you know is to eat, can't count on you for anything. None of you gets to eat today."

Fatty watches in curiosity and asks Yingzi, "Big sister, what are you looking for?"

Yingzi, while skinning the deer with a sharp knife, answers Fatty's question: "Fatty, you've never seen this animal before, have you? This is a musk deer. Inside the navel of a female musk deer, there's musk. Goodness, it's worth a fortune. But these creatures are cunning thieves. As soon as they see someone coming to catch them, they'll bite off their own navel first, chew it to a pulp. Damn it all," she curses, "if these dogs had been a bit faster, we could have gotten a piece of musk."

 After hearing this, Fatty sat down against a large tree, his head bowed and back bent, pressing down on his belly over and over with force.

I slapped his head: "What on earth are you thinking? Do you fancy yourself a deer, able to nibble at your own belly button? Besides, your navel's full of dirt, it's worthless."

Fatty became anxious: "Nonsense, my back is itchy. I'm just rubbing it against the tree. You're the one acting like you want to bite your own belly button."

After a few rounds of banter, we split up to take care of our tasks—I went to gather dry firewood, and Fatty went to help Yingzi roast the meat.
