We only needed to roast one of the musk deer's hind legs to have enough to eat; we fed its innards to the five big hunting dogs. Yingzi, with her sharp tongue but a soft heart, had earlier declared she wouldn't feed the dogs dinner, yet now she worried they wouldn't have enough to eat.

The other three giant mastiffs sat proudly at a distance, not even deigning to glance at the common hunting dogs fighting over the animal's entrails. Yingzi gave the musk deer's two front legs to two Tibetan Mastiffs and one of the hind legs to the largest Giant Mastiff named Tiger.

The three of us gathered around the campfire to eat the roasted meat. Yingzi provided each of us with a small knife and a little bowl made of rock salt. The deer leg was turned over the flames to roast, and we sliced it piece by piece with our knives, rubbing it in the bowl to give it a salty flavor. The meal was consumed quickly; my mind preoccupied with the ancient tomb in the gully, I couldn't even discern the difference in taste between the musk deer's meat and that of ordinary deer.

After the meal, the moon had risen, and by its light, we could see the clouds moving swiftly overhead—a sign that strong winds would come at night. Seeing that the time was about right, we left the hunting dogs to guard the camp and the three of us, each armed with a wooden stick and a hunting rifle, descended into Wildman Gully.

With every step forward, we plunged the wooden sticks into the ground ahead to check for opium traps. The conditions at the bottom of Wildman Gully were much better than we had anticipated. Although in some places the fallen leaves were as thick as one's thigh, there was no swamp formed by opium-soaked leaves that had been drenched and rotted by rainwater. It seemed that if we wanted to excavate the ancient tomb, we would first need to clear away the leaves covering it.

I looked up at the moon, took out my compass for comparison, and surveyed both sides of the valley. Finally, I determined the location—the valley likely contained many ancient tombs, but the most significant one, belonging to a noble of high status, was right beneath where we stood.

I planted a wooden stake there as a marker. We would return to get a good night's sleep and come back early the next morning with renewed energy to start the excavation. In this deep mountain old forest, with no other people for hundreds of miles around, there was no need to sneak around and work at night.

 As I made my way back, I regaled Fatty with tales of tomb raiding. Anyone involved in this business ought to be well-versed in such matters; it's not enough to rely solely on brute force and dig blindly. Ever since we ventured into the mountains, I've been ceaselessly educating him.

In China, the earliest recorded incidents of tomb raiding date back roughly three thousand years to the Zhou Dynasty—a time of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors, spanning the Xia, Shang, and Zhou periods. This era was further divided into the Western and Eastern Zhou. It's the same dynasty upheld by the likes of Jiang Taigong in "Investiture of the Gods," where phoenixes cried on Mount Qi. With a foundation lasting over eight hundred years, two major tomb raiding events from that epoch stood out: one was the looting of King You of Zhou's tomb, the other was the desecration of King Tang of Shang's grave. In King You's tomb, raiders found two exquisitely preserved young male and female corpses, frightening them into a hasty retreat. Meanwhile, King Tang's tomb yielded a large tortoise shell inscribed with oracle bone script.

Fatty interjected, "Old Hu, quit bothering me with this irrelevant stuff. Just tell me if there are ghosts in the tombs. If there are, how do we deal with them? And what about that 'Ghost Blows Out the Light' you mentioned last time? It sounds so sinister."

Yingzi asked, "What's this 'Ghost Blows Out the Light'? Is it that thing from the Northeast where the ghost extinguishes the light?"

I clarified, "It's not the Northeastern superstition but a belief among tomb raiders. It might not be entirely useless, though. Poor air quality in a tomb chamber could mean certain death from poisoning if a candle won't stay lit, and that's something that can be explained scientifically. Besides, how could there be ghosts in ancient tombs? Those are just superstitious tales. Even if there were, we needn't worry—I've prepared black donkey hooves, glutinous rice, and other such items to ward off evil. In short, when it comes to tomb raiding, don't fall for superstitions. If you're afraid of ghosts, you shouldn't be tomb raiding."

Fatty had an epiphany, "So that's it! You had Yingzi prepare all these things for exorcism. I thought you were just acting tough, not afraid of ghosts at all. By the way, what are the vinegar and birdcage for?"

Before I could answer, a cacophony of hounds barking wildly echoed up the slope. We all felt a sinking feeling in our hearts, fearing that some wild man or beast might be attacking our camp. But with three giant mastiffs there, not even the most daring creature, emboldened with the heart of a bear and the gall of a leopard, should dare cause trouble. What could possibly be setting the hunting dogs off? We quickened our pace, rushing back up the slope.

Upon reaching the tent, a gruesome scene unfolded before us. The pony tethered to the tree had been savagely mauled by some ferocious beast; its belly was torn open, its intestines spilled out onto the ground. The pony was not yet dead, convulsing on the ground, though its fate was sealed.

The hounds circled the dying pony, barking furiously as if they had witnessed some horrifying spectacle. Their cries were filled with a restless agitation.

 Ordinarily, horses and dogs are friends, so it was unthinkable that a dog would have bitten the pony's intestines. What sort of beast could have done this? Three heads of Giant Mastiffs and five hounds circled nearby, yet they failed to catch the perpetrator.

Looking around, there was no sign of any wild beast, only the silent mountains, the night wind rustling the leaves in the forest, causing cold sweat to drench our palms as we gripped our hunting rifles.

Blood frothed from the horse's mouth, and steam still rose from its nostrils. Though its intestines had spilled out onto the ground, it struggled for breath for quite some time. Yingzi aimed at the horse's head and fired a shot, ending its pre-death agony.

Suddenly, I noticed the horse's intestines moving, not in a post-mortem reflex, but as if something was pulling them underground. Whatever was tugging at the pony's innards was hiding beneath the carcass.

I quickly pulled Yingzi back a step. Fatty and Yingzi had also seen what had just happened. We exchanged glances, all thinking the same thing: could it be the work of a Wild Man?

Being in Wildman Gully, the first suspect was naturally the Wild Man. But did a Wild Man possess the strength to tear open a horse's belly? Perhaps it used a weapon, but if it had the skills to craft a weapon, it wouldn't be a Wild Man. It seemed the hypothesis of the Wild Man's involvement was untenable.

Before we could figure it out, the intestines were completely pulled under the horse. The situation beneath the carcass was entirely obscured from view.

We needed to move the horse's body. I weighed the hunting rifle in my hand; this gun was far more advanced than the old musket I had used more than a decade ago in Lama Gully to hunt a Human Bear. However, this sporting rifle had too small a caliber to be lethal to large predators. Nonetheless, in such a situation, having it was better than nothing—it certainly beat a fire-poking stick.

Armed with rifles and dogs, we felt somewhat reassured. Together, we pushed the horse's body aside, revealing a deep hole in the ground, hidden by the grass, with a diameter as wide as a small bucket.

The hole was too narrow for an adult to crawl through. It was into this hole that something had dragged the pony's intestines. When we had first arrived, the hole had been concealed by grass, which is why we had tethered the horse nearby. While we were searching for ancient tombs in the valley below, the creature in the hole had suddenly attacked, tearing open the horse's belly. Although the hounds were fiercely unmatched, they could do nothing as the carcass blocked the entrance, barking in frantic helplessness.

Shining a flashlight down the hole, it was pitch-black, its depth unknown. Observing the marks on the walls of the hole, my experience as an Engineer Soldier for over three years came into play. I was almost certain that the hole was not man-made but dug by some animal with sharp claws—a skilled burrower—otherwise, it couldn't have ripped open the pony's abdomen so effortlessly. But what kind of animal it was, I truly couldn't fathom. Even Yingzi, who knew the forest like the back of his hand, shook his head in bewilderment, having never seen nor heard of such a creature.

 I suspect there are other entrances nearby. Wildman Gully may seem tranquil and scenic, but it conceals deadly dangers. No wonder the team that came tomb raiding here decades ago vanished without a trace. Perhaps they too encountered these savage subterranean beasts.

It's unwise to linger here. We've decided not to wait for dawn and to move out at night instead. We split into two groups: Fatty and I, with five hunting dogs, headed down to the valley to excavate tombs, while Yingzi, accompanied by three giant mastiffs, searched nearby for the creature that attacked us. No matter how formidable it may be, it couldn't surpass the ferocity of the three mastiffs. Better to strike first than to wait defensively. Should either group encounter trouble, we'd fire a shot to alert the other, who would rush to provide support.

Fatty led the pack of hounds while I carried tools and other necessities. We descended into the valley, following the path we had scouted earlier.

I took out two engineer soldier shovels, kept one, and tossed the other to Fatty. "Hurry up with the work, Fatty. It's not wise to dig deep here. The ancient tomb beneath the layer of fallen leaves won't be too deep. The sooner we find the antiques, the better. Then we can leave this haunted place and go home, sell them, and build a road for our fellow villagers."

Fatty spat on his hands: "Watch the master at work."

His German-made sapper's shovel flew up and down, each thrust dislodging a large clump of the mire formed by dead branches and fallen leaves.

Although there weren't many trees in Wildman Gully, the wind would blow leaves from the surrounding mountains into the valley, accumulating over the years into a substantial layer. We took turns digging, reaching a depth of six or seven meters, until we finally saw soil. I grabbed a handful; it was fine-grained, without any clumps, and tasted slightly sweet when I tested it with the tip of my tongue. There was no mistake—it was a burial mound, and just four or five meters down would be the tomb chamber.

One must be cautious when nearing the tomb chamber, for some tombs have theft prevention mechanisms. The ancient tombs from the Northern Song Dynasty and the Liao and Jin periods didn't use the simple traps like falling rock traps common before the Tang Dynasty. By the Northern Song Dynasty, anti-theft technology had matured, especially in the tombs of the nobility. They couldn't undertake projects as grandiose as the imperial tombs, and the manpower they could mobilize was limited. But relatively speaking, the contents were by no means inferior; otherwise, they wouldn't match the feng shui treasure land they occupied.

An ancient tomb from the Late Northern Song Dynasty of the Jin people, like this one, would likely use the popular anti-theft technology of the time: the Tianbao dragon fire glazed tile roof. This structure's craftsmanship was highly advanced. The tomb chamber was hollow, with a layer of ultra-thin glazed tiles on the ceiling, each tile holding bags of Western Region Fire Dragon Oil. Another layer of glazed tiles was placed on top, followed by the burial mound. Any external force would break the fragile ceiling, the Fire Dragon Oil would ignite upon contact with air, and the flames would incinerate everything inside the tomb chamber—bones, burial artifacts—leaving nothing for the tomb raiders.

 Of course, this was a measure of last resort. The Tomb Master would rather die than let the tomb raiders desecrate his remains. This sort of government agency was only briefly popular during the late Northern Song Dynasty, in the Jin-Liao period. Eventually, it was supplanted by more advanced agencies, and the Tianbao Dragon Fire Glazed Tile Roof became obsolete.

Such a minor agency could not escape my notice. Its greatest weakness lies in the fact that if you dig from the side, the dragon fire glazed tiles on top won't break. Hence, once we reached the burial mound, we shifted to digging deeply on the side. The two of us worked feverishly, not knowing the meaning of fatigue, and eventually dug a large pit some six or seven meters deep.

Unwittingly, daylight had already broken. Yingzi returned to say she found nothing nearby and went into the woods to prepare lunch, promising to send a dog to call us when the meal was ready.

After Yingzi left, we continued our work and finally hit a layer of hard soil, as solid as rock. When the engineer soldier's shovel struck it, only a white mark appeared.

Fatty cursed, "What the hell, is that cement? If I'd known, we would have brought some explosives. Keep digging."

I replied, "Explosives are for the crude. This is a tamped earth layer. It's protected by a government agency on top, and the builders wouldn't have overlooked the sides of the tomb chamber. This soil was mixed using a secret court recipe from that time, containing glutinous rice juice, boy's urine, and all sorts of messy stuff—stronger than modern concrete, I tell you. This secret formula belonged to the emperor of the Northern Song Dynasty. After the Jin state conquered the Northern Song, the recipe ended up in the hands of Jin nobility."

 I hauled the large barrel of vinegar over, instructing Fatty to use a big ladle to drizzle it, spoonful by spoonful, onto the tamped earth layer. By the time the barrel was empty, the mortared wall of the tomb had nearly disintegrated. Vinegar might not seem corrosive, but it works wonders on this secret mix of rammed earth—it's the perfect counter. Digging through it afterward would be as easy as slicing through tofu.

As we proceeded with the method, the tomb chamber was on the verge of being unearthed. While we were reveling in our success, a gunshot suddenly rang out from the woods, startling a flock of birds into flight.

Fatty exclaimed in a panic, "That's my big sister's shooting!"

I grabbed the engineer soldier's shovel and the hunting rifle: "Let's hurry and check it out."

Despite our exhaustion, we sprinted through the forest, stumbling through the thick layer of fallen leaves with each hurried step.

Following the sound, we rushed deeper into the woods, five large dogs trailing closely behind. After covering some distance, we saw Yingzi, accompanied by three giant mastiffs, charging toward us.

Relieved to see she was unharmed, I asked, "Big sister, was it you who fired the shot? What did you find?"

Yingzi's face was pale, and she was panting heavily, "Oh my goodness, it scared me to death. I stumbled upon some shanties up ahead. When I went in, it was terrifying—all dead bodies, blackened and rotting. At first, I didn't see clearly and thought they were wild men, so I fired a shot. I didn't get a good look to see who they really were, though."

That's when I realized, despite Yingzi's usually tough demeanor, she had her fears—dead bodies were her greatest dread. I had thought she was fearless in the forest.

However, finding corpses and shanties in the deep mountains and old forests of the Sino-Mongolian border was incredible in itself. If they had built shanties, it meant they lived here. Who were these deceased, and why would they reside in such a remote, uninhabited wilderness?

"We should go take a look; there might be some clues," I mused, sensing a vague connection between these bodies and the group of tomb raiders who had vanished in this region before.

Yingzi led us to the shanties she had discovered. The structures were crudely made, constructed of mud and straw with a few wooden elements, all nestled densely among the trees, built high and camouflaged. They were nearly impossible to spot from a distance.

We clambered into one of the shanties to find numerous animal hides and, in a corner, indeed three corpses. The bodies were blackened from severe decomposition, the flesh nearly dissolved, and the skin shriveled. Maggots and ants moved in and out of the eye sockets and nostrils. I couldn't help but wonder if these were the rumored wild men of the Wildman Gully.

 Fatty leaned in for a closer look and said to me, "Old Hu, I was wondering why there were no Wild Men in Wildman Gully. Turns out, they're all long dead."

I nodded and replied, "What's odd is that these Wild Men had rather advanced tools. Look, they're even wearing clothes. Since when do Wild Men wear clothes? And why do these garments look so familiar to me?"

The corpses were all clad in Ni's Coats, worn for what must have been decades, now tattered and filthy beyond recognition. Yet, something about the style seemed eerily familiar, as if I had seen it somewhere before.

I noticed something metallic on the collar of the innermost corpse's clothing. I plucked it off and wiped away the grime. It resembled a military uniform's insignia, but it certainly wasn't from our squadron.

Meanwhile, Fatty had found something too. He fumbled in a corner and came upon a combat knife that hadn't been drawn in many years. With considerable effort, he finally pulled the blade free. Its steel edge was of exceptional quality; despite the years, it still shone brightly, reflecting its owner's meticulous care, no doubt frequently polished when he was alive.

At the sight of the knife, I understood. Damn it, the legendary Wild Men were actually these Japanese Devils.

But Fatty couldn't figure it out. "Didn't all the Japanese return home after their defeat and surrender? How come these little ghosts didn't leave?"

"It's not that surprising," I said. "You know too little of history, revealing your true nature of ignorance. Stop the nonsense and listen—I'll explain what likely happened."

"By my estimation, on the eve of Japan's unconditional surrender, the Soviet Union's Mechanized Army advanced southward, attacking the Kwantung Army stationed in China's northeast. They decimated what was claimed to be the most elite forces of the Japanese Army—the million-strong Kwantung Army. Some of these ghosts were scattered, fleeing deep into the forests, too afraid to venture out and having lost contact with the outside world. Unaware of Japan's defeat and surrender, they hid in the forest until they died of old age right here."

"Some people encountered a few of these suspicious, skulking Japanese Devils—clothes filthy beyond recognition, living in the forest without shaving. Weren't they easily mistaken for Wild Men?"

"Of course, this is all conjecture on my part. The real reasons, unless these ghosts come back to life to confess, will forever remain unknown. After my explanation, both Fatty and Yingzi were able to comprehend."

 Yingzi said, "Little Japan probably got lost. Don't be fooled by the fact that this is just the edge of the forest; head north, and it's all vast grasslands, and then there's the 'big mud pits'—swamps that are nothing but mud. You can't get out that way. To the south lies the primeval forest, and without a dog to lead the way, even the most experienced of hunters wouldn't dream of finding an exit. Serves them right."

As I rifled through the belongings of these corpses, hoping to find something of value, a thought suddenly struck me. Could those who came here for tomb raiding in the late forties have encountered the Japanese devils, the derogatory term for the Japanese invaders during WWII? It was entirely possible they were killed by them. They wouldn't have expected to run into Japanese devils in such a desolate place.

Lost in thought, I suddenly found a notebook in a military rucksack. It was filled with Japanese writing—the pages yellowed, but the handwriting still legible. None of the three of us understood Japanese, fortunately, the notebook contained many Chinese characters. We had no choice but to read it as if it were Chinese, focusing only on the Chinese characters within the Japanese text. However, the meanings of kanji in Japanese can be quite different, sometimes even opposite, to their meanings in Chinese. For instance, the Japanese kanji for 'stay behind' conveys a meaning that's the complete opposite of the literal Chinese interpretation. Even with such difficulties, by stringing these words together and adding some of our own conjectures, we could roughly understand half of it. The gist of it seemed to be:

The Kwantung Army of Dongning was crushed by the Soviet Army's mechanized troops, and Colonel Mu led the remnants of a small squad from the Type A Division of the Kwantung Army. The squad, consisting of soldiers, fled towards the Black Wind Pass to a secret underground fortress, intending to regroup with the remaining Kwantung Army forces inside the fortress and make a last stand against the Soviet Union, to serve the Emperor with their broken jade. However, as they neared their destination, they broke through the crust of an opium poppy field. The only soldier who knew the location of the fortress and the guide leading the way drowned in the quagmire, leaving the rest unable to find the entrance to the secret fortress. Attempting to turn back, they lost their way and, without any means of communication, were forced to settle in the deep mountains. There they remained for over thirty years, dying one by one. The narrative ends abruptly there—I surmise the author met his death while penning these words.

 I tossed my notebook aside; there was no time for such rubbish now. The walls of the tomb in the valley were nearly eroded away. It was urgent to return, grab what we could, and leave, paying no further mind to the remnants of the Japanese Devils, as they were all but decayed into oblivion. Fatty declared the knife was mine to keep. Back in the day, my family had several officer's swords, all confiscated during the Cultural Revolution. I had been hoping to add one to my collection. I cautioned him that it was a regulated blade, impossible to carry on a train. Once we got back to Beijing, we could scour the Antique Market and perhaps purchase a new one for him.

The three of us hurried back to the ancient tomb in Wildman Gully. The work was nearly done, and with a few chops from an engineer soldier's shovel, a large hole was breached in the tomb wall. Shining my flashlight through it, I saw the space inside was quite expansive, though there was a drop of over a meter down to the floor of the Tomb Chamber. Fatty, elated, rolled up his sleeves, eager to enter, but I pulled him back with a firm hand. "Have you lost your mind? Cage a few sparrows first and test the air quality in the tomb before anything else."

Catching sparrows in the woods was an easy task, unlike in densely populated areas where they were cunning. We set the simplest of traps, scattering a few grains of millet and propping our cooking pot upside down over them. Hiding at a distance, we watched sparrows slip under the pot to peck at the grains. With a tug of a string, the supporting stick was pulled away, the pot trapping the birds beneath.

We caught three at once. I placed one in a birdcage, tied a rope to it, and lowered it into the depths of the Tomb Chamber. After smoking two cigarettes, enough time had passed, and I hauled the cage back up. The little sparrow inside was belly-up, its eyes rolled back in death.

This tomb, sealed underground for centuries, was devoid of air circulation. Before a corpse begins to decay, it first bloats, filled with Corpse Qi—a miasma believed to emanate from the dead. Only after this swelling do the skin and innards begin to rot from the inside out. Although the Tomb Chamber wasn't a true vacuum, without ventilation, the stench of decay would remain trapped, lingering even after centuries. Even if Corpse Qi wasn't present, air that hadn't circulated for hundreds of years could form toxic gases harmful to the human body. Inhalation of such gases could, at the very least, cause dizziness and headaches, and at worst, lead to poisoning and death. Without a gas mask, this was not a step to be taken lightly.

 It seemed that the tomb would need a bit more time before the mountain winds could cleanse it of its poisonous vapors, so we returned to the hillside to eat some dry food and jerky. Having not slept the previous night and after a day of hard work, we were all exhausted. But the thought of the genuine treasures within the tomb swept away our fatigue. This was our first hands-on experience, and we were eager to unearth something valuable. My understanding of tomb raiding had until then been purely theoretical, but today's practice proved not too difficult. Of course, this was partly due to our choice of target. The Jurchen people of the Jin dynasty were considered an uncivilized tribe in their time, and the tomb they constructed was almost a complete replica of those from the Northern Song Dynasty, albeit on a smaller scale. It was likely built by captured Song artisans since the craft of creating Tianbao Dragon Fire Glazed Tile Roofs is complex, requiring skilled craftsmanship. The slightest error could lead to the tomb's builders being burned alive within.

Having finished our meal and noting the advancing hour, we surmised that the air within the tomb had sufficiently circulated. Concerned about a potential night attack from the creatures dwelling in the underground caverns, we were keen to retrieve the treasures and depart. So, equipped with our tools, we descended once again into the valley of Wildman Gully.

We first released a sparrow into the tomb, and seeing it emerge still lively and hopping, we were assured that the air was safe. Fatty and I took a few swigs of strong liquor to fortify our courage. Donning masks and gloves, hanging Touch-Gold Charms around our necks, and tucking Black Donkey Hooves and glutinous rice into our pockets, we grabbed flashlights and hung engineer shovels on our belts, ready to enter the ancient tomb.

Yingzi, seeing our preparations, urgently tugged at my sleeve and pleaded, "Take me with you. I want to see what an ancient tomb looks like. I've never been inside one all my life."

I replied, "There's nothing much in ancient tombs, just ancient corpses and burial artifacts. What's there to see? Actually, this is also my first time. I've never been inside one before. And you, aren't you afraid of dead bodies? How come you're not scared now?"

Driven by a strong curiosity and seeing the secretive manner in which Fatty and I were conducting ourselves, Yingzi was itching to go inside. I figured, since we were in the desolate wilderness, there was no need for a lookout as tomb raiding thieves rarely work alone. Typically, they work in trios: one to dig, another to scatter the excavated earth since it can't be piled outside the pit, and a third to keep watch from a distance. Letting her have a look wouldn't do any harm. So, I found her a mask to wear and cautioned her, "Once inside, never remove your mask. First, the air quality is poor. Second, the breath of the living shouldn't linger in the tomb—it's inauspicious. Third, don't breathe onto the ancient corpses. Startling the dead could bring serious trouble. Although these are superstitious beliefs, these customs have been passed down for thousands of years and they hold their own logic. It's always better to be cautious. We'll follow the old ways to the letter."

 Fatty was already getting anxious: "Hu Bayi, when did you become such a fusspot? If you're too scared to go down, let me do it myself. You guys just wait up here and count the money."

I retorted, "To hell with that. If you go down, you might not even find the coffin. Let's stop bickering; it's getting dark. We need to get to work."

The hole we had dug in the tomb wall was just over a meter above the floor of the tomb chamber. There was no need for ropes; we could simply climb down. As my feet touched the ground, my heart couldn't help but tense up—it was a relief to finally be inside.

The tomb chamber wasn't large, barely thirty square meters in area, and seemed to be designed like the living quarters of the living, with a main room, a rear chamber, and two side chambers. We entered through a side chamber, and the tomb master's coffin was placed right in the center of the main room.

There was no burial bed—instead, a shallow pit had been dug in the center of the main room, and the dark, somber coffin was placed within it, half-exposed. It was a tomb within a tomb.

In a corner of the main room, several skeletons were piled up, their skulls dented and cracked, clear signs of blunt force trauma. They were likely captives or wives and servants sacrificed for the burial. We weren't archaeologists, so we preferred not to dwell on these remains.

Yingzi suddenly grabbed my arm: "Brother Hu, look, there are paintings on the wall."

I shone my flashlight on the tomb wall where Yingzi pointed, and indeed, there were colorful bas-reliefs depicting various scenes. The figures in the paintings were rendered in an ancient and lifelike manner. Despite their age, the colors remained vibrant, but with the air circulating in the tomb chamber, it wouldn't be long before the frescoes began to fade.

Fatty exclaimed in admiration, "It looks like the person buried here might have been a painter in ancient times."

"Don't pretend you know what you're talking about," I chided. "During the Tang and Song dynasties, it was common for nobles' tombs to have murals that chronicled the significant events of the tomb master's life. Let's see who is buried here."

There were eight murals in total. We examined them in turn; some depicted hunting scenes in the forest, others showed drinking with friends in palaces, there were scenes of going to war, and of escorting captives. The final mural depicted a scene of being conferred nobility. In each painting, there was a man wearing a fox fur hat—undoubtedly the tomb master. It seemed this was the tomb of a general, at least a marquis by rank.

When the Jurchen forces swept south and overthrew the Song Dynasty, they looted a great deal of gold and treasure. This Jurchen general might have brought some of his spoils with him into the grave. After all, these treasures were originally ours, so we wouldn't be shy about taking them.

The three of us first made a round inside the tomb chamber. The two side chambers contained nothing but ceramic jars and pottery. The rear chamber held the bones of four horses and some armor and weapons. Aside from that, there was nothing else, suggesting the Jurchen didn't practice extravagant burials. I was somewhat disappointed. We lit candles in the southeast corner and gathered in front of the coffin in the main room. Whether we would find anything worthwhile depended on this final probe.

 The coffin of the Tomb Master was no small affair, crafted from mahogany and lacquered in black, adorned with golden patterns that were both bizarre in color and design. These likely had something to do with the ethnic totems of the Jurchen people. I ran my hand over the coffin lid; it was solid and thick, a luxury beyond the means of commoners who would consider themselves lucky to have a thin casket, while those even less fortunate might resort to being wrapped in a straw mat and buried haphazardly in the earth.

The crème de la crème within the coffin world was the core of the Aquilaria tree, the heartwood that took thousands of years to mature. Such treasures were rare and sought after, reserved for royalty who could afford to have their corpses interred within this precious wood, ensuring that their flesh would never rot, more valuable than even crystal sarcophagi and more effective than the preservation offered by a refrigerator. Other woods like nanmu, duan hongmu, and millennium cypress were also prized for their thick cores, which not only prevented decay but also deterred insects and maggots from feasting on the body—a fate no Tomb Master would wish upon their mortal remains. Thus, the choice of wood for a noble's coffin was a matter of stringent selection.

The coffin before us, while not on par with those of the imperial family, was still an extravagant piece. I inserted the blade of an engineer's shovel into the gap of the coffin lid, leveraging with force. To my surprise, it was securely nailed down, and it took several attempts before we managed to pry it open.

Fatty joined in with his tool, and together, with a concerted effort, we finally opened a large crack with the coffin creaking in protest. We shifted positions and one by one pried out the nails.

The tomb was exceedingly dry, its walls made of special materials that prevented water seepage. The glazed tiles overhead were also watertight, and most of the rainwater in Wildman Gully was absorbed by the layers of fallen leaves, so there was a considerable amount of dust within the coffin. Our disturbance sent dust swirling into the air, and even with our masks on, we couldn't help but cough incessantly. I resolved to prepare a few gas masks for future expeditions—otherwise, we were bound to develop respiratory issues.

As Fatty moved to push the coffin lid open, I suddenly felt the urge to play a prank on him, to give him a bit of a scare. I grabbed his arm and said, "Fatty, guess what's inside this coffin?"

Fatty replied, "How would I know? Whatever's inside, if we can exchange it for renminbi or the national food ration tickets, that's all that matters."

I lowered my voice deliberately and said, "My grandfather once told me a story from 'The Extensive Records of the Taiping Era,' about two tomb raiders, one fat and one thin. They unearthed a huge coffin in an ancient tomb and tried every method they could think of—chopping with axes, hacking with knives—but they couldn't open it. The fat tomb raider knew the Great Compassion Mantra, and when he recited it towards the coffin, the lid cracked open by itself, and an arm covered in green hair reached out from within."

Fatty wasn't scared, but Yingzi was frightened out of her wits, quickly hiding behind Fatty: "Brother Hu, stop talking nonsense. Don't you see where we are? Are you trying to scare us to death?"

 Fatty knew I was trying to spook him. Apart from his fear of heights, he was truly fearless. Back in the day at school, when it came to brawling with other kids, he was the fiercest of them all. Now, Fatty's face was a picture of courage, unmoved by my attempts to scare him, his expression one of noble righteousness. "Yingzi, big sister, don't listen to him. This guy just wants to scare me. He seems to forget who Fatty is. What have I ever been afraid of? Let him go on."

Continuing, I said, "That arm, covered in green hair, with fingernails over three inches long, grabbed the fat tomb raider who was chanting the Great Compassion Mantra and dragged him into the coffin. The coffin lid immediately slammed shut, and from within, only screams could be heard, terrifying another tomb raider so much that he turned tail and fled."

Fatty forced a grin, a few strained chuckles escaping his lips. I guessed he was feeling a bit jittery inside, but he was determined to play the tough guy. He stepped forward to join me in pushing the coffin lid, but we applied too much force and ended up knocking the entire lid to the ground, revealing all that lay within the coffin.

A tall male corpse lay there, its bodily fluids long since evaporated, leaving only a soy-purple dried skin clinging to the skeleton. After nearly a thousand years, this was still considered remarkably well-preserved, akin to the rare wet mummies unearthed from the Mawangdui in Hunan, which are one in a thousand. Although his facial features had collapsed into black hollows where his eyes and nose once were, his face was still faintly recognizable, appearing to be in his forties or fifties. He wore a heaven-reaching crown on his head, a red robe with blue-trimmed gold embroidery, cloud-treading boots on his feet, and his hands were placed on his chest.

Yingzi peeked inside from behind Fatty and let out a shriek: "Oh my goodness, that's terrifying!" She quickly averted her gaze, unable to bear the sight any longer.

Her scream made my scalp tingle, but with the coffin already open, could we turn and run? Bracing myself, I pressed my hands together and bowed thrice to the ancient corpse: "We are in dire straits, lacking food and clothing, and are forced to borrow a few genuine items to exchange for some modest funds. We mean no offense. After all, you should have ascended to heaven or descended into the earth long ago; wherever you were meant to go, you have gone. Dust returns to dust, earth to earth, and wealth and jewels are but worldly possessions, brought not into life and taken not into death. These treasures you've left behind serve little purpose now. We, even as thieves, have principles. After taking them, we will surely use the majority to build bridges and pave roads, to improve the lives of the people, following the exemplary model of Lei Feng, never forgetting our roots, with a clear distinction between love and hate, and a firm standpoint."

Before I could finish my speech, Fatty, unable to contain himself any longer, reached into the coffin, groping about. I hurriedly reminded him, "Easy there, for heaven's sake. Don't damage the body."

 Fatty was unwilling to listen. Since entering the tomb chamber, he hadn't found anything of value, save for a few broken pots and jars, and the skeletal remains of burial companions. After all the trouble we'd gone through, it was time to see what treasures the tomb master's coffin might hold.

Seeing that my attempts to persuade him were futile, I stopped wasting my breath and joined him in examining the contents of the coffin. The ancient corpse was surrounded by porcelain, a subject I knew little about at the time, especially porcelain. I had only seen a few pieces of blue-and-white porcelain from the Northern Song Dynasty and had no understanding of the value, craftsmanship, or history of these ceramics. I only knew that gold had a price, but jade was priceless. I was determined to find some ancient jade, so I carelessly tossed the porcelain aside. Fortunately, amidst my haphazard search, I found two jade bi discs in the hands of the ancient corpse. They were a vibrant green, carved into shapes resembling moths, yet not quite resembling butterflies.

We examined the pair of jade bi for a long time but couldn't determine what exactly they were. I only knew that they were likely made of jadeite and predated the Northern Song Dynasty, so they must be valuable. Otherwise, why would the tomb master clutch them in death? They could probably fetch tens of thousands at least, which was a significant sum, as there were not many households with that kind of wealth in the entire country back then. To ascertain their specific value, we would need someone like Big Gold Tooth, an expert in the field, to appraise them and then contact some Hong Kong and Taiwan businesspeople to sell them.

Fatty, not quite satisfied, wanted to pry open the ancient corpse's mouth to see if there were any gold teeth. I suggested that we had done enough and should not be too ruthless; it was only right to leave the deceased with some dignity. We picked out a few of the more attractive pieces of porcelain to take with us and returned the rest to their original places.

After collecting the items, we lifted and replaced the coffin lid. Though we hadn't left with as much as we had hoped, we weren't leaving empty-handed either. I told them it was time to go, to repair the tomb wall and head home. As I turned to leave, I suddenly noticed that the candle in the corner had silently snuffed out.

Fatty and Yingzi (a personal name) noticed it too. Even though they wore masks, the foreheads that showed were covered in cold sweat. A layer of fine sweat covered my entire body as well. I somewhat regretted having exaggerated the horror of the phenomenon of 'Ghost Blows Out the Light' when discussing tomb raiding with them.

I glanced back at the coffin. The lid was securely replaced and nailed down, not a sound to be heard. Could it be that ghosts truly existed in this world?

Yingzi (a personal name), who stood beside me, was deathly afraid of corpses and ghosts. She immediately reached to remove her mask, but I quickly held her hand and said, "You can't take off the mask. What are you trying to do?"

 Yingzi wanted to whistle for the hunting dogs to come inside, but I patted her shoulder and said, "Don't worry, it's not time for that yet. Besides, dogs can't bite ghosts anyway."

Fatty walked over to look at the candles on the ground, then turned to ask me, "Old Hu, how much did you pay for each of these candles?"

"I bought them in Beijing and brought them here. I didn't really pay much attention to the price when I was shopping—probably two cents each, I guess."

Fatty complained, "Couldn't you have bought the ones that cost five cents each? For something so important, how could you settle for cheap goods?"

Scratching my head, I replied, "Next time I'll buy imported ones. Whichever is more expensive from America, Japan, or Germany, I'll get that. But the candles have gone out now, so let's not play the wise man after the event. Shouldn't we put everything back exactly as it was?"

It had taken an enormous effort to get our hands on these few items, and neither Fatty nor I were keen on returning them all. It would be like making sticky rice balls without any filling—completely pointless.

Fatty, undaunted, believed that even if a ghost really did show up, he'd smack it with a shovel until it was picking up its teeth off the ground. "I'm taking all these items today," he declared. "If you want them put back, a ghost will have to knock me flat first. Otherwise, no chance."

Yingzi felt it was better to put everything back. "None of us know any spells for subduing demons or capturing ghosts. If we really stir up trouble with ghosts and goblins, none of us will make it out of the tomb alive."

Before I could speak, the two of them were already arguing. Eventually, they both agreed to my compromise: relight the candles, put back a few pieces of porcelain at random, and see if the candles stayed lit. If they went out again, we'd return another item. If that still didn't work, we'd only take the two jade pieces and leave the rest of the porcelain behind. Perhaps the candles had been extinguished by a gust of wind from outside the tomb chamber. If we didn't take something back after all our efforts, it wouldn't just be a shame—it would be downright embarrassing.

Fatty slapped his thigh in agreement: "That settles it. I'll put a small porcelain piece back first. Old Hu, you go relight the candle. If it goes out again, we'll just pretend we didn't see anything."

Bargaining with the spirits of the tomb like this, I might be the first to do so openly. If the tomb raiders of past dynasties knew what I was doing, they'd be so angry they'd rise from their graves just to strangle me. I'm truly a disgrace to our ancestors. But now, in the era of Reform and Opening-up, we should all adapt to the historical tide and not cling to those rigid, traditional rules. The economy needs to be invigorated, and so does our thinking. Without invigorated thinking, how can the economy thrive?

As I rationalized my actions, I took out a match and lit the candle in the corner of the wall. By then, Fatty had already placed a tri-colored porcelain vase with water patterns on top of the coffin. Too lazy to move the lid again, he simply set it on the coffin lid and came back to me, saying, "There, no more problems. See, the candle isn't out. Should we start acting out the sixth scene from 'Shajiabang' now?"

 Suddenly aware of some unusual circumstances, my nerves were on edge. When Fatty spoke, I was so startled that I didn't catch on right away, and I retorted, "What the devil's 'Act Six'?"

Fatty hit me with a head knocker, saying, "What are you thinking about? It's the retreat in Act Six of the Shajiabang opera."

I had no mind to pay attention to his words and gestured for him to be silent, pointing to the candle on the ground and whispering, "Why the hell is the candle flame green?"

The flame was emitting a strange, greenish glow, casting an eerie light on our faces that turned them a ghastly shade of green. Fatty and Yingzi also leaned in to look. Confronted with this sight, we exchanged glances, speechless. The candle's sickly green flame flickered twice and then snuffed out without any apparent cause.

I knew this was bad luck; on my very first tomb raid, I'd run into a big zongzi – a serious problem. I grabbed Fatty and Yingzi by the arms and bolted towards the tomb raider's tunnel. The priority was to get out; I had no intention of staying behind to become a burial offering for the Jurchen barbarians.

We were nearing the tunnel entrance when a sudden gust of wind surged from behind. If we didn't dodge, it would surely hit us squarely. The three of us ducked down to the ground, narrowly avoiding the porcelain vase with water patterns that Fatty had placed on the coffin lid. It flew over our heads, shattered against the edge of the tomb raider's tunnel, and turned into countless fragments. Another loud crash followed as the coffin lid, which had been nailed back in place, was thrust so forcefully into the tomb wall that it embedded itself there, sealing the exit. The wall was made of tamped earth mixed with a secret formula from the Northern Song Dynasty, hard as rock. The coffin lid was extremely thick and heavy, thrown with unimaginable force. It would take significant effort and more than a moment's work with an engineer soldier's shovel to break through it.

"To embed the coffin lid in the tomb wall requires immense strength," I thought. "Had we been slower, it could have crushed our heads." Even the usually fearless Fatty was terrified, his heart pounding with fear. "Old Hu," he implored, "you should go negotiate with it. We can leave a few more treasures behind. It's no good for anyone if things turn violent. After all, peace is most precious."

This first venture turning out so poorly, anger flared within me, and I fell back into my old impulsive ways. I turned around, shielding Yingzi behind me, drew the black donkey hoof from my bosom with one hand, and with the other, I brandished an engineer soldier's shovel at Fatty, saying, "Negotiate my ass! It's blocked our way out, clearly wanting us to become burial objects. I've set my mind on these ancient jades today. Damn it, let's see who's tougher. Grab your weapons, and let's fight this damned ghost that's come barking up the wrong tree."

 At that moment, the lidless coffin within the main chamber had been propped upright, revealing the ancient corpse inside. Its once purple-hued, desiccated skin had, at some unknown point, sprouted a thick layer of red hair.

I drew in a sharp breath at the sight, my earlier bravado to rush in and fight drained by half. I had heard tales of zombies growing white or black hair, known as the white and black fierce, and even of venomous corpse demons sprouting green hair, but this red-haired variety was new to me.

We had been too careless this time. Considering the tomb's modest size, we thought avoiding the government agency would suffice. Little did we expect to encounter a red-haired giant rice dumpling within. We hadn't brought our shotguns, and the tomb raider's tunnel we had dug was securely blocked, leaving no way to call down the big dogs for assistance. In the forest, the hunting dogs and shotguns were our Great Wall of defense, but now we were left with nothing but a German engineer soldier's shovel and a black donkey's hoof to do battle.

However, the black donkey's hoof needed to be stuffed into the giant rice dumpling's mouth to be effective, and I had only heard of its use, with no guarantee of its efficacy.

The ancient corpse had grown red hair even on its face, rendering its features indistinguishable. It looked like a fiery red great ape, and with a shake of its arms, it leaped out of the coffin, covering over two meters in a single bound, its approach silent and swift as the wind. In just a few leaps, it was upon us, extending its ten dagger-like claws in a ferocious pounce.

Never would I have imagined the giant rice dumpling to be so agile. In that critical moment, there was no time for thought. The fight chamber allowed no room for maneuvering; retreat was not an option. We had to counterattack to defend ourselves. Fatty and I shared the same thought: regardless of what it was, we would flatten it first and ask questions later. With a joint cry, we swung our engineer soldier's shovels at the red-haired ancient corpse with all our might.

The ancient corpse moved with astonishing speed, sweeping its arms horizontally. We felt a tremendous force collide with our hands, numbing our grip and forcing us to lose hold of the shovels. They flew up like leaves caught in a gale, clanging as they embedded themselves in the tomb chamber's glazed roof. Although it was dark above, the sound alone was enough to confirm that such a heavy blow could bring down the Tianbao dragon fire glazed tile roof at any moment.

The Western Region fire dragon oil was no trivial matter. Once spilled, the tomb chamber would be consumed by fire, the jade and stone burning together, and the tomb would be utterly destroyed. To escape, we had to end the battle quickly, but bare-handed, it was easier said than done.

 Deprived of their tools, the group hesitated to use the Black Donkey Hoof they held, a known counter to zombies, fearing the reckless act against the formidable Rice Dumpling. Such was its ferocity that one might be torn to shreds before the hoof could be stuffed into its maw. With no other choice, they dodged the Ancient Corpse's lunges, scrambling towards the back room where armor and horse bones were displayed.

The Tomb Chamber, devoid of light save for the beams of their flashlights, became even more treacherous as they fled. Fatty, just steps away from the back room's door, stumbled over a jar by the wall and fell to the ground with a cry.

The Red-haired Corpse Monster, shadowing their every move, pounced with a shriek that echoed through the narrow space like the wails of a night cat, a sound so harrowing and piercing it set one's nerves on edge and raised goosebumps on the skin.

I had sworn, time and again, never to let any comrade-in-arms fall before me. Seeing Fatty's life hanging by a thread, I cast aside all thoughts of danger. With a kick, I struck the ghoul's chest—a blow that felt like hitting a steel plate, sending a sharp pain through my leg that nearly snapped the bone.

The Red-haired Corpse Monster, reeling from the attack, abandoned Fatty and viciously swiped its claw towards my head. I hurled my flashlight at the creature and rolled beneath its arm, narrowly evading its talons. I now found myself trapped in a dead-end corner, the wall and the back of the corpse monster forming a triangle that penned me in. Should it turn and lunge at me again, I would stand no chance.

I had faced death-defying situations countless times in my life, and it was in these moments of dire peril that calm was most needed. This red-haired Rice Dumpling was corporeal and brutish, impervious to blades and spears, but no ghost. It held no terror for me. Without further thought, I leapt onto the back of the Red-haired Corpse Monster. The stench that filled my nostrils was foul, and I thanked the heavens for my mask, which spared me from being overwhelmed by the odor before the fight even began.

Blinded without my flashlight, I could see nothing in the pitch dark. The Red-haired Corpse Monster, with its stiff limbs, could not reach back to grab me, but it shook its body violently, trying to dislodge me.

With one hand, I clung tightly to the monster's neck, while with the other, I fumbled with the Black Donkey Hoof, trying to shove it into its mouth. I pressed it against the creature's face haphazardly, unable to locate its mouth. Instead, I was the one left dizzy and disoriented, stars flashing before my eyes—a dire sign. A few more shakes and I feared I would be the one to fall first.

 Suddenly, in the darkness, a flash of light caught my eye. I thought I was seeing things, but when I looked again, I realized it was Fatty and Yingzi, each with a flashlight clenched in their teeth for illumination, charging toward me with a massive mace they had retrieved from the back room. They were ready for a direct confrontation. I quickly leapt off the back of the Red-haired Corpse Monster.

The mace weighed a hefty amount, a heavy single combat weapon from the age of cold arms. When we first entered the tomb, we had seen it among other weapons, armor, and horse bones piled on the ground in the back room, presumably used by the Tomb Master in battle during his lifetime.

Although these weapons were coated with a verdigris patina, the product of long exposure to the air, the effectiveness of the mace did not rely on sharp blades but on the sheer force of its weight to crush the enemy. Fatty and Yingzi, flanking the sides, hoisted the mace with four hands and swung it like a temple bell hammer, slamming it into the chest of the Red-haired Corpse Monster. The weight of the mace, combined with their momentum, delivered a powerful blow that knocked the creature to the ground with a thud.

The two of them had exerted themselves too much and were now gasping for air. I thought I could almost hear their hearts pounding fiercely.

I praised them, saying, "Well done! I didn't expect such strength from you two. I'll make sure to commend you both when we get back."

No sooner had the words left my mouth than the Red-haired Corpse Monster sprang up from the ground as if it had springs attached. I cursed loudly, "Damn it, it's like it can't be steamed soft or boiled tender! Fatty, hit it hard again, and this time aim for the head."

Fatty, fueled by rage, didn't wait for Yingzi's help this time. He mustered his brute strength, lifted the studded mace, and aimed a fierce blow at the Red-haired Corpse Monster. Unfortunately, the monster leapt forward at just the right moment, causing the mace to fly back into the back room, while Fatty was sent sprawling, his palms split open and bleeding, crying out in pain.

A thought struck me—the Engineer Soldier's shovel was stuck in the ceiling. If we wanted to break open the tomb door sealed by the coffin lid, we could use the mace. We needed to retrieve it from the back room, lure away the corpse fiend, smash the coffin lid, and rush out. There was more space outside, with hunting rifles and dogs at our disposal; we could handle the situation however we needed. Staying in this cramped tomb chamber limited our options.

I helped Fatty up from the ground, and the three of us fled into the back room of the ancient tomb. This annex was lower than the main chamber. After descending, I shone the flashlight around and saw that the mace, thrown with tremendous force by the corpse fiend, had smashed a large hole in the wall of the back room. It was not just a pit but a hole—could there be another hidden chamber beyond? I had heard tales of ancient tombs concealing secret chambers. Perhaps this was one such secret room. It seemed we had been quite mistaken this time.

 The gaping hole in the tomb wall, left by the violent strike of a spiked club, was a dark abyss. When illuminated by the flashlight, it appeared bottomless, revealing a long, expansive passage.

As I stood in astonishment, the red-haired corpse monster charged into the inner chamber, bringing with it a chilly wind. The three of us, not daring to hesitate, reversed our grip on the spiked clubs, hoping to push it back out and then rush to smash the coffin lid. However, the creature's strength was beyond imagination. With a lift of its arms, exerting a force of over a thousand pounds, our combined efforts were futile. The spiked clubs were once again sent flying, spinning through the air and striking the tomb wall behind us.

The crack in the wall now widened. With no other path available, we were forced to retreat into the secret chamber behind the tomb wall, bracing ourselves with the spiked clubs for another round of combat.

Yet, the red-haired corpse monster did not pursue us further; it simply circled the inner chamber. I let out a sigh of relief and shone the flashlight on the faces of Fatty and Yingzi. Aside from a hand injury that Fatty had sustained, none of us were seriously harmed. Reflecting on the series of fierce battles within the tomb chamber, which lasted only a few minutes, it felt as though we had narrowly skirted the gates of the underworld.

Suddenly, I remembered something and grabbed Fatty's hand. "Why aren't you wearing gloves? When did you take them off?"

Fatty looked down at his hands. "I was sweating so much while opening the coffin that I took off the gloves."

I cursed at him. "You're truly undisciplined! How many times have I told you to wear gloves when touching ancient corpses in a tomb? It could very well be your bare hands that provoked the red-haired giant 'zongzi' to rise from the dead."

Unyielding, Fatty retorted, "You're talking nonsense. An ancient corpse isn't a landmine that explodes upon touch. Don't you dare slander the innocent."

Yingzi, trying to mediate, interjected, "Stop bickering, you two. Look, there are characters on this wall. What does it say?"

Following the beam of Yingzi's flashlight, we saw a red sign on the wall with bold letters: "Black Wind Pass - Underground Gena Warehouse."

Fatty and I exchanged a glance. "A secret fortress of the Kwantung Army... who would have thought that the underground passage of the Japanese fortress lay merely a wall away from the tomb's inner chamber? Just half a meter further in, and the tomb would have been breached. If it weren't for the spiked club being violently knocked against the tomb wall by the corpse monster, this deeply hidden military fortress might have remained undiscovered beneath the ground forever."

 Before I had time to take a closer look, the wall separating the ancient tomb's inner chamber and the fortress suddenly collapsed with a thunderous crash. The red-haired corpse creature had already leaped out from the broken wall of the tomb chamber.

Fatty cursed loudly, "Damn it, like a pesky plaster that won't come off!" Seizing his spiked club, he was ready to go head-to-head with the creature.

I quickly stopped him, saying, "Don't go toe-to-toe with it; let's find a way out first, then figure out what to do." Without a moment's hesitation, we took off running into the depths of the underground fortress. The passageways were incredibly spacious, with cement floors that could accommodate armored vehicles. However, the corridors were long and wide, with no cover or obstacles, and the red-haired corpse monster was incredibly fast, closing in on us from behind in an instant.

I thought about throwing the Black Donkey Hoof to stall it, but as I frantically searched my person, my hand brushed against a pocketful of sticky rice. I had heard that ancient tomb raiders always carried sticky rice into tombs, as it could be used to draw out the poison if one was afflicted by corpse qi—a term often used in Chinese fantasy novels referring to a kind of miasma or energy emitted by corpses. I wasn't sure if it would work on zombies, and this red-haired creature hardly looked like a typical zombie.

A chilly wind blew from behind, carrying a putrid stench. I grabbed a handful of sticky rice from my pocket and flung it behind me at the red-haired corpse monster. The rice scattered over its face like flowers strewn by a celestial maiden, yet it seemed unfazed, merely pausing before continuing its relentless pursuit.

By now, we had reached the end of the underground fortress's passageway. The large iron door of the Gena Warehouse was ajar. It seemed the Kwantung Army had retreated in such haste that they hadn't locked the door. However, after thirty-odd years without use, the hinges were nearly rusted shut. The three of us dashed into the warehouse, gritting our teeth and using all our strength, finally managing to close the heavy iron door just before the corpse creature could get in.

Even if the creature had a head of copper and arms of iron, it couldn't break through. We couldn't even hear it banging on the door from inside. The doors of this kind of military facility were designed to withstand explosive shockwaves, with two layers of quilting sandwiched between sheets of iron and steel to absorb the force. Back in the day, the Japanese devils—derogatory term for the Japanese invaders during WWII—were so terrorized by American air raids that even their underground fortresses were built to withstand large aerial bombs. Even if the corpse monster was formidable, it didn't have the destructive power of the U.S. Army's high-explosive bombs. We were safe for the moment, but figuring out how to get out was still a vexing problem.

 I sat on the ground, catching my breath, and shone my flashlight around. The warehouse was truly vast, with various supplies piled up like mountains. Given such a large space, it was puzzling how there were no traces of it on the outside. I calculated the direction and distance I had run and had an epiphany. It turned out that the hillside to the west of Wildman Gully had been hollowed out to create an entire Underground Fortress. The more I thought about it, the more it made sense. Japan had invested its national strength in the management of Manchuria, setting up its heavy industrial base to maintain the entire war situation, mostly within Manchuria. Especially after Japan’s mainland suffered air raids from the U.S. Army, Manchuria had become Japan’s strategic rear. To consolidate defenses, particularly against the northern threat of the Soviet Union, the Kwantung Army had constructed countless Underground Fortresses in Manchuria. These were permanent defensive installations. Although the place we arrived at was in Inner Mongolia, it was also part of the Occupied Zone of the Japanese Army during those years. The Japanese leadership believed in the principle of "Defend Manchuria but not Mongolia," much like protecting the river but not the riverbanks. Thus, establishing peripheral defensive facilities for Manchuria along the Sino-Mongolian Border was a natural course of action.

Black Wind Pass was a strategic location coveted by military tacticians. If the Soviet Union's forces were to attack from the Grassland, this would be their inevitable path. However, in the end, the Soviets chose to attack from the Manchurian side, rendering this painstakingly built Underground Fortress strategically insignificant. Presumably, the defending troops in the Fortress must have received the Emperor's edict announcing the unconditional surrender over the radio. With morale dissolving, some committed suicide, while others fled.

Constructing such a large-scale underground facility would have required a massive workforce. I shudder to think of the blood and sweat of the Chinese laborers that went into it, and it is very possible that, to keep military secrets, the laborers who built the Fortress were executed upon completion. The supplies in the Gena Warehouse had survived for over thirty years, with some still in relatively good condition. There might even be large-scale electrical equipment. It's a waste not to make use of the Ghosts' belongings—if there's a way to return, I'll have the villagers organize a caravan to haul away the spoils of war.

 Fatty stood up and rubbed his sore spots; he had taken quite a tumble in the tomb chamber. Tearing two strips from his clothing, he asked Yingzi to help him bandage the wounds on his hands. His whole body ached as he cursed the zombies outside.

"I don't think those were zombies," I said. "The black donkey hoof and glutinous rice didn't affect them. Besides, we've heard plenty about zombies. Shaanxi has the most. The custom there before the Ming Dynasty was to expose the dead to the sun for sixteen days, letting the bodies decompose before burial to prevent them from turning into zombies. When I was in the military in Lanzhou, I saw zombies with long black hair unearthed from the ground. I've heard there are ones with white hair too. Additionally, corpses buried with poisonous insects might turn green, but I've never heard of any with red hair."

After Yingzi finished bandaging Fatty's hands, she interjected, "That thing wasn't a zombie at all. I thought you knew—it's a Corpse Demon."

Fatty and I had never heard of a Corpse Demon, so we asked Yingzi to elaborate. "What is a Corpse Demon?"

Yingzi recalled stories the elders in her clan used to tell. Long ago, when the Manchu people were still called the Jurchen, there was a form of witchcraft within their tribe known as 'zhuangsha,' which you may have heard of. During the burial rites, a piece of burnt talisman paper was placed in the deceased's mouth, and they held their most cherished possession in their hands. If tomb raiders came to steal, the corpse would become possessed, sprouting tough hair all over, impervious to blades and firearms, and would not rest until it had strangled the tomb raiders. The type of spirit summoned affected the color of the hair that grew on the corpse. These were just stories to me, but witnessing it today, I've realized such terrifying things do exist in this world."

Fatty pulled out two jade bi disks he had pried from the ancient corpse's hands. "I'm not giving them back. If they want them, they can pay twenty thousand yuan for them, or even food ration tickets will do. But what's up with this jade?"

I examined the jade bi, which had turned from its original vibrant green to a pale yellow. I couldn't explain the change; I was suddenly aware of how limited my own knowledge and experience were. I had been somewhat self-important until recently, but now I saw that I still had much to learn.

However, since we had already taken the object, fear was pointless. I stood up and rallied them both, "Let's go further in and see if there are any firearms or ammunition. Best case, we find a tank and drive it right over that Corpse Demon, flattening it into a pancake."

chapters.name: Chapter 19: Kwantung Army Underground Fortress
chapters.content:
Fatty asked me, "Do you have any military knowledge? It's impossible for there to be a tank here."

I replied, "Let's not jump to conclusions until we've had a look inside. Even if there really is a tank, it's unlikely to be operational after nearly forty years. Even with daily maintenance, it would be long past its service life by now."

The passageways within the Gena Warehouse were a labyrinthine tangle, akin to a maze. To prevent getting lost, we hugged the walls as we searched for an exit.

The corridors of the Underground Fortress, like those of the Gena Warehouse, boasted high, arched ceilings—a waterproofing design. Shining our flashlights upward, we could see emergency lights and pipelines installed above. If we managed to find the generator, there might be a way to illuminate these lights.

Not far along, we spotted a map of the Fortress on the wall, which marked out major passageways, the Traffic Trench, storerooms, Soldier Concealment Caves, shower rooms, Barracks, rest areas, granaries, drainage pipes, and the power station among other auxiliary facilities. However, crucial positions such as gun emplacements, ventilation shafts, Counterattack Holes, Observation Holes, and the Combat Command Room were not indicated. Inside the hill, the Fortress was divided into three levels. The complexity of its structure and the enormity of its scale underscored the Kwantung Army's emphasis on this Military Base in its heyday.

I took the map down from the wall. Having served as a Combat Engineer and having participated in the construction of Military Facilities in the Kunlun Mountains, I was no longer worried about finding our way out with the map in hand. The sheer size of this secret Underground Fortress was beyond my imagination, stretching thirty kilometers in depth and over sixty kilometers in width at the front defenses. It turned out the hills on both sides of Wildman Gully had been completely hollowed out, forming two Permanent Support Defense Works that supported each other. Three passages ran transversely through Wildman Gully, interconnecting the Fortress beneath the hills on either side. The underground passage we had broken into from the Ancient Tomb of the Jin Dynasty General was the lowest of these three. The Fortress was thick at both ends and tapered in the middle; although the ends were vast, only three passages connected them. This design was likely a tactical consideration—if one end of the Fortress were to fall to the enemy, the passages could still be severed to hold the other end.

 From our current position, the nearest exit wasn't too far away, but it was uncertain whether the Kwantung Army had deliberately sabotaged the fortress's exits during their retreat. Otherwise, the only way back might be through the ancient tomb, or perhaps we could attempt to escape through something like a ventilation outlet. Suddenly, I remembered what happened last night on the hillside: our horses had been eviscerated by a creature from an underground burrow. Could that very burrow have been a ventilation outlet of the fortress, enlarged by the creature's claws to serve as its lair? If that was indeed a ventilation outlet, there was no hope of climbing out through it; the hole was too narrow.

I shared my thoughts with Yingzi and Fatty, asking for their input on how we might exit.

Fatty remarked, "Hu, if you hadn't mentioned it, I'd have completely forgotten. The monster that attacked our horses might be using this underground fortress as its den. Wandering around blindly, we might bump into it at any moment. We need to find some weapons for self-defense."

"You're right, better safe than sorry. If the exit is destroyed, we'll have to climb out through the tomb's robber hole, which means another head-on clash with the Corpse Demon," I said. "There should be an area in the Gena Warehouse where weapons and equipment are stored. Let's go see if we can find anything handy. Each of us should grab a few items. It would be ideal to find some Japanese Army field pumpkin hand grenades. Those grenades have a long shelf life and pack a considerable punch, perfect for dealing with Corpse Demons."

The Gena Warehouse was filled with various supplies: standard military coats, blankets, dry batteries, mess tins, gas masks, and more. Thanks to the unique construction of the fortress, the air here was relatively dry, preserving some of the materials quite well. I casually picked up a few Japanese Army Haruta-style gas masks and stuffed them into my bag. Finally, on the right side of the Gena Warehouse, I found the weapons storage.

Rows of iron racks were stacked with wooden boxes loaded with firearms. There were no machine guns, just rows of Arisaka Rifles, commonly known as the 'three-eight cover' or Type 38. Along the wall stood a few Type 60 Cannons, but not a single shell could be found nearby.

 Fatty pried open a wooden crate meant for rifles and grabbed one from inside. With a swift motion, he pulled back the gun bolt, shone his flashlight inside, and said to me, "Old Hu, this gun's still good to go. They're all brand new, never unsealed, the mechanical parts all oiled up, and not a single bullet has been loaded."

Yingzi and I each picked up a rifle as well. I raised the Arisaka-style rifle, took aim, and then tossed it back: "These lousy Japanese rifles only have a five-round capacity, with a non-automatic, rotating bolt action—it's too slow to load, and the recoil is particularly strong. I'm not used to it."

Yingzi asked me, "Little Ghost, what's not to like about this rifle? It packs a punch. My uncle used one like this when he first joined the Northeast Democratic United Army. Why don't you like to use it, Brother Hu?"

Before I could reply, Fatty interjected: "Don't mind him. He's been spoiled by playing with semi-automatic weapons every day in the army, and he's developed some quirks. Of course, he wouldn't fancy such an outdated gun. If we run into a Corpse Demon later, we'll just stand behind him and watch him show off his tricks of catching a wolf with his bare hands." While speaking, he rummaged through the bottom of the pile and found an ammo box. Upon opening it, he found bullets wrapped in oiled cloth, gleaming golden in the beam of the flashlight. Fatty had been pampered by his father since childhood, playing with guns as soon as he could walk. By the time he was in junior high, he was already an expert in firearms. Although he had never used an Arisaka-style rifle before, it was not unfamiliar to him. Seeing the ammunition, he skillfully pressed the bullets into the rifle, pulled back the gun bolt with a flick of his wrist, and aimed it at me.

I hurriedly pushed the muzzle away: "Don't point a loaded gun around carelessly. A gun's muzzle is not for pointing at comrades, only traitors aim their guns at their own. I don't like using this Type 38 because it's not suitable for close combat. The bullets have too much penetration power; at a distance of thirty meters, one shot could go through three or four people. Unless you fix a bayonet for close combat, it's too easy to hurt your own men. Plus, in the underground fortress with its many steel structures, a bullet hitting a steel plate could ricochet unpredictably. You might end up dealing with your own people before hitting the enemy."

Fatty slapped his chest confidently and said to me, "With our marksmanship, it's not just blowing smoke. After all these years, you should know. Hitting a target a hundred steps away or shooting a lantern off a horseback is child's play for us. How could we possibly miss and hit a steel plate? Don't believe me? Let's try placing a chicken egg on your head later and see."

 I interrupted him as his talk grew increasingly erratic. "Do you think it's easy for me to keep a level head? This head of mine is for pondering life, not for you to use as a target for egg-tossing. Let's not beat around the bush, shall we? See if there's another weapon we can use. I've always felt this kind of rifle isn't quite right—after all, it's been obsolete for years. Old rifles are prone to misfire. Back when I was on the front lines in Vietnam, there was a civilian worker transporting supplies for us. He stole one of the old German-made guns we'd captured from the Vietnamese militia. Climbing a hill, the darn thing misfired, and just like that, it blew open the head of our deputy regiment leader. This isn't child's play."

We pried open the crates on the rack one by one, hoping to find a few of those field pumpkin hand grenades. Instead, in a wooden box marked with a plaster flag, we unearthed more than a dozen submachine guns with an odd design. A few resembled the British Sten submachine gun, with the magazine inserted horizontally on the left side of the gun. Unlike the British Sten, these had curved magazines and an additional wooden gunstock.

Yingzi asked me, "Hu Ge, what kind of gun is this? Why does it look so strange? Is it a shoddy piece?"

I pulled on the submachine gun's bolt and removed the magazine to examine it. "This is likely a Japanese-made Type 100 submachine gun. They only started equipping troops with it late in the war, and it wasn't produced in large quantities, so it's quite rare. It was probably intended for use against the Soviet Army. This gun is much more reliable than the Type 38, especially for close combat. If it jams, at worst, the cartridge gets stuck—it won't misfire or backfire. You and Fatty should ditch the rifles and arm yourselves with a submachine gun for protection."

Yingzi had never handled a submachine gun before and didn't know how to operate it. She stood by our side, holding two flashlights to illuminate our work, while Fatty found a box of submachine gun bullets. Together, we loaded the bullets into the magazines.

Humming a tune, I pressed the bullets one by one into the magazine, feeling quite pleased with myself. It had been a while since I had handled a submachine gun, and the memory of using the Type 56 in the army made my palms itch with anticipation. Lost in my moment of pride, Yingzi suddenly tapped my shoulder and whispered, "Hu Ge, I think I just saw a kid run past behind you."

 How could there possibly be a child here? Deep within this old forest, where human footprints are scarce, let alone in this hidden fortress, buried so deep in secrecy. How could a child suddenly appear out of nowhere?

We were all squatting on the ground, loading bullets, with Yingzi crouched across from me, flashlight in hand. It was unintentional, a casual sweep of the flashlight's beam, when she glimpsed a child's figure darting behind me.

I turned around, flashing the light in all directions. Behind me was a T-shaped passage, pitch-black and eerily quiet. Not a trace of a child to be seen. I asked Yingzi, "What child? Have you scared yourself silly? Maybe your eyes are playing tricks on you."

Although Yingzi was brave, being a girl from the mountains, she had a strong sense of feudal superstitious consciousness. Now frightened, her complexion had changed. "I'm not lying; I really saw a child run past behind you. There's no mistaking it. There was no sound of footsteps, just the sight of a child's figure, really fast, just zipped past. Could there be a ghost?"

Secret Fortress of the Kwantung Army 2

When I pressed Yingzi for details, she couldn't clarify, only that she had caught a fleeting glimpse of a child, seemingly a little girl, but she wasn't certain. She hadn't seen the clothes clearly, just a figure, about five or six, maybe seven years old. The direction the child ran was exactly where the map indicated an exit.

The passage was no more than two meters away from me. In such a silent place, it would be impossible not to hear a child running past. So noiselessly, it could only be a specter. The underground fortress was a world cut off from the outside, untouched for decades. Who knew what was hidden within? Today's events had already taken their toll on us. Better to avoid more trouble—when you can't confront something, isn't it better to evade it?

I suggested we take a longer route to the fortress exit, avoiding the passage the child had run through.

Yingzi, who was most fearful of ghosts and spirits, nodded in agreement. "Climbing ten more miles is better than running into a ghost-built wall."

Fatty was skeptical. "Old Hu, I've noticed you've changed. Ever since you were demobilized from the army, you're not as fearless as before. It's not like you to shy away.
