Now, just because Yingzi saw a child, you want to take a detour? Let me tell you, if you want to go the long way around, you two go ahead. I can't walk that much anymore. I'll take the shortcut." He reminisced about our days as Red Guards, going up to the mountains and down to the countryside. "Back then, what were you ever afraid of? Over those years, who did we ever yield to?"

 I found myself at a loss for words, as if what Fatty had said was true. In the past, I was the type to use the falling sky as a blanket. But since enlisting in the army, all the way through China's Counterattack in Self-Defense Against Vietnam, I witnessed comrades-in-arms fall one after another. I've seen bloodshed and death time and again. To be frank, I have indeed become somewhat overcautious, always looking before I leap. Could it be that the passage of years has indeed swept away my courage and audacity?

I said to Fatty, "How old are we now? We can't compare to the past. When we were Red Guards, we were indeed fierce and ruthless, ready to fight anyone who crossed us. But that was a ridiculous era, and looking back now, it all seems both laughable and tragic."

Fatty replied, "But at least in that era, you fought and charged. I can't stand to see you all jittery now. Do you remember the long poem I wrote in the notebook I gave you for your sixteenth birthday?"

That notebook was probably long gone by now. Over the years, Fatty had given me many notebooks since his mother worked at a government logistics agency and had all sorts of notebooks at home. I really couldn't recall any long poem.

Seeing that I couldn't remember, Fatty decided to recite a few lines for me. His Mandarin was impeccable, and his voice, deep and resonant, carried the authority of a national radio broadcaster. He began to recite with fervor:

"Together in the park, we played at guerrillas, side by side in class, we read our books. On Xianyang Road, we smashed the 'Four Olds', and together we joined the grand link-up at Jinggangshan.

On the eve of burying imperialism, revisionism, and reactionaries, before marching into the world, by the radio, we listened intently, to the Ministry of National Defense's declaration of war, each word and phrase."

After Fatty's impassioned start, I immediately remembered. It was a narrative long poem titled "A Salute to the Warriors in the Third World War," widely circulated among the Red Guards. We knew it too well. When we were Red Guards, how many times had we recited it together? Hundreds, thousands. It was our favorite rhythm, our dearest words, our most youthful and magnificent dreams. My emotions were stirred, and forgetting where I was, I clenched my fists and joined him, reciting in unison:

"On that unforgettable night, the longing for battle coursed through every vein.

Our fathers' fervor inspired us, thrilling our hearts. We are the offspring of soldiers, destined to gallop through the flames and gun smoke."

 During the Third World War, which sought to eradicate the last vestiges of exploitation, we were assigned to the same unit.

Our friendship began there, its duration beyond reckoning, only knowing it surpassed mountains in height and outstretched roads in length.

In the trenches, we shared a loaf of bread, licked a handful of salt together.

Humming the same tune, we were covered by the same military blanket.

Word by word, line by line, we repeatedly studied the thoughts of our leader, the great truths.

Beneath the red flag, with sincere devotion to the Party and a fervent desire to dedicate ourselves,

We gripped our rifles, raised our fists, and made an ironclad vow: we were willing to give our all for the cause.

In the blaze of artillery fire, we advanced shoulder to shoulder, storming the enemy's three-hundred-meter line,

Our submachine guns spewing the proletariat's vengeance in bullets.

Do you remember how we drank from the waters of the Don, crossed the Ukrainian grasslands, scaled the Ural Plateau, and rekindled the red star atop the Kremlin?

We followed the footsteps of the Commune, through the streets and alleys of Paris, charged through every town, village, and harbor of Europa to the rhythm of "The Internationale."

We used Jerusalem's Wailing Wall to block the venomous bullets of Christians, planting the red flag on the banks of the Suez.

The shimmering lakes of Switzerland, the lights of Pisa, the twilight of Yemen, the temples of Phnom Penh, the cherry blossoms of Mount Fuji, the hearth smoke of Havana, the red wine of Spain, the clear springs of Black Africa,

All these never tempted us to linger.

For we each had a steel gun in hand, a heavy responsibility on our shoulders.

Countless sleepless days and nights, countless blood-soaked campaigns from south to north.

Thus, our invincible ranks followed the red sun, pressing forward without end.

Listen: the call of brothers from all continents, like a surging torrent, a mighty roar.

Look: the flags of liberty of slaves from all seas, like sparks setting the prairie ablaze.

Ah, the world is awash in red, with only the White House remaining a speck.

Three red flares rise in the night sky, you pat my shoulder: "Comrade, do you remember the words of a Politburo member on the battlefield in America, seeing the fervor of the children, the world's friends rejoicing at the prospect of liberation, the expectant eyes of the old Red Army of the Soviet Union?"

Remember, this is the final struggle, the decisive battle for the fate of humanity is today.

The bugle has sounded, our hearts united in resolve, we charge forward like a gale.

One hand holds a green leaf, the other a poisoned arrow, this brass eagle emblem that has dominated for two centuries,

Is cast into the roaring flames amidst the victorious cheers of the people.

Yingzi, seeing us talk endlessly and not understanding a word, grows impatient and interrupts: "What are you two going on about so animatedly? It's getting late; no matter which path we take, it's time to set off. If you wish to continue, you can do so once we're outside, alright?"

Fatty picks up his Type 100 submachine gun, tucks several magazines into his belt, his expression resolute, and gestures forward: "Comrades, victory lies ahead. Follow me."

 Thus, Fatty took the lead, Yingzi held the middle, and I brought up the rear. In single file, the three of us advanced towards the passage where Yingzi had seen the child run through. It was a gently sloping path that, after a hundred meters or so, transformed into ascending steps, indicating that we were venturing into the hillsides of Wildman Gully.

The passage narrowed as we went, and the humidity increased significantly, making breathing laborious and lending an oppressive sensation akin to being buried alive.

We were close together when, without warning, Fatty halted in his tracks. Caught off guard, Yingzi, following directly behind, collided with his back. The impact sent Yingzi tumbling backward down the steps, but I quickly reached out to steady her. "What's going on? Why did you suddenly stop?" I asked Fatty.

Fatty turned around and shouted, "Run back! Run!" His voice had changed, tinged with terror, the bravado from earlier completely dissipated.

Secret Fortress of the Kwantung Army 3

Fatty was urging us to flee for our lives. From behind the other two, my flashlight's limited range couldn't reveal much, but I could make out a large open space at the top of four or five steps ahead. Uncertain of what he had seen, I nevertheless trusted Fatty's instinct and prepared to retreat.

Simultaneously, I felt dozens of icy needles piercing my back, a chill penetrating to the bone, as if struck by a frigid electric current. My body shuddered uncontrollably, and with a sudden burst of strength, I leaped forward, pushing both Fatty and Yingzi ahead of me. We tumbled and rolled up the inclined, gloomy corridor, crashing into the cavity at the stairway's end.

Mysteriously electrified, it seemed the current had also spread to the others, leaving us all quaking and teeth chattering, none of us understanding what had just happened. We tried to speak but found no voice. If it were an accidental brush with a live wire, one would expect numbness, not this bone-deep, outward radiating cold.

Fortunately, the three loaded submachine guns we carried did not discharge in the chaos. Lying on the ground, our flashlights still on, the beams revealed why Fatty had turned to run. We were in a vast stone chamber, half natural, half man-made, covered in green moss. The damp stone walls and ceiling were festooned with countless enormous bats, far larger than any ordinary bats we'd seen. Disturbed by our intrusion, they awoke from their slumber, unfurling their wings and revealing rows of white, fearsome tusks that made one's scalp tingle at the sight.

 Bat had a peculiar face, with two diamond-shaped ears standing erect, a round head, and a round nose. His limbs were remarkably long, with elongated upper arms, forearms, metacarpals, and phalanges. His teeth and claws were sharp and deadly. During my time as a combat engineer in the Kunlun Mountains, I encountered such large bats. Known scientifically as Macroderma gigas, also called the ghost bat, they are a bloodthirsty and carnivorous species, one of the most ferocious among bats. They prefer to dwell in the subterranean caverns of grasslands in pastoral regions, emerging at night to prey on livestock such as cattle and sheep. Especially in the grasslands of Outer Mongolia, they once caused great trouble, but sightings of these creatures have been rare over the past decade or so.

I had thought them extinct, yet here was a multitude of ghost bats making their lair in an abandoned underground fortress of the Kwantung Army. They roosted by day and ventured out at night, using the fortress's ventilation holes as exits—a nest more secure and comfortable than any other.

Several ghost bats had already taken flight from the stone walls. I struggled to rise, but as I pushed off the ground, I slipped on a mixture of bat guano and animal remains. The stench was overpowering, and the ground was sticky and slick. Bat guano, also known as saltpeter, is a highly prized ingredient in traditional medicine. Hard to come by in small quantities, it was utterly repulsive to see it in such abundance.

Abandoning the effort to stand, I curled my finger around the trigger of my Type 100 submachine gun and opened fire on the approaching ghost bats. As I began shooting, the other two regained their senses, and our three submachine guns created a crisscrossing barrage. The muzzle flashes and the streaks of bullets lit up the stone cave in alternating brightness and shadow, while the cacophony of gunfire, the clinking of ejected casings, and the thud of spent shells hitting the ground melded together.

Thousands of ghost bats were now in tumult, these creatures of darkness terrified of fire and light. Aside from those struck by bullets and plummeting to the ground, the rest swarmed like dark clouds—some flying over our heads, others scrambling up through the ventilation holes.

Our submachine gun bullets were quickly expended, with no time to reload. The ghost bats whizzed past, their sharp claws and tusks tearing our clothes into shreds. Fortunately, our thick attire prevented deep wounds, though some scratches did break the skin.

Fear gripped me more than the physical pain. I was terrified of losing my eyesight and dared not open my eyes. With one hand shielding my head and face, I wielded the submachine gun with the other, swinging it wildly as if it were a club, while my legs kicked frantically to fend off the ghost bats diving at me.

 Time had become a blur when the cave finally quieted down, presumably as the pig-faced Large Bats had all fled. Fumbling for the flashlight that had fallen to the ground, I was about to call out to Fatty and the others to check if they were injured.

Suddenly, darkness loomed before me as the largest of the pig-faced Large Bats descended silently towards my head. It must have been the leader of the cave's bat population, having concealed itself in the deepest recesses of the Stone Cave. Now, it made its late appearance, its wings unfurling to fill the entire wall.

Armed with nothing more than an empty gun and a flashlight, I was defenseless. The beast was mere inches away, its porcine face with its layers of wrinkled skin and hard bristles and tusks was terrifyingly clear. Just as I was about to be bitten by the Large Bat, a burst of submachine gun fire erupted from beside me. A volley of bullets struck the pig-faced Large Bat, which fell to the ground with a few final flutters and died.

It turned out that Fatty, sensing the urgency of the situation, had reloaded and opened fire, saving my life. I exhaled deeply and surveyed our surroundings. Apart from a few Large Bats on the ground that had been shot and were still struggling, there were no other hidden Bats left.

Several gashes on my body were bleeding profusely. Yingzi and Fatty too had sustained minor injuries, but nothing serious. Yingzi tore some strips of cloth from her clothing to bandage my wounds.

The pain from my injuries was intense, and I couldn't help but curse. Back in my days on the front lines, amidst the hail of bullets, I hadn't suffered a scratch, and now these beasts had torn so many gashes in me—it was excruciating.

Fatty asked me, "Old Hu, when I told you guys to run back just now, why did you end up pushing us further in?"

I recounted the incident but only mentioned that my back might have brushed against some exposed wires and received an electric shock. I didn't dare tell them the truth because even I found it unbelievable. I asked Yingzi to check my back for burns. When Yingzi pulled back my shirt and shone the flashlight on it, she exclaimed, "Oh my goodness, Brother Hu, what happened to you? This doesn't look like an electric burn."

Fatty also leaned in to inspect my back: "You've been electrocuted? There's a black handprint on your back, but it's small, like that of a child."

Damn it, it was as if we'd encountered a real ghost. It seemed we were pushed into this Bat Cave by that little ghost. "Don't let me see it," I muttered, "if I do, I'll skin it alive."

Just as Fatty was about to speak, his flashlight dropped to the ground: "Oh my god, Old Hu, Yingzi, back at the Gena Warehouse, I didn't believe you, but now I've seen a child run past too."

 Yingzi and I hastily grabbed our flashlights and shone them around, but aside from bat droppings and carcasses, there were no signs of any child.

Fatty swore to the heavens, "You all saw him run behind you, I'd be lying if I were your grandson. He ran inwards, I saw it clearly—a little boy, just a kid, wearing green, about five or six years old, with an unusually pale face, not like a living person."

Apart from me, they had all seen a child in this underground fortress. Why was it that only I hadn't seen him? Yet, the handprint of the child I had felt on my back was undeniably chilling. Fatty claimed to have seen a boy, while Yingzi insisted it was a little girl she saw in the Gena Warehouse. Who was mistaken, or was this underground fortress running a nursery?

We tidied up a bit and stood up, loading new magazines into our submachine guns. Fatty pointed to a wall of the stone chamber, "That little rascal ran right in here." After saying so, he used the butt of his gun to scrape away the moss and bat droppings on the wall, revealing a half-covered iron door, its surface mottled with rust and emblazoned with four striking characters in dark red paint: No Entry Allowed.

"Secret Fortress of the Kwantung Army 4."

Forbidden Child read aloud the characters on the door and then said to us, "Do you know what this means? It's saying you can't walk in, if you want to enter, you have to lie down—probably a morgue or a cremation furnace."

Upon hearing Fatty's explanation, Yingzi commented, "So 'No Entry Allowed' is meant for the dead. I've heard the elders in the village talk about these ghostly cremation furnaces—this iron door must lead to one."

I rapped on the iron door with my knuckles, feeling its heft, "Fatty, don't pretend to know what you don't. These four characters likely mean 'entry prohibited.' Although I'm not versed in Japanese, I'm quite familiar with military facilities. Look here, there's a large recess at the bottom of the door with inner hexagonal gong patterns; it must require a turntable to open this door. The hole at the bottom is an exhaust groove; this is an airtight door. When the door is closed, the exhaust vent automatically sucks out the air from inside, creating a semi-vacuum environment. It's a place for storing valuable items. Our military bases have similar facilities."

 The airtight door's wheel had long been dismantled, and without the proper tools, prying open this iron gate was as daunting as scaling the azure heavens. As for what lay within the Secret Chamber, that was anyone's guess. It was quite likely to house items such as Chemical Weapons or Bacterial Weapons, given that such hazardous materials were typically stored in Sealed Secret Chambers to prevent accidental leaks.

Japanese Chemical and Bacterial Weapons, notorious though they were, should not be underestimated. Even after many years in the natural environment, they retained their lethal potency. However, I had no interest in the contents behind that door. Consulting the map to swiftly locate an exit seemed the more prudent course of action.

Fatty, on the other hand, was brimming with curiosity about the door, especially after I mentioned the possibility of valuable items being stored behind it. His interest piqued, he and Yingzi took turns knocking and kicking at the door, their behavior suggesting an unyielding resolve to see what lay beyond. They murmured to each other in frustration, "What treasures could be inside? Ah, it's so aggravating not to be able to see."

I paid them no further mind, instead focusing on matching the map to the exit within this Stone Cave, once the dominion of the pig-faced Large Bats. According to the topography depicted on the map, there should be a Small Passage within this cave that led to an exit at the mountain's peak.

Yet, despite my searching, I found only a massive pile of collapsed boulders at one end of the Stone Cave. As expected, the Japanese Army had demolished the Fortress's exits during their retreat.

Our current position was directly beneath the spot where we had pitched our tents on the slopes of Wildman Gully. Shining a flashlight upwards revealed several large holes in the cave's ceiling. These sizable ventilation shafts were not straight but twisted and turned to prevent external attacks. It was through these openings that the Bats took flight. Alas, we lacked Wings, and even if we could reach them, it would be futile; the ventilation holes were crafted just small enough to prevent an adult's passage. The Little Japanese had been cunning, fearing enemies might crawl through these shafts into the Fortress, they had designed the openings to be neither too large nor too small.

I called Fatty and Yingzi over to inform them that the exit was blocked. We had two choices: either search for another way out or take our Submachine Guns back to the ancient tomb and eliminate the Corpse Demon. We couldn't afford to waste time here; we had no provisions and had seen no sign of food within the Ghostly Fortress. If we continued aimlessly, we would eventually be too weak to crawl, leaving us nothing but to await death.

 The situation was clear: the underground fortress extended deep and wide, spanning dozens of kilometers. Walking from one exit to another would take a considerable amount of time, and searching for another exit was now pointless. The Japanese wouldn't have kindly left an exit open; if they had collapsed one, the rest were surely destroyed as well.

Yingzi kicked the corpse of a large bat on the ground: "If it really comes down to it, we could eat this thing. It's all meat."

Fatty shook his head vigorously: "You guys can eat it if you want to. I'd rather starve than touch that. It's damn disgusting. I bet the meat is either rotten or sour, and definitely not palatable. By the way, Old Hu, do you think the exit might be behind that iron door? It seems possible. Let's find a way to open it and see."

After some thought, I said, "That possibility does exist. The secret chamber isn't marked on the map, only a passage that leads to an exit. But it's hard to pinpoint the location accurately, and we can't be sure that the passage is behind that door. Opening the door isn't difficult, though. I saw some tools in the Gena Warehouse; we can go find a hexagonal wrench of the right size."

Yingzi chimed in: "Going back to the Gena Warehouse is perfect for grabbing some clothes to change into. Just look at the state of us three, we're filthy enough for fifteen people to stare at for half a month."

Her reminder made us realize just how dirty we had become. Our clothes, hair, faces, and hands were all smothered with the overpowering stench of bat dung.

We then made our way back to the lower-level Gena Warehouse, which was only a few hundred meters away. At the Gena Warehouse, we first found some Kwantung Army military uniforms and coats to change into, wiping the dirt and bloodstains from our faces as best we could. Each of us also picked out a steel helmet to buckle onto our heads.

Yingzi, naturally handsome, looked even more striking in the military attire. Fatty applauded her appearance: "Girl, you in that Japanese military uniform, you're the spitting image of Yoshiko Kawashima."

 Yingzi had no idea who Yoshiko Kawashima was and mistook Fatty's words for a compliment, basking in the praise. I had to tell Yingzi, "He's saying you resemble a Japanese female spy."

On hearing this, Yingzi's eyebrows shot up in indignation, and Fatty quickly corrected himself, "I misspoke, I misspoke. What I meant was that seeing Yingzi in military attire, armed with a rifle, reminds me of the poem: 'At dawn, the drill grounds gleam, a striking figure with a five-foot gun, the children of China possess remarkable ambitions, eschewing rouge for the love of arms.'"

Laughing, I added, "Fatty's practically a poet these days, always ready to recite a few lines. Look at us now, in these outfits, we're just like the Japanese devils. This reminds me of a story told by one of my father's old comrades-in-arms. I was just a kid back then. My uncle, who had served with my father in Shandong with the Eighth Route Army, recounted that after the victory, they received instructions from the Central Party Committee to sail from the Jiaodong Peninsula to the Northeast to receive the fruits of victory. My father couldn't go because he got seasick and regretted it deeply, especially after hearing how the Northeast was full of foreign goods. My uncle said that when they arrived in the Northeast, they found a treasure trove of Japanese goods. His whole unit, dressed in tatters like a band of beggars, ended up taking over a Kwantung Army warehouse from the Russians. They all got new outfits; aside from the Chinese flag, everything from their clothes to their shoes and weapons was Japanese, identical to the Kwantung Army. The locals, seeing them from a distance, turned tail and ran, thinking the ghosts had returned. I feel like we now share a bit of the sensation our revolutionary forebears had when they picked up those foreign leftovers."

As I spoke, I found a hexagonal wrench on a shelf storing gasoline drums: "Now we're all set, we've got everything we need. Let's move out quickly."

The three of us, dressed in Kwantung Army uniforms and carrying Type 100 Submachine Guns, retraced our steps. I covered the rear again, and this time, Fatty and the others didn't mention seeing any shadowy figures of children. I didn't ask, but shadows of doubt and ghosts of suspicion flickered through my mind.

 Inwardly, I mused: Fatty said the child ran into the iron gate. What exactly is this little ghost up to? Is it trying to show us the way out? Could we be so lucky? Or does it have other schemes in mind? Damn it, I still have a bit of glutinous rice left. It's said that ghosts fear glutinous rice. If that little ghost dares to cause trouble, I'll make sure it regrets coming and ensure its hasty retreat. Otherwise, it wouldn't showcase Old Hu's skills.

As I walked alongside them, I bolstered my confidence. The wound on my back seemed to hurt less. Before long, we arrived for the second time at the stone cave with the airtight door.

To be safe, we all donned steel helmets and gas masks, pulled back the gun bolts, and chambered the bullets. Before opening the door, I had Yingzi grab a handful of glutinous rice ready to scatter and instructed Fatty to aim the submachine gun, ready to shoot anything that might be inside the door without hesitation. Additionally, I advised Fatty to coordinate with me, taking turns firing to avoid any gaps in reloading magazines.

Once everything was arranged, I slung the submachine gun over my shoulder, clutched the hexagonal wrench onto the door's rusted threads, and turned with all my might. The secret door hadn't been opened for decades, and the threads were rusted solid.

I exerted all my strength, nearly breaking the wrench, until finally, I heard the creaking and groaning of metal, and with a hiss, the three exhaust grooves beneath the door allowed air to fill the airtight chamber, and the iron door began to crack and creak open.

Secret Fortress of the Kwantung Army 5

As the air slots in the airtight door filled with air, the heavy iron door swung open. I hastily stepped back two paces, raised my submachine gun and flashlight to the doorway, but inside, all was eerily still.

The situation was unexpected. Beyond the door lay impenetrable darkness, and the beam of the flashlight seemed to be devoured by the blackness inside.

I signaled to Yingzi, who understood and scattered a handful of glutinous rice into the secret chamber like a celestial maiden casting flowers. Yet still, the secret chamber remained silent, as if all the sounds in the world had vanished, leaving only the heavy breathing from within my gas mask.

It seemed we had been overly cautious. As the saying goes, suspicion breeds phantoms, and before anything had even happened, we had scared ourselves half to death.

Unable to contain himself any longer, Fatty took the lead and entered the secret chamber, with Yingzi and me following closely, filing in one after another.

 The Secret Chamber was a solitary room, roughly forty square meters in size, with no other exits save for an airtight door.

What it contained was neither bacterial nor chemical weapons. Before entering, I had conjured up every possibility, except for what actually lay before us—more than a dozen large coffins haphazardly strewn about the Secret Chamber. Time had eaten away at these coffins; some were rotting, varying in size, craftsmanship, and style, including an enormous stone coffin. The most luxurious among them were two made of Phoebe Nanmu, a type of precious wood, and the ground was littered with countless shards of pottery and porcelain.

I turned to look at Fatty and the others; they shook their heads at me, their faces a picture of bewilderment, even behind their gas masks.

Fatty asked me, "Old Hu, what's going on? It's like a museum. Where did all these coffins come from?"

After a moment's thought, the answer wasn't hard to deduce, though our preconceived notions had blinded us to it.

Wildman Gully was originally an ancient tomb cluster from the Jin-Liao period. When the Kwantung Army constructed this secret underground fortress, particularly the three passages connecting the two sides of the fortress that cut right through the valley of Wildman Gully, they must have unearthed a number of ancient tombs during the construction. The burial artifacts and coffins of the Jin-Liao nobility were treasures to the Japanese. They stored everything excavated from the tombs in this semi-vacuum Secret Chamber. The Kwantung Army's retreat was hasty; they only managed to roll up and take the antique burial objects, leaving these coffins behind.

Fatty remarked, "The Japanese sure knew how to take advantage of a situation, leaving nothing behind for us. Let's see if there's anything valuable left inside these coffins. It would make this trip worthwhile." With that, he kicked open the lid of a large coffin. The lid had already been pried open by the Japanese and was not nailed back on; a single kick sent it clattering to the side.

Yingzi, a personal name, didn't dare come over to look. "I'll wait for you two at the door. I'll keep watch, make sure no one locks us all in here," she said, then walked to the doorway, standing with one foot inside and the other out, guarding the entrance.

I called out to Yingzi at the door, "You're always so astute, big sister. I hadn't even considered that. After all these years as a soldier, it's embarrassing to admit. This door can only be opened from the outside. If we were all trapped in this Secret Chamber, we'd be in quite a predicament, with no tears enough to find a way out."

 Fatty was rummaging through the coffin with reckless abandon, cursing as he went: "Nothing but bone fragments; those Japanese devils really had no decency, implementing their 'Three Alls Policy' wherever they went, not even leaving a single intact jar behind for us."

After turning over three or four coffins to the same end, Fatty was cursing nonstop, then he went to push against a vermilion lacquered coffin made of precious Phoebe nanmu wood.

I didn't pay much attention to the ordinary coffins; my gaze was constantly drawn to a massive stone coffin. Intuition told me there was something inside.

I couldn't understand why I felt this way, but suddenly I was overwhelmed with the urge to open the stone coffin. I called Fatty over to help, and together we pushed against the slab of stone on top. It was exceptionally heavy, and after much effort, we only managed to create a narrow gap.

Panting heavily, Fatty waved his hand: "Let's take a break; it's too heavy. I can't push without something in my stomach."

My own stomach was growling with hunger, and exerting myself only made stars dance before my eyes, so I sat down to rest as well. We took off our gas masks and each lit a cigarette.

Blowing out a ring of smoke, Fatty said: "Old Hu, do you think the ancients had water in their brains? Making a coffin out of stone, I've never seen anyone use stone for a coffin before."

I stroked the stone slab and said: "This isn't just a coffin; it's a stone sarcophagus. Coffin, coffin—the wooden coffin is inside this stone chest. Whoever enjoyed such a burial was certainly high-ranking, perhaps even a prince."

Scratching his head, Fatty said: "I see, it's quite complex. We're all buried in Wildman Gully, but compared to the one we dug up, the general's tomb, who had a higher rank, the occupant of this stone coffin or the general?"

I shook my head: "Hard to say, we're not well-versed in history. But during the several hundred years of the Jin, Liao, and Yuan dynasties, the nomadic tribes of the north were unprecedentedly powerful. They won their empires from horseback, so I suspect it was those with the highest military honors who were buried in this prime feng shui treasure land. The nobles buried nearby might have burial artifacts even richer than those in the general's tomb. The tomb master's personal tastes in life varied, so the burial artifacts would certainly differ. Take the ancient tomb we excavated; the tomb master was a mere warrior, lacking in sophisticated taste and artistic appreciation, which is why the items in his tomb were mostly horses and weapons."

 Fatty remarked, "Actually, those horses must have been exceptional breeds, worth a fortune if they were still alive. But now, only their bones remain, which I bet even the scrapyard wouldn't want. It's a good thing he still had two jade bi discs; otherwise, we would've been toiling in vain. These two jade bi discs can be taken to Big Gold Tooth to find a buyer. At the very least, they should fetch a tidy sum."

As we finished speaking, our cigarettes had burned down to the filters. We donned our gas masks once more, braced ourselves, and pushed the massive stone slab again. Yingzi came over to help, and at last, we managed to move the slab aside, revealing a coffin of pure black beneath. This coffin was nearly twice the size of an ordinary one and unusually tall. Not counting the arched lid, it stood more than half a person tall.

The craftsmanship of the coffin was exquisite, far from ordinary. Around both ends and the sides of the lid were colorful, gold-trimmed paintings of auspicious mythical beasts—cranes, qilins, turtles, and snakes—all intended to bless the person within, that they might ascend to immortality after death. The lid also bore a celestial map of the twenty-eight constellations, and a ring of cloud patterns adorned the base of the coffin in gold. Whatever secret technique was used, the colors remained as vibrant as if new, even after centuries, truly a sight to behold.

We had never before seen such a lavishly magnificent coffin. Had we not witnessed it with our own eyes, we could never have imagined that such an artful and grand casket existed in the world.

Fatty was overjoyed, "Even if there's nothing inside, we could make a fortune just by selling this coffin." He rolled up his sleeves and slid the coffin lid open.

Even Yingzi couldn't resist the urge to see what lay within this great coffin. The three of us gathered around, shining our flashlights inside. The brocade silk lining had long since decayed, likely to turn to ash upon touch. Resting atop the layers of rotten fabric was a skeleton, its flesh and clothing disintegrated over the millennia, leaving only the skull somewhat intact, its jaws wide open, revealing two rows of black, decayed teeth. Much of the skeleton had disintegrated into the air, and without the skull, it might have been impossible to discern that these were human remains.

Yingzi swept the beam of her flashlight along the edge of the giant coffin and screamed in shock, "Oh my goodness, it's the children!"

At each end of the coffin stood a naked boy and girl, looking to be about five or six years old, lifelike in appearance. The boy had a topknot while the girl's hair was done up in two buns—a style far from modern, more akin to ancient figures in wall paintings. Could they be the sacrificial boy and girl servants meant to accompany the master of the coffin in death? With the master almost completely decomposed, how could these boy and girl servants have been preserved so perfectly?

Secret Fortress of the Kwantung Army 6

 "These two little brats are probably fakes, made to look so lifelike." As Fatty spoke, he reached out to pinch one of the children in the giant coffin. "Today, old Fatty is going to see for himself if these little buggers have really become enchanted or what."

I quickly grabbed Fatty's hand to stop him. "Don't touch without gloves, it could be poisonous. Take a closer look at these kids' skin, it's all covered in patches of bluish-purple Mercury Blisters. That's Mercurial Sore."

Back in the fifties, my grandfather, Hu Guohua, stayed in a major hospital in Beijing for a while due to an illness. During his stay, construction for the Workers' Stadium nearby was underway, and an ancient tomb was unearthed at the site. He sneaked out of the hospital to join the crowd and ventured into the Underground Palace for a look.

The tomb was said to belong to a prince from the Ming Dynasty, surrounded by a moat of dark water. The Underground Palace's Tomb Chamber was divided into three sections: front, middle, and rear. A Thousand Jin Gate hung at the entrance. Passing through the gate, one first entered a hall that mirrored the layout of the Tomb Master's family home, complete with various pieces of furniture, known as Burial Artifacts.

Further inside, the central Tomb Chamber, referred to as the resting hall, was where the Coffins were placed. This ancient tomb was a Joint Burial Tomb, and what was particularly special was that the coffins of the Tomb Master and his consort, the prince and princess, were suspended in mid-air, locked with Large Iron Chains, copper rings, and locks.

The rear section was the auxiliary chamber, specifically for storing Burial Artifacts.

Not long after, another ancient tomb from the Yuan Dynasty was unearthed in Haidian, and both tombs contained the remains of Boy and Girl Servants who were buried alive. When excavated, they looked identical to living humans, except that the clothes on the boy and girl servants from the Yuan Dynasty tomb turned to ash upon touch.

Later, my grandfather recounted these two events to me as stories. He said that while these Boy and Girl Servants were alive, in addition to ingesting mercury, they had holes drilled into the Top of the head, back, and soles of the feet, which were then filled with mercury. After death, their bodies were coated with Mercury Powder, turning them into specimens that, even after thousands of years, their flesh did not decay. This technique was far more advanced than the mummies of ancient Egypt. However, the two civilizations had different backgrounds and Value Orientations. Moreover, to preserve the appearance of a corpse using Mercury Injection, living subjects were required, as the blood circulation in a deceased could not facilitate the infusion, which is why this technique was never used on any Tomb Master.

 Perhaps the cruelest act in the world is to bury the living with the dead. Fatty, donning gloves, lifted the body of one of the children, examining it closely. Indeed, atop the head, on the back, and under the feet, several holes were revealed. These openings in the bodies had been carefully sealed by skilled craftsmen using fire lacquer. Many areas on the corpses displayed patches of black and purple pockmarks. Burial companions or gold, silver, and jade artifacts were often coated with mercury powder, which, over time, would undergo chemical changes. In more recent cases, the color would appear as a reddish-brown, while in older instances, it would turn black and purple. These mercury blisters were commonly known as mercurial sores or mercury soaks, and in some places, the term for the corpse's condition was 'rotten yinzi', a term for mercury sulfide.

Fatty was clearly a bit nervous. Attempting to appear calm, he sighed and said, "I've read about mercury soaks on antiques in Lu Xun's writings. It seems that the old fellow didn't just make it up; there is truth to it."

Yingzi inquired, "This is just too pitiful. Hu Ge, why haven't they dressed these boy and girl servants? I remember the child I saw running by earlier was wearing clothes. Could it be a ghost's spirit?"

I told her, "Only they themselves would know if they are spirits. But it's not that these two children are undressed. Burial objects, including boy and girl servants, would have certainly been dressed in finery. After nearly a thousand years, by now, those clothes would have rotted away. After so many years, this giant coffin is likely from the Yuan Dynasty. The moment the Kwantung Army unearthed and opened this large casket, the clothes would have turned to dust upon contact with the air."

I never believed in ghosts, but sometimes the ironclad facts before you leave no room for doubt. Fatty and Yingzi saw the figure of a child in the passageway, identical to the pair of boy and girl servants buried with the coffin. And then there was the handprint on my back. The facts here were beyond human comprehension. Perhaps one could explain it as a sixth sense response, a premonition, or the like. In any case, all these belonged to natural phenomena. With our limited understanding, we could only catch a glimpse into the shadows of this mysterious and unfathomable unknown world.

However, the spirits of these two children led us here, seemingly without any malicious intent.

Yingzi said, "Maybe they want us to give them a proper burial. It's often said that being buried brings peace. Why don't we help them? It's so very sad."

 Fatty nodded in agreement, "I'm only in it for the treasure, not to meddle in sundry matters, but this time the situation is special. Let's do a good deed and bury them properly, rather than leaving them exposed like this. They've stood guard for the Tomb Master for a millennium; it's time for them to rest."

"The bodies are filled with mercury; they can't be burnt away. All we can do is dig a grave and bury them, hoping the world will see fewer such tragedies."

Without further delay, Fatty and I took off the Kwantung Army Greatcoats we were wearing, wrapped the Boy and Girl Servants in them, tied them up, and hoisted them onto our backs. The bodies, heavy with mercury, were dead weight. Thankfully, they were children; had they been adults, carrying even one would have been a struggle.

Seeing no valuable treasure, Fatty was somewhat displeased, almost wishing to set all the coffins ablaze. Yingzi and I quickly dissuaded him, and he reluctantly gave up the idea.

We returned to the Stone Cave to discuss our escape. Hunger and thirst tormented us, and it was all the more frustrating that the Underground Fortress offered neither food nor water, and we had no explosives or shells. Our only way back to the surface was through the General's Tomb's robbery tunnel. But the thought of the Corpse Demon's monstrous strength gave us a headache; even well-fed, we might not be a match for it, let alone now, weakened by hunger.

The three of us exchanged glances, our thoughts aligning. With over a dozen Dead Bats on the ground, we had no choice but to consume these creatures to appease our hunger.

Humans are omnivores by nature, and when driven by desperation, there's nothing we can't eat. Yingzi recounted how she had eaten bats with her grandfather in a cave deep within an ancient forest during her youth. A forest fire had coincided with a rare famine, driving away the larger animals. People resorted to eating ground mice, bats, locusts, and grasshoppers. She claimed that bat tendons and crunchy bones were quite tasty, with a satisfying chew.

The Large Bats in the Stone Cave, with their gaunt frames and sinister, ferocious appearances, looked like mummies of blood-sucking demons. Fatty and I were skeptical about the palatability of their flesh.

But survival trumped all, and we couldn't be choosy. To cook them, we'd have to return to the Gena Warehouse, where plenty of wooden crates could serve as firewood. Of course, coffin planks could also be burned, but the idea of eating meat roasted over coffin wood was somewhat unsettling. So Fatty used the rope he carried to pick out five or six plump Dead Bats, tied their feet together, strung them up, and dragged them along, including the sizable Bat King among them.

 After returning to the Gena Warehouse, I set aside the overcoat that was wrapped around the Boy and Girl Servants. Yingzi drew a short knife and cut off the Bat's ugly Head, its fleshless claws, and then proceeded to gut it, discarding the clumps of blue-grey intestines and the excess offal from the stomach of the pig-faced Large Bat. Finally, she carelessly skinned it.

I found a large pile of wooden crates and kicked them into planks, then whittled some shavings with a knife. I struck a match to ignite the shavings, starting a fire with Fatty assisting by my side, squatting on the ground, rolling up his sleeves to blow on the flames, fanning them larger.

We found several bayonets from rifles to skewer the Bat and set it over the fire to roast. Fatty frowned, clearly reluctant to eat such a thing.

Yingzi encouraged him, "It's not bad. Don't think of it as Bat. Chew it a bit more, and it'll taste just like mutton."

I didn't mind. Isn't a Bat just like a rat? When the troops were on maneuvers in Shaanxi, I ate all sorts of rodents—ground mice, dormice, flying squirrels, field mice, masked palm civets, and the like. They all tasted pretty similar, with layers of fat and lean meat that indeed resembled mutton. However, I had never tried Bat meat before.

The pig-faced Large Bat is a warm-blooded creature with not much fat, so it shouldn't be overcooked. Once the meat looked done, I tried a piece from the shoulder—it was crispy, filled with sinew and cartilage, not as delicious as mutton but certainly chewy.

Seeing me eat, Fatty also pinched his nose and took a bite, finding it quite satisfactory. He then devoured one whole, and still not satisfied, he skewered the largest Bat King on a bayonet to roast.

When we had eaten about half, a string of sticky, glistening liquid dripped down from the roof right above Fatty's head, landing squarely on his face. Caught up in his feasting, Fatty felt his face wet and wiped it casually, exclaiming, "How did so much drool end up on my head?"

Secret Fortress of the Kwantung Army 7

Fatty, with his mouth greased from eating, felt the dripping mucus land on his face. He cursed without thinking, "How did so much drool end up on my head?" As soon as he said it, he realized something was off.

There were only three of us in the Underground Fortress—Yingzi and I were sitting opposite him. Even with all the skill in the world, we couldn't possibly drool on his head.

All three of us felt it strange and looked up simultaneously, wondering what could be dripping. The fire, fueled by the broken ammo crates and wooden planks, lit up the surroundings brightly. Beyond the reach of the firelight, darkness remained, a silent and lonely blackness.

 Above us, at the juncture of firelight and darkness on the rooftop, emerged an enormous human face, twice the size of an ordinary person's. It was so pale it seemed as if it had been smeared with flour, devoid of any expression, making it impossible to discern joy from anger. With a hooked nose and a pair of blood-red, strange eyes, it fixed its gaze intently on the roasted bat meat in Fatty's hand. Its lips were thick and large, protruding forward, and its gaping black maw was open, with half of its blood-red tongue hanging out, saliva nearly forming a river, dripping down in a steady stream.

The owner of that face had a long neck, with skin both dark and tough. Due to the high ceiling of the underground Gena Warehouse, the rest of its body was concealed in darkness, leaving only its face and a portion of its neck visible. It seemed very interested in the roasted bat meat we were eating, as if it wanted to swoop down and snatch it away, yet it hesitated, fearful of the flames burning below.

However, it appeared that the aroma of the roasted meat was too tempting to resist, and it looked as if it could no longer contain itself, ready to leap down from the inverted roof at any moment.

As the three of us looked up, we were both startled and amazed. Although I had no knowledge of this creature's origins, I could tell that it wanted the roasted bat meat.

We had brought a total of five large bats from the Stone Cave. Yingzi and I had each eaten half, while Fatty had consumed one whole bat by himself, leaving three remaining. Fatty had divided the largest bat, the Bat King, into three parts, skewering one portion on the bayonet of his rifle, now roasting it over the fire.

This pig-faced Bat King, who knows how many centuries it had lived, was frighteningly large. Not counting its wings, its body alone was the size of a five or six-year-old child, and quite hefty. Our fire for roasting the meat was small, and even after dividing the Bat King into three parts, we could only roast one at a time. Thus, only the bat meat in Fatty's hands was eighty percent done, with the rest being uncooked, dead bats.

But in this urgent moment, there was no time for further thought. Seeing Fatty petrified by the expressionless face above, I quickly snatched the bayonet with the skewered roasted bat meat from his hands, waved it in front of the monstrous face, and then flung it aside with force.

I had used too much strength, and instead of throwing it far, the bat meat was flung off the bayonet, landing not far behind Yingzi. Before Yingzi could even turn to look, a massive beast leaped down from the roof, pounced on the roasted Bat King, and, without even chewing, swallowed it whole.

 Illuminated by the firelight, we could see it clearly: the creature was not human. Its face resembled that of a baboon, strikingly human-like, with an exceedingly long neck. Its body was the size and shape of a bear, yet it lacked the bear's clumsiness. In contrast, its build seemed somewhat flattened. Its hind legs were bow-shaped, short and thick, while its forelimbs were unusually long. When it moved, it could grasp the crevices in the walls and hang there, its movements more at ease scaling the walls than on flat ground.

Yingzi had never seen such an animal, but Fatty and I had come across its picture before. As soon as it revealed its full appearance, we immediately recognized it: the Giant Ground Sloth, no doubt about it.

This creature dwelled in subterranean caverns deep within the grasslands, predominantly found on the great grasslands beyond southern America and Africa. Despite both being sloths, the Giant Ground Sloth was quite different from the jungle-dwelling sloths, and even more so from its distant relative, the tree sloth. The Giant Ground Sloth bore more traits of its ancestral Ice Age forebears, notably larger in size and primarily carnivorous. It seldom ventured out into the sunlight, preferring to prey on Large Bats, giant ground rats, pythons, and other subterranean animals.

The hunting method of the Giant Ground Sloth was one of stillness conquering motion. It rarely initiated attack, instead lying in wait in the darkness, motionless, sometimes for days on end without food or drink. When an animal passed by, it would strike like lightning, extending its gaping maw to consume its prey in one bite.

In the early days of the nation, an African brother country had gifted one to the Beijing Zoo. However, the animal did not adapt well to the Beijing environment and died not long after. Fatty, some classmates, and I, during our trip to Beijing to meet with the victorious Red Guards, were taken on a chaotic tour of the city, which included the zoo. There, we saw the enormous cage that once housed the Giant Ground Sloth. The creature was gone, leaving behind an empty cage. We found the sight of the massive, vacant enclosure somewhat odd, and gave it a few extra glances. An introduction and images of the creature adorned the cage.

Years had passed, and the memory of this event remained vivid. But we never imagined that we would encounter such a creature, and such a large one at that, in the Underground Fortress of the Kwantung Army.

Presumably, it had followed the pig-faced Large Bats here. The number of Large Bats within the fortress was beyond counting; we had seen a Stone Cave nest with no fewer than a thousand, and the fortress extended dozens of kilometers deep, possibly hiding several more nests.

The creature was tough, with a skin so thick and layered with small bone plates underneath that it resembled armor. Once it reached adulthood, this armor was virtually impenetrable.

The ferocious pig-faced Large Bats, with their sharp claws, could easily tear through the stomachs of cattle and sheep, but they could not harm the Giant Ground Sloth. Even if they scratched at it, it would cause the sloth no pain or irritation. With no natural predators here and countless pig-faced Large Bats to hunt, the Giant Ground Sloth thrived.

 However, I had no idea how the colossal Grassland Sloth managed to enter the Fortress. It was possible that an earthquake or a landslide had created large fissures in the Underground Fortress, and it had crawled in through them in search of food. If we could locate that entrance, we might be able to escape through it.

The Grassland Sloth that had leapt down from the roof devoured the roasted bat meat, its long tongue licked around its mouth a few times. Clearly, such a small piece of meat was not enough to fill its stomach and only whetted its voracious appetite. It eyed the three of us, pondering its next move. In the subterranean world, it was the king, occasionally embarking on hunting expeditions. Whenever it moved, there was scarcely anything that could stop it.

In the moment of standoff, my mind raced. The layout of the Underground Fortress and the strategies for dealing with wild beasts were somewhat unfamiliar to me. Should I strike first? The submachine gun was within reach, but the firepower of the Type 100 Submachine Gun was quite limited, and the Grassland Sloth's thick hide was more than a match for it. I didn't want to provoke it and end up in a worse situation, with no guarantee of escape.

The Yousaka-style Rifle, used by the Japanese Army, had excellent penetrating power and should be capable of taking down the Grassland Sloth. However, we only had a few bayonets, and the two rifles we had loaded with bullets were placed some twenty to thirty meters away. Someone would have to distract the Grassland Sloth so I could run and grab a rifle. This back and forth would take a brief but critical span of time, and the Grassland Sloth was dangerously close to our position.

As these thoughts flashed through my mind, none seemed promising. At that moment, Fatty stood still and whispered to me, "Old Hu, I remember this creature only eats warm-blooded and cold-blooded animals, not humans. I think we're fine." He gently kicked the dead bat towards the Grassland Sloth, signaling that it should take the bat and leave us alone.

Unexpectedly, the Grassland Sloth didn't even glance at the dead bat but instead salivated incessantly at us.

Fatty turned to me and asked, "Why isn't it eating the bat? It keeps staring at us as if it has ill intentions."

I dared not get distracted by talking to Fatty. I kept a vigilant watch on every move of the Grassland Sloth, ready to act if it showed any sign of attack. I would have to be quicker, picking up the submachine gun from the ground and unleashing a barrage of bullets at it.

Yingzi said, "We've eaten quite a bit of the roasted bat meat. Perhaps it sees us as bats."

 Before she had finished speaking, the grassland sloth, unable to resist the tempting scent of the roasted bat meat, began to advance towards us step by step. All wild animals naturally feed on raw flesh, having never tasted cooked meat. Once they experience its flavor, the taste of cooked meat becomes their greatest temptation.

Noting its sluggish pace, I decided that running was wiser than engaging in combat. I called out to the other two, and we turned to flee. But after just a couple of strides, I tripped over a hard object and nearly shattered my knee, tumbling to the ground. Fatty and Yingzi fell alongside me.

Puzzled by what had tripped me, I glanced at the ground, which was smooth and devoid of any object that could have caused a fall. A thought struck me: in our rush to escape, we had forgotten to bring the corpses of the young boy and girl. Could it be the ghosts that tripped us?

The grassland sloth had probably never seen a two-legged creature like humans before. Smelling the roasted bat on us, it mistook us for bats, albeit unable to accept such oddly shaped ones and wary of the firelight. It hesitated, calculating how to devour the delicious meal now within reach. Seeing us fall, it pounced forward.

Its hind limbs were thick and strong, and with one leap, it was upon Fatty, who seemed the meatiest, and thus its chosen first bite.

Fatty, seeing the danger, struggled desperately, his hands scrambling on the ground for a weapon. By chance, he found the skewer used for roasting bats, grabbed it, and plunged it deep into the sloth's arm, blade sinking in up to the hilt.

The blade, having been heated for a long time, was like a glowing red metal rod. When it pierced the sloth, only the foul stench of charred flesh filled the air. The sloth, an unrivaled force in the caverns below, had never suffered such pain and was both hurt and enraged. Yet, it dared not bite Fatty again and slowly backed away, waiting for another opportunity.

After the searing stab, the temperature of the skewer quickly dropped. The fresh blood of the sloth caused wisps of white steam to rise from the blade. Fatty's successful strike was solely due to the skewer's heat; otherwise, it wouldn't have penetrated the beast.

Taking advantage of the moment Fatty repelled the sloth, Yingzi and I each hoisted the military greatcoat containing the children's bodies onto our backs, hoping the little ghosts would cease their mischief.

With the sacrificial children's corpses on my back, I bent down to pick up the submachine gun, well aware that the Type 100's firepower was insufficient to kill the grassland sloth. But in a critical moment, I hoped to use it for defense.

 Before I could even pull back the gun bolt, a claw suddenly reached out from the wall behind me, swiping straight for my head with such speed and force that I had no time to duck. My only option was to use the submachine gun in my hand as a shield. But the claw struck with such power that the weapon was knocked from my grasp and went flying into the darkness beyond the reach of the firelight.

Unbeknownst to me, four grassland sloths had descended from the wall—two large and two small, with the smallest being almost the size of the others. Clearly, they too were lured by the irresistible scent of roasted bat meat and had come to hunt.

We were completely encircled by the five grassland sloths. If one decided to pounce, the others would surely follow in a frenzied rush to tear us to pieces and devour us.

Our only refuge was the fire. The three of us stood back to back, huddled together: Fatty armed with a bayonet, Yingzi with a submachine gun, and I was left empty-handed.

The fire, kindled from wood chips, was dimming by the moment and would soon extinguish. If that happened, we would be nothing but a feast for the grassland sloths. The thought alone made me curse our luck inwardly: one was troublesome enough, and now, the entire clan of grassland sloths that occupied this fortress had mobilized. Trapped in a dire situation, I wondered how we could possibly fight our way out.

We couldn't afford to delay any longer. I grabbed a burning stick from the fire and swung it at the smallest of the grassland sloths blocking our path. Startled by the flames, it recoiled to one side, creating a gap in the encirclement.

The flame on the stick was already weak, and it nearly went out as I swung it. We didn't dare waste a moment and charged through the opening. The salivating grassland sloths hesitated but then lunged at us in unison.

Yingzi's submachine gun spat out a burst of bullets. The leading grassland sloth was hit, and blood spattered from its body. However, their thick, calloused skin meant the bullets penetrated their flesh but could not pierce the bony armor beneath. Instead of being deterred, the creatures became enraged and pressed on, determined to consume us.

With only Yingzi armed with a submachine gun, Fatty and I waved our burning sticks to fend off the grassland sloths whenever she had to reload. We fought and retreated, and because our escape was somewhat aimless, we inadvertently moved further away from our weapons cache and ended up near the large iron doors of the Gena Warehouse.

 Beyond the iron gate lay the Corpse Demon; our initial plan was to eat and drink our fill before meticulously devising a strategy to escape through the passageway beyond the gate. However, an unexpected assault by the slothful behemoths of the Grassland caught us off guard, forcing us to retreat hastily to this spot. The flames on the sticks dwindled, leaving only charred wood with a few sparks above, and our bullets were running low.

The Grassland giants loomed large, several huddled together forming an insurmountable wall. A mere swipe of their paws would result in broken bones and torn tendons at the least. As the circle of Grassland sloths tightened around us, we found ourselves trapped against the iron gate with no room to maneuver.

The time had come to risk it all. Fatty and I hurled our smoldering sticks at the Grassland beasts, while Yingzi unleashed a barrage from her Type 100 Submachine Gun, pushing the creatures back a few steps with our final burst of strength. Fatty spun around and pushed open the previously sealed iron gate; I took out the Black Donkey Hoof and hurled it outside.

To our surprise, the Corpse Demon was not waiting at the door. With no time to ponder, we continued our retreat into the passageway behind the gate. Just as Fatty was about to close the heavy iron door, an immense force slammed against it. The brute strength of the Grassland behemoths, weighing several tons, was truly formidable. The three of us exerted all our might to shut the gate but to no avail.

Suddenly, a bone-chilling wind hit us. I dodged hastily, realizing that the Ancient Corpse, possessed by the death god and a general from the Jin dynasty, had never left the gate's vicinity and was lurking nearby. Bereft of intelligence, the Corpse Demon, like a zombie, was cursed by a sorcerer's talisman to blindly attack the living.

The Corpse Demon appeared as swiftly and silently as a gust of wind or a flash of lightning. Had I not been battle-hardened with extensive combat experience, it would have already taken me down. I rolled to the ground, scrambling to dodge, when the iron gate was forced open, and the largest of the Grassland sloths leaped out first.

The Grassland behemoth, using its sturdy hind limbs like a giant frog, sprung from the gate and inadvertently knocked over the Corpse Demon. Unable to bend its body, the Corpse Demon quickly sprang back up, its ten knife-like fingers piercing the chest of the Grassland sloth.

The Grassland beast let out an odd cry and bit fiercely. The other Grassland sloths, varying in size, swarmed out from the Gena Warehouse. Seeing their kin wounded, they converged to tear and bite at the Corpse Demon.

 The smallest of the grassland behemoths was gruesomely decapitated by a Corpse Demon, which in turn was fiercely bitten by two of the creatures. The monstrous strength of both parties was evenly matched, and for a moment, they became entangled. In an instant, the walls, the floor, and the iron doors were splattered with copious amounts of the behemoths' fresh blood, flesh flying everywhere, while the Corpse Demon's arm was bitten off.

The sight before us was so harrowing that it sent shivers down our spines. Had the Corpse Demon and the grassland behemoths coordinated their attack, the three of us would have undoubtedly met a grim fate with no place to lay our bodies to rest. Our blundering intervention had inadvertently led to a situation where the two beasts fought each other, a stroke of luck indeed.

Time was of the essence. Carrying the corpses of the boy and girl, we fled towards the breach in the tomb wall of the rear chamber. We cursed our lot for not having more legs, scurrying like a family in mourning, floundering like fish slipping through the net. Our disheveled escape needs no detailed description.

The large hole in the tomb wall had collapsed just as it had been when we first escaped. Now, having returned in full circle without any valuable loot, we had only managed to invite trouble and ended up with two corpses filled with mercury—truly an absurd and laughable outcome. However, despite the underground fortress yielding no treasures, it contained many garments and pieces of equipment, and perhaps a few simple engines could still be found. This information could be shared with the villagers, ensuring our harrowing ordeal in the fortress was not in vain.

All we needed to do was climb out of the vertical shaft of the thieves' tunnel. By this point, everyone's physical and mental stamina had reached their limits. Yet in desperation, people can summon extraordinary strength, much like a cornered dog fighting to escape. Yingzi unleashed a barrage of submachine gun fire on the lid of the thieves' tunnel's coffin, sending two magazines' worth of bullets flying and shredding the wood to splinters. The coffin lid, originally embedded in the wall, was now riddled with holes. Fatty charged and shouldered it into two pieces, revealing the tunnel once more. I pushed Yingzi up the shaft, then Fatty and I hoisted the corpses of the boy and girl, which Yingzi caught from above before pulling me up.

Fatty was left below, as he needed us to pull from above to make it up the shaft. Just as he was about to climb, two blood-soaked grassland behemoths charged into the tomb chamber. They were in a state of frenzied rage, their roars thunderous. It was likely that the rest of their family had been slaughtered by the Corpse Demon. Despite the demon's ferocity, it probably could not withstand the onslaught of such colossal beasts and was torn to shreds.

 The two battered grassland sloths, with bloodshot eyes, relentlessly pursued us and followed us right into the tomb chamber. Fatty glanced back, his face paled, and he scrambled towards the vertical shaft, but in his panic, he struggled to make any progress. The grassland sloths had reached the robbers' tunnel, but luckily for us, the tunnel was too narrow for them to squeeze through. They clawed at the earth, desperately trying to widen the tunnel to escape. Seeing the urgency of the situation, I picked up Yingzi's submachine gun and tossed it to Fatty. Understanding the plan, he fired off a few shots to push back the sloths crowding the tunnel entrance, then sprayed bullets at the Tianbao Dragon Fire Glazed Tile Roof above the tomb chamber. The glazed tiles shattered, and bags of Western Region Fire Dragon Oil poured down, engulfing the entire tomb, including the two grassland sloths, in the fierce flames ignited by the oil.

Meanwhile, Yingzi and I mustered our last bit of strength to pull Fatty out of the shaft. Even so, a large portion of Fatty's pants had caught fire from the flames spurting out of the tunnel, and he frantically patted down the flames, screaming in agony like a slaughtered pig. Yingzi hurriedly doused the fire with her water bottle, but his pants were already burned to the point of exposing his backside.

The loyal hunting dogs sat by our side, watching as their three masters emerged from the hole. It was now midday, and the sunlight was dazzlingly bright, a stark contrast to the gloomy underground fortress—it felt like another world.

Fatty, with one hand covering his injury and the other holding up two jade pieces he had acquired from the tomb, examined them in the light. He couldn't help but wax poetic and recited a few famous lines from an epic war poem:

"The flames of war have been extinguished, the gun smoke has dissipated.

Oh sun, you have never been as warm as you are now;

Oh sky, you have never been as blue;

The smiles on the children's faces have never been as sweet."

Yingzi and I couldn't help but burst into laughter at Fatty's antics—have you ever seen a poet reciting verse while clutching his behind? However, an unexpected event soon froze our smiles.

chapters.name: Chapter 20
chapters.content:
In the forest at the end of the valley, a series of muffled thunderous roars echoed, booming and rolling despite the clear midday sky, free of any dark clouds. Everyone's hearts sank at the sudden thunder—having just emerged from an ancient tomb, they now faced another mystery.

Listening more carefully, the sound seemed less like thunder and more like some enormous beast charging towards the valley from afar. Its heavy footsteps, coupled with the relentless crashing against the trees as it ran, at first gave the impression of continuous thunder, punctuated by the occasional bark of a dog.

"I hear barking," I realized, noting that three of our dogs were missing from the valley, leaving only five large hunting dogs lying on the ground. The three giant mastiffs were nowhere to be seen. Exhausted and preoccupied earlier, I hadn't paid much attention to the hunting dogs. Perhaps, with our prolonged absence, they had taken turns hunting for food. What kind of wild animal could cause such a commotion when chased by the giant mastiffs?

Yingzi listened intently for a moment, then smiled and said it was nothing to worry about—they were just chasing a wild boar. "Let's head up the hillside and enjoy the spectacle. We'll have wild boar meat to feast on shortly."

As we climbed halfway up the hill, we could already see the large trees in the forest being knocked down one after another. The valley's hunting dogs could no longer stay put; they scattered in a fan formation, intending to block the wild boar's escape route through the valley.

Suddenly, a red pine snapped at the mouth of the valley, and a giant wild boar burst forth from behind the tree. Had it not been for the creature's lack of a long snout, I might have mistaken it for a young elephant. It weighed easily over a thousand pounds, with black and long bristles, and tusks on either side of its mouth curved upward like two daggers. These tusks were not only a proud symbol of its masculinity but also a sign that it was the king of wild boars in the forest. With its plump and round body, short and thick limbs, it charged into the valley like a whirlwind.

Behind the giant wild boar, the three giant mastiffs pursued at a steady pace, neither lunging nor biting fiercely, nor straying too far. In a line, they all ran into Wildman Gully.

The boar's skin was as tough as a rhino's, and it would rub its corpulent body against the pine trees in the forest when idle. This served both to scratch an itch and to coat itself with pine resin, warding off the bites of insects. In the summer, the mosquitoes in the deep mountain old forests were as large as small birds. There's a saying in the mountains: "Three mosquitoes make a dish." This wasn't an exaggeration. Even old oxen couldn't withstand the bites of these mountain mosquitoes, but the wild boar was unfazed. Its skin was like a suit of iron armor, impervious to bites. The tusks, along with its massive weight, were the boar's treasures for roaming the forest, offering both offense and defense. Even tigers, human bears, and leopards in the mountains dared not tackle it.

However, the giant mastiffs raised by hunters had special techniques for dealing with wild boars. The Tibetan mastiffs were the size of small calves, yet they seemed small compared to the giant wild boar. These three giant mastiffs intended to drive the wild boar deeper into the valley before finishing it off. In the forest, filled with large trees, there was no room to maneuver, and a charging wild boar was akin to a tank.

 Deep within Wildman Gully, the layer of fallen leaves was exceedingly thick. The Giant Wild Boar had not even covered half the distance before its substantial weight caused its limbs to sink into the leafy bed. Three large Tibetan Mastiffs encircled it, biting here and there, sapping the wild boar's strength and fighting spirit. Meanwhile, five Large Hunting Dogs formed an outer ring. In such a scenario, they dared not compete with the Tibetan Mastiffs for glory, content instead to play the role of a small cheer squad on the sidelines, shouting encouragement.

Frustrated and desperate, the Giant Wild Boar clumsily struggled within the leaf pile, mustering all its might to leap upwards, miraculously freeing its limbs and shooting up.

The Giant Mastiffs awaited precisely this moment. As the wild boar reached the apex of its jump, the largest of the three Tibetan Mastiffs also leaped powerfully, like a cannonball fired from its chamber, colliding with the Giant Wild Boar. The force and angle of the impact were perfectly calculated, flipping the boar over, belly-up, onto the deep, soft bed of twigs and decaying leaves.

The other two Tibetan Mastiffs, lying in wait, wasted no time, pouncing on the Giant Wild Boar's exposed belly to deliver vicious bites. The stomach was the wild boar's only weak spot, and once exposed to the enemy, its fate was sealed, especially against the lion-like ferocity and swiftness of the Tibetan Mastiffs. In less than four seconds, the boar's intestines, stomach, and heart were all torn out.

Seeing that the wild boar was finished, the three of us slowly descended the hillside. Fatty and I, witnessing the incredible coordination of the three Giant Mastiffs and their tactical use of the terrain, couldn't help but want to pat the heads of the Tibetan Mastiffs in commendation, grinning and beckoning them over.

Unexpectedly, the Tibetan Mastiffs and hunting dogs bypassed us, gathering around Yingzi instead. She took out some jerky, feeding it to them. The dogs, seeing their master pleased, wagged their tails in appeasement.

Feeling snubbed, Fatty and I exchanged a look. I shook my head and sighed, "Damn it, our warm faces have met with the dogs' cold backsides."

Fatty huffed and said, "Old Hu, do you remember what Mr. Lu Xun once said about sycophantic dogs? That's just the nature of these creatures. They look down on people with disdain, fail to recognize faces, and only know to fawn over power. Let's not stoop to their level."

 Fatty returned to the tent to fetch a knife, a pickaxe head, and a hunting shotgun, then came back to the valley to assist Yingzi in butchering the wild boar. Carrying the shotgun and accompanied by two large dogs, I went down the hillside to find a spot to bury the young boy and girl, to prevent them from troubling us again.

Yingzi asked, "Brother Hu, are you hungry? Why don't we eat something before we go?"

I replied, "No need. A good meal can wait. I'll just be hungrier later. We shouldn't wait until night to bury the dead; that would be rather unsettling."

I had the two large dogs drag the bodies of the children, wrapped in a military greatcoat, to a spot facing the vast grassland, where I dug a deep pit. My engineer soldier's shovel had been left behind in the ancient tomb, so digging with the pickaxe head was exhausting. The sun was setting, and after digging just over a meter deep, I was drenched in sweat and my stomach was rumbling.

Looking at the pit, over a meter deep, I thought to myself that it was sufficient. After all, they were just children; burying them too deep was unnecessary. Their bodies were filled with mercury, so there was no concern about insects or rodents.

So, I took the children out of the military greatcoat, rewrapped them neatly in two more coats, and laid them side by side in the pit. I clasped my hands in prayer and bowed twice: "Young friends from ancient times, it's regrettable that you didn't live in a new society filled with civilization, democracy, and sunshine, where you could have experienced societal care. But this was all destined, and there's no need to cling to it. Life has its end, and one should not forget. Many things are beyond our control; they are determined by fate. After death, burial brings peace. Those not at peace become zombies. Our resources are limited here; we have no coffin to lay you in, nor incense to honor you with. After I return, I will burn more paper money for you, in the hope that you will reach the Western Pure Land of Ultimate Bliss soon. Do not entangle us any longer; we too are busy with our work. This is all we can do for you. Being greedy and insatiable is not the trait of a good child."

After saying this, I pushed the soil back into the pit with the help of the two large dogs, and with a few handfuls of earth, I buried the two ill-fated boy and girl servants. Looking back towards the distance, I saw the setting sun, blood-red, and was filled with a myriad of emotions.

It was getting late. Yingzi called out to me from afar to return. So, with the hunting dogs, I made my way back to our campsite on the hillside. Fatty had moved a large stone to firmly block the ventilation hole that a large bat had used to attack the horses. The aroma of pine resin mixed with the scent of roasting wild boar meat, as well as a pot of soup made with pig offal and ground mushrooms and wood ear fungus, assaulted my senses. I couldn't wait to rush over, cut off a piece of meat with a knife, and stuff it into my mouth.

 After dinner, we sipped the tea bricks brewed by Yingzi, discussing our return journey. Without the horses to carry our luggage, the trek back to Ganggang Camp was daunting. We couldn't move our pots, pans, and tents, and the animal skins we'd hunted along the way would have to be left behind—a significant loss. Eventually, Yingzi had an idea: send two dogs back with a message, asking the villagers to organize a horse team to excavate the Kwantung Army's fortress. There were too many valuables here to leave behind; it would be a waste. Moreover, the dogs would make excellent guides for the villagers. In the meantime, we would find a safe place nearby to stay until everyone arrived, then move the goods together.

At this point, we had no other choice. Fatty, seemingly unconcerned with our predicament, took out the two jade bi he had been obsessing over. I scolded him, "You're hopeless, unable to wait even for dawn in your poverty. Stop carrying those jade pieces around; looking at them over a hundred times a day, aren't you afraid they'll wear out? Better let me keep them safe."

Fatty held the jade bi up to my face, his expression full of astonishment, "Old Hu, are these the ones we took from the ancient tomb? Take a look, is there something off about them?"

Since obtaining the pair of jade bi from the tomb, I hadn't had the chance to examine them closely. Fatty, with his exaggerated surprise, handed them to me, "Why has the color changed again?" I took the jade bi and scrutinized them.

Both jade pieces were carved into shapes resembling moths, with every detail vividly present, as if they were alive. The body of the bi-disc was adorned with patterns of strange creatures, likely fantastical rather than real. They were plump, their bodies somewhat resembling lean lions, or perhaps scaleless flood dragons, with several claws and a curled, large tail. The patterns were bizarre and might not represent animals at all, but rather clouds or waves.

The craftsmanship of the patterns on the bi-disc's body was not as refined as the sculpting of the form, merely outlined with a few strokes. Despite the roughness, there was a sense of simplicity and expressiveness to it. Sometimes, simplicity is its own form of beauty.

It was truly puzzling. I remembered when we first retrieved them from the ancient tomb's coffin, the jade bi were a deep green. Yet, when observed inside the Kwantung Army fortress, their color appeared a pale yellow.

 At this moment, the hue was a deep, deep yellow, its color having changed several times within the day, a mystery to us all. Could it be that there exists such a thing as Color-Changing Jade in this world? Our ignorance of antiques was apparent, and it seemed we had no choice but to return to Beijing to seek the expertise of Big Gold Tooth, a dealer in antiques, to enlighten us.

Reflecting on this grave-robbing expedition, it was far from smooth sailing. The hardships endured along the way were just the beginning. The ancient tomb we discovered in Wildman Gully, belonging to a general, was disappointingly sparse in burial artifacts.
