The only item of potential value was this pair of Jade Bi, and even obtaining them was a near-fatal ordeal. The difficulty of the task was such that no metaphor, not even "carrying mountains and seas," could adequately convey it, and the peril was such that "skating on thin ice by an abyss" seemed an understatement. If these were to be appraised as worthless, I might as well find a wall to dash my head against.

This experience has taught me a lesson: not all noble tombs contain a trove of valuable funeral objects. One must thoroughly understand the historical and cultural background of the tombs, and possess a broad knowledge of antique appreciation. Only with this information can one target the right tombs and ensure that the efforts are not in vain.

Fatty, on the other hand, was brimming with confidence, betting that the Jade Bi could fetch at least thirty to fifty thousand yuan, or perhaps even be recognized as national treasures. In that case, we wouldn't sell them to businesspeople from Hong Kong and Taiwan. Instead, we'd offer them directly to The Palace Museum. Should the government be pleased, a reward of a hundred thousand or eighty thousand would be like child's play. They might even allocate us an apartment in Beijing and have us wear a Big Red Flower, touring the country to give report speeches. We could stir emotions with our stories, and upon finishing, the female university students in the audience, with tears brimming in their eyes, would rush to present us with flowers and love letters.

I told him to stop dreaming, that it would be a stroke of luck if we weren't sent to squat in a clay kiln instead of being invited to a Model Workers' Deeds Report Meeting. Nevertheless, if we could indeed net thirty to fifty thousand yuan as Fatty claimed, it would be an unexpected windfall. After all, our year-round hustle selling cassette tapes barely scraped together three to four thousand yuan. In bad years, after deducting expenses for food and accommodation, we hardly made any profit.

Having not slept for two days, I chatted briefly with Fatty and Yingzi after a full meal and promptly fell asleep. With the hunting dogs standing guard, there was no need to fear wild beast attacks. I slept through the confusion of the world, and in my dreams, I returned to the battlefield shrouded in gun smoke. The sky above the trenches was filled with the faces of my brothers-in-arms, each one youthful. They had faces but no bodies, and these faces were bleeding incessantly, slowly ascending to the heavens. I lay on the ground, crying and shouting, wanting to grasp them, but despite my frantic efforts, I was paralyzed, unable to move an inch.

 The evening passed without incident; the large bats that dwelled underground had vanished without a trace, likely having been frightened off by the gunfire to seek a new cavern to call home.

I slept through to noon before waking. By that time, Yingzi had already dispatched three hunting dogs to deliver messages back home, each dog's neck adorned with a small leather pouch containing a note penned by Fatty. It instructed those in the village to bring additional manpower and tools, and if possible, explosives, to Wildman Gully for the excavation of the Kwantung Army's Western Relics.

After a meal of wild boar at midday, we moved our tents and supplies near the entrance of the valley, setting up camp behind a large boulder that shielded us from the wind. This spot, at the edge of the forest and grassland, would be easily found by the villagers when they arrived.

Yingzi went to forage for wild greens with the dogs while I dug a pit for a stove and set a pot to boil water. We had brought some flour, so Fatty set to work making dumplings stuffed with prime mushroom and wild boar meat, a feast to celebrate our initial success. Though we'd had a close call, we were unscathed and had made some gains, particularly the wealth of supplies in the Kwantung Army Fortress, which would greatly aid the villagers' lives. This achievement alone was worth a toast or two.

Thus, we spent our days hunting with the dogs, and over ten days had passed. I felt almost like a hunter of the mountains. At last, the villagers arrived—over forty in number, led by the Branch Secretary and the accountant. With the men away working at Ox Heart Mountain, it was mostly women, girls, and older children who came. The village had few horses, no more than ten, and hearing of the abundance of Western Relics, they feared not having enough mounts, so they brought along mules and donkeys as well. Along with their own hunting dogs, they made a noisy entrance through Black Wind Pass.

Everyone was eager to start, but I suggested that after their arduous journey, we should rest for a day to regain our strength before beginning work. Moreover, we couldn't proceed haphazardly. Having served as a combat engineer, I volunteered to take charge, planning to distribute tasks and utilize operational research to devise a plan. I urged that we act methodically and not like a disorderly mob.

 The crowd buzzed with a noisy excitement, finding amusement in the situation as they whispered and speculated among themselves, drowning out my voice. No one could hear me clearly until the Branch Secretary had to intervene, bellowing for silence: "Quiet down, everyone! Listen to my nephew here. What he says is what I say, and that's the word from the organization. We owe it to my two nephews and Yingzi, this young lady, for the chance to recover these Western Relics from the little Ghost. Whatever they say, that's how we'll proceed."

I repeated my instructions, telling everyone to set up tents, get the pots ready for cooking, eat, and rest. Then, in consultation with the secretary and the accountant, we discussed our lack of explosives. Nevertheless, accessing the Underground Fortress wasn't too daunting a task. We could start from the General's Tomb, which was close to the Fortress's passageway. With five people working, we could clear the collapsed Tomb Chamber in less than half a day. However, we had to be prepared for wild beasts that might be lurking within the Fortress. Creatures that dwell underground are afraid of fire, so we'd need plenty of torches. It was crucial to emphasize that once inside, no one should act on their own. We were not to take any of the munitions, only the supplies needed for daily life—Military Greatcoats, Japanese boots, blankets, motors, cables, and wires. We would take as much as we could carry, then reseal the Fortress without letting the information leak. Otherwise, we'd have to surrender our finds.

The Branch Secretary pounded his chest in assurance: "Nephew, rest easy. Once these folks have their share, they'll keep tight-lipped. They've learned their lesson from the earthquake year when many went to Ox Heart Mountain seeking Treasure, only to have it confiscated by the Cultural Relics Bureau. This time they're wiser. Even with a gun to their head, no one would spill the beans. Besides, our Village is so secluded, we hardly see an outsider all year round. This time, we'll make a fortune in silence."

That evening we buried pots to cook, set up camp, and rested. The next morning, I divided the forty-some men and women, young and old, into four groups. The first group, the youngest, was led by Yingzi to hunt in the mountains. Another, composed of the eldest, stayed behind at camp to cook for everyone, led by the accountant. Fatty and I each took a group of strong young people to take turns excavating the collapsed General's Tomb, under the overall command of the Branch Secretary.

The villagers had brought a plethora of tools—spades, pickaxes, shovels, and even a few utterly unnecessary hoes. I split my group of ten into two teams: one to dig out the collapsed earth and Glazed Tiles, and the other to transport the excavated soil and rocks. The project progressed in an orderly fashion.

 Suddenly, from nowhere, a dark cloud drifted over, and with a flash of lightning, a sudden hailstorm descended upon us. Everyone was thrown into disarray, scrambling for the shelter of tents near the mouth of the valley to escape the pelting ice.

Upon returning to the camp, the accountant took a headcount and found that, in addition to the hunting party that had ventured into the mountains, we were short by three people.

The weather in the wilderness is fickle, changing at a moment's notice. This hailstorm had come on too quickly; there had been past incidents of hail causing fatalities among both humans and animals. So, when the hail began, everyone used whatever they could find to shield their heads and ran back in a panic, and in the confusion, it was inevitable that some would lose their way.

What concerned me most, however, was the legendary opium den. Ever since our arrival at Wildman Gully, we had been exceedingly cautious, yet we had not encountered any opium dens. Over the past few days, our vigilance had somewhat relaxed. If, by some misfortune, we were to stumble upon one and get trapped inside, not even a deity could rescue us.

I said to the Branch Secretary, "Let's take stock and figure out which three people are missing and which group they belong to. That way, we can estimate where they might be, and I'll take a few people to start a search."

The Branch Secretary replied, "Ah, my dear nephew, you have such a sharp mind. I get so flustered that everything turns dark before my eyes; my brain just stops working in a crisis. Let's have the accountant check which three are missing."

As the crowd calmed down from the chaos of the hailstorm, the hail itself also ceased. The storm had been brief but intense, and as quickly as it had arrived, it departed, driven away by gusting winds that scattered the dark clouds. The mountain wind howled, whipping up the fallen leaves within Wildman Gully into a frenzy, and the weather turned chilly in an instant.

The accountant went from tent to tent tallying up the numbers, and eventually came to report to the Branch Secretary and me, "Uncle, the three missing are Bai Ling, Gui Lan, those two girls, and Old Wang's second daughter-in-law. What are we going to do? We should hurry and use dogs to help us search."

These three belonged to Fatty's group. Since it wasn't their turn to work yet, they had been idly chatting in small clusters along the east and west sides of the gully. When the weather turned, everyone was preoccupied with getting back, and no one noticed their absence.

The Branch Secretary said, "These three, I told them not to come, but they insisted. And now they've caused a commotion. Hu Da, my nephew, what do you think? Should we all go look for them?"

I replied, "The hail and rain came down so fiercely just now; they might have run off to find shelter from the rain. We shouldn't send too many people; more isn't always better. Otherwise, we might end up losing a few more in the search, and that would only compound our troubles. I'll take four or five people who are nimble and used to walking the mountain paths. I've lived in Wildman Gully for half a month and know the terrain well. You don't need to worry; just stay at the camp. It's gotten cooler, so have the women brew some ginger tea to ward off the chill."

The Branch Secretary slapped his thigh in agreement: "That's exactly what we should do."

 Fatty and I, accompanied by five hunters accustomed to traversing streams and scaling mountains, began our search from the ancient tomb at the heart of Wildman Gully. Most of the hunting dogs had been taken by Yingzi and her group into the mountains for hunting, as we needed a substantial amount of food and meat to feed nearly fifty people. The hunting party was short on dogs.

We also needed to leave a few dogs behind to guard the camp against wild beasts. Thus, we only brought three with us, of which only one was a hunting dog; the other two were large, domestic watchdogs.

Wildman Gully ran north to south, with the vast grasslands of Outer Mongolia to the north, where our camp was located. To the south lay a chain of undulating mountains and primal forests. At that moment, a strong wind was blowing, whistling through Wildman Gully. We moved with the wind, which made the dogs' sense of smell less effective.

Leading the search party, we called out as we went, making our way to the southern exit of Wildman Gully. There, the trees grew dense, a thicket of white birch and larch. Apart from our shouts, the sound of our footsteps, and the barking of the dogs, only the whooshing of the wind could be heard. I felt an unusual stillness here; it was too quiet, almost eerily so. It seemed as if no animals or birds inhabited this patch of forest, not even the common little squirrels, which added to the oppressive atmosphere.

Three giant mastiffs had once driven a giant wild boar out of this forest. Due to its quietness, we had never hunted in this area before. I was hesitating when suddenly the hunting dog barked.

I released the hunting dog, and it darted out like an arrow, with all of us following closely behind. Underneath a large pine tree, we found three missing women. The girls, Bai Ling and Gui Lan, were holding onto the second daughter-in-law of the Wang family, at a loss of what to do. They called out to us urgently to help save her. They had heard our shouts for a while but, against the wind, we hadn't heard theirs.

The second daughter-in-law of the Wang family was frothing at the mouth and unconscious. I checked her breathing with my finger: she was fine, breathing steadily, not poisoned, likely just fainted from fright. A rest back at the camp should bring her around. "How did you end up here?" I asked. "Did you encounter a wild beast?"

Bai Ling recounted their ordeal. While waiting to start work, they were chatting idly in Wildman Gully. Women's conversations usually revolved around which young man was strikingly handsome or which girl was rather plain. They were deeply engaged in their talk when, without warning, the clear sky clouded over, and a fierce hailstorm hit, giving them no time to even glance at the sky. The three, none of whom had hunters in their families and were all accustomed to farming, lacked the experience of deep forest navigation. In a panic to find shelter, they lost their bearings and ended up running southward.

Gui Lan added that the second daughter-in-law of the Wang family was a few years older than the two of them, and they respectfully called her 'Second Sister-in-law.' They had a good relationship with her back in the village. Initially, they just followed Second Sister-in-law, too busy shielding their heads and not paying attention to their surroundings. But as they ran, they realized something was amiss. Once the hail stopped, they took a closer look and found themselves surrounded by trees. Apart from the three of them, not a soul was in sight. The dense canopy of trees blocked out the sky like a giant umbrella, and the mountain wind blew the fallen leaves around like snowflakes, a truly frightening sight. Gui Lan asked Second Sister-in-law if they had run in the wrong direction and suggested they should head back immediately.

 My sister-in-law found it odd when the sky suddenly darkened, and she saw a swarm of people tumbling toward this direction, nearly all of them men. Their faces were unclear, and she was so dazed by the hail that she didn't give it much thought and just followed the crowd. In the end, aside from her two younger sisters, everyone had vanished, leaving them alone and frightened.

Suddenly, they spotted a group of people huddled under an ancient tree, several hundred in number, all men, squatting in rows so that only their backs were visible. The sisters had heard tales of mountain-dwellers gathering ginseng and Ganoderma, precious medicinal herbs, especially the ginseng, known by many names such as 'divine herb' or 'earth spirit's cudgel.' Such treasures grew deep in the mountains, and a centuries-old ginseng could even become sentient, able to transform into a chubby boy or a young maiden. If a forager stumbled upon a rare old mountain ginseng, they mustn't exclaim their discovery but instead use code like 'two-horned lantern' or 'triple-petaled palm' to avoid alerting the ginseng spirit, which would vanish into the earth. One had to quietly tie a red string around it and wait until nightfall when the ginseng slept to dig it up. Before the digging, they would worship the mountain deity, fast, bathe, and wrap the unearthed ginseng in red cloth to bring it home safely.

The men squatting motionless sparked their curiosity: were they harvesting ginseng? And why were there so many of them? Driven by curiosity, she decided to take a closer look, despite the protests from the timid Bai Ling and Gui Lan. Ignoring them, she approached and tapped one of the squatting men on the shoulder, asking, "Brother, what are you up to?"

Whatever she saw next, her scream of horror was the last thing she uttered before fainting. Bai Ling and the other sister rushed to her aid, only to find that the men under the tree had disappeared without a trace, as if they had evaporated into the forest air.

Bai Ling told me, "Brother Hu, then you guys came along. It scared us to death. It's broad daylight, and we saw ghosts. All those old folks were crouching there, and in the blink of an eye, they were gone."

I called Fatty over to investigate the spot Bai Ling mentioned. Leaves littered the ground; autumn was half over, and deep fall was approaching. The leaves of the white birch trees rustled in the wind, but there was no sign of the hundreds of men. As we searched, we knew we had to quickly uncover any potential threats to our group.

Not far along, Fatty tripped and fell flat on his face. Cursing, he got up, thinking he had stumbled over a tree root, but a touch revealed it felt unlike one. Bringing it closer for inspection, he instantly dropped it in shock, exclaiming, "My God, a human thigh!"

I found his reaction odd and went over to pick it up. It was, in fact, a human forearm bone. Back where Fatty had fallen, more bone protruded from the earth, likely broken off when Fatty's leg had struck it.

I sent two men to escort Bai Ling and her sisters back, then led the remaining few to dig up the soil with the butt of our hunting rifles. We didn't have to dig far before uncovering a mass of human bones. Fatty asked me, "My heavens, could these be the laborers who built the Kwantung Army's Underground Fortress? Did the Kwantung Army kill them and bury them here in this forest's pit of ten thousand corpses? The figures Gui Lan and her sisters saw, could they have been ghosts?"

 A bone-chilling mountain breeze swept through, the cold intensifying, causing the few people digging in the earth to break out in goosebumps all over their bodies.

Moth-bodied Chi-patterned Double Dagger-shaped Bi

Skeleton after skeleton was buried and compressed within the soil. We had only uncovered a small patch beneath the layer of fallen leaves, yet it was already impossible to count the number of human bones. The bones bore clear signs of savage killing, with knife marks visible on the ribs, neck bones, and skulls. Numerous decapitated heads, clearly severed by a blade, were scattered among them.

There are many legends about Black Wind Pass, but perhaps the most famous is the battle at the end of the Jin dynasty and the beginning of the Yuan dynasty when the Mongols decisively defeated the main Jin forces. Hundreds of thousands of Jin soldiers lay dead, their bodies piled into mountains. When the Mongols cleaned up the battlefield, they carelessly tossed the corpses into Wildman Gully. It is said that they filled the entire valley, and now, nearly a thousand years later, those soldiers and generals have long since decayed into the soil and air.

The numerous white bones in the forest are unlikely to be remnants from that era. The Black Wind Pass battle between the Jin and Yuan dynasties is the only large-scale battle known to have taken place here in history, until the Kwantung Army's secret deployment. Since then, no other battles have been recorded.

After much thought, there seemed to be only one possibility. Comrade Lenin once said: When analyzing any problem, the absolute requirement for a Marxist is to place the issue within a certain historical context. Fatty felt that the multitude of human bones in the forest were likely those of Chinese laborers killed by the Kwantung Army, a hypothesis that fully conformed to Comrade Lenin's criteria.

But there was one thing that puzzled him. As Fatty walked under a tree, he stumbled over an arm bone, which led to the discovery of the mass grave buried in the earth. However, how could an arm bone be sticking out halfway from the ground?

This fact was somewhat jarring. If an arm had been exposed when the Kwantung Army buried the bodies, the carcasses would have long been dug up and devoured by wild beasts. Could it be that it deliberately stretched out from the earth to trip Fatty, to make us discover them? The thought gave me the creeps, and I dared not delve deeper into it. I called everyone to refill the excavated earth and hurried back to camp to discuss countermeasures with the Branch Secretary.

We rushed back to the camp at the other end of the valley, where we found Yingzi and her team had also returned from hunting in the mountains. Despite encountering hail, they had managed to hunt several roe deer, bears, and wild roes, enough to feed the people and hunting dogs for three or four meals.

 Several older women were busy cooking, while others rested or gathered inside a tent to visit Old Wang's daughter-in-law. I entered the tent and saw that she had regained consciousness, sipping some hot ginger soup, and was recounting her ordeal in the woods to the Branch Secretary and others: "So I got closer, and oh my, can you guess what it was? You'd never believe it, but here's what happened—oh, that thing, it was so frightening."

The Branch Secretary, growing impatient, urged her: "What are you doing, spinning yarns and performing like you're in a pingshu or singing a Beijing opera about heroes of Liangshan? Cut the nonsense and get to the point."

Old Wang's feisty daughter-in-law shot the Branch Secretary a glare: "What's the rush? I'm getting to it. Don't interrupt, okay? Where was I? You're trying to guess what happened? Well, I saw a group of people squatting in a circle, looking shabby, one worse than the other. I was puzzled and wanted to see what was going on. At first, I thought they were regular ginseng diggers, but as I approached, I realized they weren't. They were all bowing to a big tree. Bowing to a tree, as if it were a Bodhisattva or something. So I slapped one of them on the back to ask what they were doing, and guess what happened?"

The Branch Secretary, exasperated, said: "You're impossible, really. How on earth did Old Wang ever marry such a woman? It's so frustrating talking to you. Old Wang should take you home and give you a good talking-to."

Fearing the conversation was getting out of hand, I shot Yingzi a look, and understanding the cue, she quickly changed the subject and took Old Wang's daughter-in-law by the hand: "Sister-in-law, so what happened next? What did you see?"

Old Wang's daughter-in-law told Yingzi: "Oh, he was squatting there, and when he turned around—my goodness, he had no head! I got so scared I fainted. When I came to, I was here in the tent, with Bling tending to me and feeding me soup. And now, I'm telling you the whole story, how it all happened."

The women around were afraid of ghosts, and they began to murmur among themselves after hearing her story. The Branch Secretary quickly stood up and declared: "Ghosts and spirits, what nonsense! We are now basking in the spring breeze of Reform and Opening-up, soaking in the sunlight of the household responsibility system. In broad daylight, with the universe so clear, no one should spout such foolishness."

I took the Branch Secretary out of the tent to a secluded spot and told him everything I had seen and heard in the woods.

After listening, the Branch Secretary shed tears: "Our village suffered greatly at the hands of the 'little devils' during the war; they took many for forced labor, and none returned. My own uncle was among those taken, rumored to have been sent by the Kwantung Army to mine coal in Hokkaido, Japan. Others said he was taken to the Greater Khingan Range to work on construction projects. To this day, there's no certainty of his fate—neither seen in life nor found in death. My grandmother went blind from crying, still hoping for his return, a hope unfulfilled even to her death. Among those bones buried in the woods, there might be our fellow villagers. Even if not, they are still our Chinese compatriots. In good conscience, we cannot ignore this. Furthermore, if the resentment of these souls is too strong, their unrest could terrify us all. We would no longer be able to search for Western relics. Nephew, don't you think we should exhume them and give them a proper reburial?"

 I offered him a few words of advice. In such a situation, there wasn't much we could do with our abilities. A mass grave left by the Japanese Army had been discovered at Pingdingshan, containing the remains of thousands. To find and properly rebury each set of remains was nearly an impossible task, as many skeletons were already fragmented and scattered. Haphazardly piecing together a skull from one body with the torso of another showed great disrespect to the deceased. Moreover, we couldn't just come all this way to collect the Kwantung Army's Western Relics and leave empty-handed. What I mean is, we should bring offerings of incense, wine, and meat to the forest to pay our respects, and perhaps later erect a monument in their memory.

The Branch Secretary wiped his tears and runny nose with his sleeve and replied, "That's right. When we return to the village, we'll organize some of the local lamas to recite scriptures and pray for the souls, to help them rest in peace."

I never used to believe in ghosts, until recently when I came to understand a truth: there's nothing in this world that can be said to definitely not exist. A hunter goes into the mountains and comes back empty-handed after a whole day—that doesn't mean there are no wild animals there. What we see and hear in life is but a tiny fraction compared to the vastness of the universe. We should hold a sense of reverence for the unknown. Even if there are no specters causing mischief, the remains of those who died in the forest deserve our sympathy and it is necessary to do something for them from any perspective.

After the incident with Old Wang's second daughter-in-law, the people in the village have started to doubt and suspect the presence of ghosts. This place is truly strange; anything can happen. We can't afford to delay any longer at Black Wind Pass; who knows what else might occur.

After lunch, I had Fatty continue leading two groups to excavate the Kwantung Army's fortress, aiming to break through a passage by nightfall. The accountant was still to stay at the camp, preparing dinner with a few of the older women, while also watching over the mules and supplies. The Branch Secretary, Yingzi, and I, along with a few of the braver souls, took several jugs of liquor—home-brewed by the villagers—and some dried meat, and went to the southern end of Wildman Gully's forest to pay tribute to the spirits of the deceased laborers.

 By this time, the wind had ceased, and the woods were steeped in silence. We laid out our offerings of meat and wine on the ground. In lieu of incense, we stuck a few cigarettes upright in the soil. The Branch Secretary, amidst a flood of snot and tears, made fervent vows and pledges. The minor spirits had long been scared away; he swore to enlist lamas to pray for the souls of the departed and to erect a monument in their memory.

Only then did I realize that of all the villagers, the Branch Secretary was the most superstitious. Once he started on his beliefs, there seemed to be no end. I stood by, smoking, waiting, when suddenly, I felt something amiss in the woods.

The trees here were sparse, a far cry from the towering giants of primeval forests. What struck me as most peculiar was the presence of several withered old locust trees. In the forests of the Sino-Mongolian Border, one mostly finds pines and birches; locust trees, let alone the common thorny locusts of the northeast, are virtually nonexistent.

The locust tree is inherently yin, as can be inferred from its name—a character for 'wood' combined with 'ghost.' If such a tree dies, it becomes even more saturated with yin. According to the Sixteen-Character Yin-Yang Feng Shui Secret Technique, one of the sixteen characters strictly prohibits the presence of dead locust, willow, or poplar trees around a grave. Otherwise, the deceased's soul becomes entangled in the yin energy, pinned within several miles of the dead locust, unable to leave. In ancient times, after slaying their enemies, some would bury the corpses next to withered locust trees, ensuring their foes could not rest even in death.

I quickly surveyed the locust trees in the vicinity—all dead, seven in total, arranged in the pattern of the Big Dipper's sweeping tail. Whether this was a natural formation or the work of a Japanese with knowledge of yin and yang was unclear. No wonder Old Wang's daughter-in-law saw those lost souls crouching under the trees; surely, these spirits sought to escape the woods during the changing of heaven and earth, yet ultimately failed to break free.

I explained the situation to the Branch Secretary, urging that we cut down these dead locust trees at once.

With the decisive vigor of a moth-bodied, chi-patterned double dagger-shaped bi, the Branch Secretary commanded everyone to get to work. Despite lacking proper tools for felling trees, the dead locusts, already decayed, came down easily without much effort.

In the time it took to finish a meal, all seven ancient locusts were felled. The Branch Secretary was very pleased. He poured out the remaining wine into the earth, laid out wild fruits and apricots, and offered up deer and rabbit meat. We stood in silent tribute. Yingzi and I, along with a few others, dug firebreaks and lit a fire to burn the locust wood.

Flames soared high, and the dry wood crackled strangely, emitting plumes of black smoke. The stench was unbearable, and people covered their noses, standing back at a distance. Only when sparks flew out of the firebreaks did anyone approach to extinguish them.

 Starting a fire in the forest is no child's play; a careless act could spark a wildfire that sweeps across the land. We couldn't afford even a hint of negligence, and so we watched anxiously, guarding the flames until they were completely extinguished. Afterwards, we buried the ashes with soil to prevent any chance of them reigniting.

After a bustling day, it wasn't until evening that we finished. Upon returning to Wildman Gully, we found that Fatty and the others had already unearthed the Underground Fortress. Everyone hurried back to camp and were relieved to see that Old Wang's daughter-in-law was no longer in danger. She could eat and walk again, so we all feasted and drank our fill to restore our strength.

At the break of dawn the next day, we lit torches soaked in pine resin. More than twenty of us, leading several mules, entered the Underground Fortress through a passage extended from the wall of General's Tomb. At the iron doors of the Gena Warehouse, the signs of a struggle were evident. The Ancient Corpse had been torn to shreds, and the bodies of several large Grassland sloths lay nearby, their blood dried to a dark red hue. The sight of these things was still enough to send a shiver down the spine.

There was no longer any danger here, and with our many torches—especially those fueled by pine resin, which burn long and are not easily extinguished by the wind—even the fiercest of animals lurking in the Underground Fortress would not dare to approach.

The Branch Secretary was overjoyed at the sight of such a vast amount of Japanese Army supplies, far exceeding his most optimistic estimates. He eagerly called everyone to gather the Western Relics, and we loaded the mules with bundles of military greatcoats, shoes, rainproof cloths, dry batteries, and field mess kits, continuing to transport them out.

In the remote mountain villages, what we lacked most were these industrial products. Everyone raced to be the first, displaying a spirit of bravery reminiscent of the era of the Great Leap Forward, calling out to each other as they worked.

Yingzi and I led a few others in search of another section of the passage. According to the map, there was an even larger warehouse on the other side, which wasn't difficult to find if one followed the map.

The warehouse doors were tightly shut, and it took a horse to pull them open. Inside, we were all dumbstruck: row upon row of artillery pieces, like mountain guns, field howitzers, Type 60 Cannons, mortars of various sizes, and ammunition boxes piled up like mountains, stretching as far as the eye could see.

It seemed these guns were prepared for maneuver warfare. The entire Japanese Army could be divided into six parts, including the home army, which was stationed across the Japanese islands and its colonies, including Taiwan and Korea. These troops were known as the home army.

 In addition to the Chinese Expeditionary Army, which refers to the forces that invaded mainland China, there was also the Southern Army, which operated in Southeast Asia and Australia, as well as the Navy and Air Force, and the Kwantung Army stationed in Manchukuo. Altogether, these comprised the six major Military Regions.

Of these, the Kwantung Army was most favored by the Emperor and the Imperial General Headquarters, heralded as the elite of the elite. The Japanese held China's northeastern provinces in higher esteem than their own land for three key reasons: first, the strategic depth was considerable; second, the region was rich in resources, with its forests and mineral deposits beyond measure; third, it offered a high ground advantage, poised to strike the heartland at any moment. Long ago, Japan had articulated its covetous gaze upon the Northeast through the infamous Tanaka Memorial, and even during World War II, the so-called Tanaka Plan emerged, which underscored the extent of Japan's fixation on Manchuria, to the point of preferring it over the Japanese homeland itself.

Thus, the Kwantung Army's equipment and supplies were second to none among Japan's military forces, rivaled only by the Navy's Combined Fleet. However, these militaristic ambitions have long since become a laughingstock before the wheels of history. We need not extend any courtesy to the Kwantung Army; they certainly didn't afford us any. Rolling up our sleeves, we clamored to take everything back with us.

I cautioned them to be wary of torches near the ammunition boxes, for an explosion would leave no chance of escape—we would all be buried alive. Behind the countless artillery pieces lay even more large wooden crates, stamped with the red steel seal of Kashima Heavy Industries. Upon prying one open, we found it full of small electric motors, but they were too heavy to lift, impossible for the horses to carry. We had no choice but to dismantle them and carry the parts back piecemeal.

The supplies from the Underground Fortress took an entire day to move, and we had barely scratched the surface. The accountant busied himself tallying the haul, which was a fortune in itself—enough to use and to sell.

At dinner, the Branch Secretary approached me with a concern. At this rate, the transportation was endless, and the mules couldn't carry so much. With deep autumn upon us, if we left a team to guard the site and another to transport the goods back to the village, the difficult mountain paths would mean each round trip would take over half a month. We wouldn't manage more than two trips before the heavy snow sealed off the mountain. He suggested burying the entrance to the Fortress and having everyone return to the village, to resume the work the following spring.

I agreed, having been away from Beijing for over a month and growing weary of the mountain's confines. We needed to sell the relics we had unearthed to Big Gold Tooth. I acquiesced to the Branch Secretary's proposal, knowing that Fatty and I were unlikely to return with them. I entrusted the Branch Secretary to come back to Black Wind Pass next spring and offer paper money for the entombed boy and girl. Moreover, I emphasized the importance of not tampering with the munitions in the Underground Fortress, as they were not meant for civilian use.

 The Branch Secretary, having understood the situation, readily promised to address the matter, saying that upon returning to the village, he would find a lama to chant sutras and, incidentally, take the two children along to be blessed as well.

In order to depart the next day, nearly everyone stayed up all night, busily packing their belongings. By the time everything was ready, the sun had already risen. Thankfully, despite the hustle and bustle of the evening, no further incidents occurred.

The journey back was uneventful, and upon reaching Ganggang Camp, the village was bustling as if celebrating the New Year. Families had summoned their menfolk back from their labors on Ox Heart Mountain, and every household stewed pork with glass noodles.

That evening, Fatty and I sat cross-legged on the Kang in Yanzi's home, drinking with Yanzi's father. We had barely had a few drinks when we heard shouting outside, and even the village hunting dogs joined in the commotion. My intuition told me once again that something had gone wrong, and it was likely no small matter.

Stepping outside, we saw the Branch Secretary going from door to door, banging on them and calling people out: "This is terrible! There's been a landslide on Ox Heart Mountain, and the archaeological team is trapped inside. Everyone, quickly grab your tools and let's go rescue them!"

I only came to understand the details of this incident much later. It turned out that within the ancient tomb's underground palace on Ox Heart Mountain, layer upon layer was revealed. Archaeology, unlike tomb raiding, is not so straightforward or convenient. The archaeological team would excavate one level and then clean it, a process both time-consuming and laborious, while also clearing the surrounding chariot and horse pits, sacrificial burial pits, and other types of burial pits. It was only upon reaching the seventh underground layer that the archaeologists finally uncovered the coffin of the Empress Dowager.

China's policy on ancient tomb excavation is protective in nature, meaning that tombs are never actively excavated. Only when construction, earthquakes, tomb raiding, or other factors threaten the existence of ancient tombs are archaeologists dispatched to the site for emergency excavations.

 The ancient tomb from the Liao Dynasty at Lama Gully's Ox Heart Mountain is of such a nature that an earthquake caused the mountain to split open, revealing the underground palace within. Over the course of several years, as the archaeological team excavated, more than three thousand cultural relics have been unearthed. The mysterious veil of the final layer of the underground palace is also about to be lifted.

However, just as the seventh layer of the underground palace was breached, those in the village who had been collecting Western relics returned to Ganggang Camp. In celebration, they sent for their family members who were working at the archaeology site, asking to take a few days off. Normally, with the project's progress being extremely tight and the shortage of hands, leaves were hardly granted except during the festive seasons. That day, as if by some whimsical fate, since the underground palace had been dug down to the last layer with no major tasks remaining, the manager approved the leave for everyone, leaving only a dozen members of the archaeological team to clean up the seventh layer of the underground palace.

The workers from the village had barely left when a landslide occurred. The year of the earthquake, the mountain had cracked from the bottom up, and the waterfall at the mountain's peak had dried up from that time. The cracked part of the mountain, possibly hollow inside, could not withstand the pressure and the outward tension after opening, or perhaps it was related to the team digging too deep into the mountain, resulting in a very serious landslide accident. Eleven members of the archaeological team who were inside clearing the tomb master's coffin were buried within.

This incident was not reported to Ganggang Camp until half a day later. We only knew that there had been a collapse that trapped many people. It was a half-day's journey from there to Lama Gully, and we knew that even if we went, we wouldn't arrive in time to rescue anyone. But we could not neglect our duty, for those buried beneath were comrades sent by the organization to work there.

The branch secretary organized a rescue team while sending someone to notify the medical station in the banner. Fatty and I joined in, and after digging at Ox Heart Mountain for two days and nights, everyone had to accept the grim reality. The leaders from the banner arrived and, seeing the situation, knew there was no hope. The only thing left to do was to excavate the bodies of the victims for burial.

There was something peculiar about the situation. The mountain had not collapsed earlier or later but just after the villagers had taken leave, sparing most of them from the disaster. This could be seen as a fortunate stroke of luck amidst misfortune. In the grand scheme of things, there seems to be a divine will at play, though who can truly make sense of it.

 So, over fifty people stayed behind to continue their slow excavation on the mountain, while the rest of the elderly, women, and children returned to the village. This delay lasted another three or four days. Not wanting to linger any longer, I bid farewell to everyone and, accompanied by Fatty, made my way back to the long-missed Beijing.

Upon disembarking from the train, we didn't go anywhere else but headed straight for Panjiayuan. Big Gold Tooth was just as before, insufferably vulgar with a mercenary air about him. Unassuming as he might seem, he was actually a seasoned and experienced expert in Panjiayuan.

The moment Big Gold Tooth spotted us, he quickly set aside his business and bombarded us with questions, "Gentlemen, how come it took you so many days to return? I almost died of longing."

Fatty was itching to take out the two jade bi disks to show him and finally find out their worth, a question that had been troubling us both. Today, we hoped to get to the bottom of it.

Big Gold Tooth quickly signaled to us with his eyes, hinting not to take out the items: "Let's head to Dongsi instead. That restaurant where we had the mutton hotpot last time is quite nice and quiet. Panjiayuan is a mixed bag, crowded with watchful eyes; it's not the place for confidential talks. We can't afford to reveal the burial artifacts here. Just give me a moment to wrap up this deal, and we'll be on our way."

The 'burial artifacts' Big Gold Tooth referred to was industry jargon, as I've mentioned before. It's a synonym for 'burial artifact,' not specifically pertaining to antiques from the Ming Dynasty. It's a euphemism for burial artifacts in general, much like the terms 'antique' or 'antiques'—all related to grave robbing. In earlier times, they were simply called 'antiques' or 'bone artifacts,' denoting relics left from previous dynasties.

While we chatted, Big Gold Tooth managed to offload an early Qing Dynasty icebox and a Yongzheng-era official kiln marked rainbow small teapot to a foreigner accompanied by a Chinese translator. These items weren't particularly significant, just trifles really. We didn't see the exact price, but I reckoned the foreigner must have been fleeced.

After closing the deal, Big Gold Tooth counted his money: "Three days without business, and today's take is enough for three years of living. These foolish foreigners, buying a couple of fake goods as if they've found treasure, they can go home and cry. After counting his money, he turned to me and said, "Back during the Year of the Metal Rat, when the Eight-Nation Alliance entered Beijing, they didn't hesitate to swipe good things from us. Today, I reckon I've done a bit of heavenly justice. Master Hu, wouldn't you say that's the right reasoning?"

 Fatty and I, presently seeking his assistance, naturally deferred to him. I promptly picked up the conversation, praising Big Thumb: "In ancient times, Huo Yuanjia triumphed in a martial arts competition, defeating the Russian strongman. Today, we have Lord Jin, who cunningly appropriates the ill-gotten wealth of foreigners, a true glory for our country. His feats are indeed lofty."

After gathering our belongings, we once again visited the small restaurant where we first conversed. Big Gold Tooth might have made a tidy sum today, and buoyed by our flattery, he seemed quite elated. While drinking, he even recited a couple of lines from a Peking opera in a dramatic fashion: "You wretched foreign slave, I shall beat you with my steel whip, wah ya ya ya ya!"

Looking around, I noted that it wasn't the peak hour for dining; the restaurant was cold and clear, with only our table tucked in the corner. A waiter dozed off on the counter, and two attendants responsible for the hot pot squatted at the entrance chatting away, paying no attention to the three of us.

I then asked Fatty to take out the jade bi and show it to Big Gold Tooth, also briefly recounting the key points of our journey to the Northeast. Big Gold Tooth examined it meticulously, occasionally bringing it to his nose to sniff and even licking it with his tongue, inquiring about the details of the ancient tomb we explored.

Big Gold Tooth remarked, "When it comes to antique appraisal, I only know the basics—it's a craft handed down by my ancestors. Today, I shall display my humble skills. When such an item arrives, it's like a traditional doctor taking a pulse; there's also an inspection to be done, especially with funerary objects. Unlike common antiques, which are often handled and acquire a sheen over time, funerary objects are unearthed from grave robbing and have always been buried in ancient tombs. There's also talk of new and old tombs, water tombs, and dirty fights among grave robbers, known as 'Old Dipper'. First, we look at the craftsmanship, the shape, and the color. Next is smelling, which is a crucial step in identifying funerary objects. In the south, forgeries are aged by soaking in fecal pits, but while the color may age, the smell is distinctly different. It's more putrid than the scent of an ancient corpse's fart sealed inside with jade plugs to prevent the leakage of corpse qi and thus decay. The appearance might seem authentically aged, but one whiff can reveal the truth, fooling no expert's nose. Then there's asking: where does the item come from, and what is its provenance? Grave robbers naturally detail from which tomb the item was pilfered, allowing me to judge whether their account is true or false and if there are any flaws. This also helps to indirectly assess the item's authenticity and value. Lastly, it's about feeling with the hands, a realm that can only be understood and not conveyed in words. Countless antiques have passed through my hands, which are connected to my heart. A true antique, a treasure, regardless of its size or weight, can be felt through a heft, a touch, a pinch. This 'weight' isn't about the actual mass of the object. Antiques possess a spirit and a sense of profound weightiness accumulated over hundreds, even thousands of years. Fake goods, no matter how well-crafted, can never replicate this sensation."

 Fatty exclaimed, "Oh my goodness, you've said so much and I haven't understood a single word. Please, just tell us, how much are these two burial objects worth?"

Big Gold Tooth chuckled heartily, "Fat Master is getting anxious. I admit I've been rambling a bit, but it's all with good intentions. I hope that both of you will learn more about the knowledge of antiques appraisal in the future. After all, ancient large tombs contain hundreds, if not thousands, of burial artifacts. Without some understanding of this area, it will be difficult to make informed decisions in the future. Now, let me talk about these two burial objects. I can't name them exactly, but let's give them a provisional title based on their appearance: we can call them 'Moth-bodied Chi-patterned Double Dagger-shaped Bi.' As for their value..."

Antiques, you see, don't have a fixed price, unlike sugar or coal, which have a set price per pound. The value of antique collectibles is very subjective; as long as there's a buyer who values the item, it becomes valuable. Otherwise, no matter how exquisite the object is, if there's no buyer, it's essentially worthless.

For these two burial objects, I'll give you a baseline estimate. Based solely on their own merit, they would be valued between forty and fifty thousand yuan in the domestic market. Of course, their value would be significantly higher overseas, but this is the going rate in our country right now. When it comes time to sell, if there is a suitable buyer, the price could go much higher. It's hard to say exactly, as it will depend on the circumstances at the time.

 Big Gold Tooth mentioned that he once knew a fellow trader at Panjiayuan who dealt in all sorts of trinkets like tile pendants, arrow clusters, old coins, emblems, calligraphy supplies, iconography, and snuff bottles. Eventually, that guy shifted his business and started dealing in mummies out in Xinjiang. Now, he's made a fortune.

Fatty, puzzled, asked, "But aren't mummies just desiccated corpses? How could they be worth anything?"

Big Gold Tooth explained, "Not at all. What we see as just dried-up mummies, the international market sees as treasures. In Beijing, any mummy predating the Ming Dynasty goes for twenty thousand, but once it's taken abroad, it's worth a hundred thousand, my friend. Think about it. Foreigners are fascinated by such exotic curiosities. To them, our ancient Eastern land is shrouded in mystery. For instance, imagine the Natural History Museum in New York advertising an exhibition of a 'Mysterious Eastern Beauty Mummy' – it would cause a sensation. This mummy craze was sparked by last year's discovery of the Loulan female mummy at the Xiaoriver Tomb Cluster in Loulan. Even domestically, just put up an exhibition anywhere, and you'll have people lining up to see it. That's what I call a business opportunity."

After hearing this, both Fatty and I had an epiphany, nodding in agreement. We realized there was so much more to this than meets the eye. It's true what they say: without speaking, nothing is clear; without lighting, nothing shines. Plus, knowing that the two jade bi disks we had were worth around fifty thousand each, we felt our efforts hadn't been in vain.

I then inquired, "Lord Jin, what did you call that burial object again? It had such a tongue-twisting name."

Big Gold Tooth filled my cup with beer and said, "Don't rush. We've got all the time in the world today. Let me explain it slowly. It's called a moth-bodied, chi-patterned, double dagger-shaped bi. In our antique business, there's a rule: if an item doesn't have an official name, it's named based on its features."

"Just like the famous national treasure, the Zenghou Yi Chime Bells. This musical instrument certainly wasn't called by this name in the past. However, what it was originally called is now hard to verify. So, archaeologists named it based on the tomb it was excavated from and the type of instrument it is."

 This moth-bodied, chi-patterned, double dagger-shaped bi disc, its very name already encapsulates all of its distinctive features. Resembling a pair of moths, it was unearthed from the tomb of a Jurchen general. In ancient times, such moths symbolized warriors who would willingly sacrifice themselves. There's a saying, isn't there? Like a moth to a flame, they go without return, knowingly embracing death with open arms and resolute courage.

Nowadays, we're aware that moths, being unable to see, are merely drawn to the light. But the ancients didn't see it that way. They held in high esteem the spirit of these large moths, crafting accessories in their likeness to honor those who had distinguished themselves in battle. Wearing such an ornament was a mark of glory.

Look at the patterns on this piece, known as the Chiwen Pattern. It resembles the head of a lion and the body of a tiger, yet it is neither. The chi is a type of hornless dragon, and objects engraved with the Chiwen Pattern were believed to ward off evil spirits. Not long ago, a Ming Dynasty prince's tomb was excavated on Mount Mujia in Yunnan. You might have heard tales of the valiant heroes of the Ming in storybooks. Among Emperor Zhu Yuanzhang's generals was one named Mu Ying. The tomb unearthed belonged to this very Prince Mu, and inside, a pair of jade double chi bi discs similar to the ones you've discovered were found. In modern terms, these would be akin to medals or military decorations.

Let's talk about this pair. As the name implies, they come as a set, which is significant. Such adornments were meant to be hung on either side of a helmet, so only a pair holds value; a single piece is worthless.

The worth of this moth-bodied, chi-patterned, double dagger-shaped bi pair lies primarily in their historical and aesthetic value rather than the material itself, which is not particularly precious. They are made from a type of pale yellow variegated flint from the Caucasus region, not true jade. Although, if one insists on classifying it among jades, it wouldn't be entirely incorrect. High-quality pale yellow is quite valuable, changing into twelve distinct colors over the course of twelve hours – but the material of this particular pair is not of the finest grade.

Ah, there's an inscription here. The name Zi Ma is carved upon it, suggesting he was the owner of this pair of bi discs. This man appears to have been a marshal and the Left Supervisor of the Army during the late Jurchen period. During a siege, he reputedly killed over two hundred Mongol soldiers with his bow, displaying extraordinary valor before ultimately dying in battle. He was quite a figure, and legend has it that the Jurchen ruler exchanged his body from the Mongols for a hundred thousand taels of gold.

Listening to this feels like deciphering a myth. There are comprehensible parts, but not many. Fatty, uninterested in listening further, simply busied himself with the hotpot, sliding slices of beef tripe, lamb, chicken, and an assortment of vegetables and mushrooms into the simmering broth. Weary of grilled meats from recent days, he was eager for a change. Today, with the chance to indulge in lamb hotpot, he set to it with gusto, focusing solely on one thing: eating.

 I asked Big Gold Tooth what was hot in the antique market these days, something that could fetch a high price.

Big Gold Tooth replied, "The Westerners call our country's products porcelain, and it's safe to say that porcelain is always the hottest commodity in the antiques trade. The porcelain produced during the most glorious periods of Chinese history is unparalleled, even by modern advanced craftsmanship. Have you heard of Chenghua porcelain, for example? Especially the painted Chenghua porcelain—it's the cream of the crop. They don't have to be big; just a tiny piece, no bigger than a three-year-old child's toy, can be worth a hundred thousand yuan at Panjiayuan Market, no haggling necessary. You just mentioned that a lot of pottery and porcelain was found in the ancient tombs at the Black Wind Pass near the Sino-Mongolian Border, but it's a pity they weren't excavated. Those must be from the late Northern Song Dynasty. What a shame! I hate to say something you might not want to hear, don't take it the wrong way, but you've missed the mark this time. Those unexcavated jars and pots are worth far more than the moth-bodied, chi-patterned double dagger-shaped bi you've found. So, you two still have a lot to learn. Take the opportunity to come with me next time I go to the countryside to collect items. You'll see the tricks of the trade. After one successful trip, you could easily net a few million."

I agreed repeatedly and said to Big Gold Tooth, "I've actually been considering a bold idea. Next time, we'll go for a big haul, solve our problems in one go. Tomb raiding in the deep mountains and old forests is far riskier than in the mainland. No matter how many lives one might have, they can't withstand such wear and tear. I plan to target a top-grade feng shui treasure—a large tomb. But this is no child's play. I need to prepare thoroughly beforehand, or I might not be able to handle it."

Big Gold Tooth asked, "Master Hu, are you serious about hitting a big target? Have you chosen one yet?"

I replied, "No, the thought just crossed my mind. Large tombs in remote areas are extremely hard to find. Right now, I'm like a farmer, knowing only how to read the feng shui and locate the pulse of the land, completely clueless about historical and archaeological value assessments. I'm very blind in choosing targets and I'm not eager to act immediately. Our recent actions were a bit too hasty for quick success. We can't keep doing these short-term stunts. However, it's a double-edged sword. Although we didn't unearth any major items in the northeast this time, we did gain some experience and funds. It could be considered a practice run at grave robbing."

Big Gold Tooth said, "Hearing you talk like this reminds me suddenly of something about Xinjiang..."
